There's a lot I like personally and it by far outweighs my issues I have with it. The biggest one is more of a preference really, and that's the power supply. I wish it was just a USB cable of some kind, not the kinda bulky brick and old school proprietary connector thing. It feels sturdy, mic range is very good, it compliments other compatible devices nicely, and Alexa said we can get married when humans colonize Mars soon pretty happy with it overall.

We purchased our Echo Dot 3rd Gen on November 26th 2018 and it blew out in March of 2019. About 4 months of light use on a $50 speaker that is self powered (meaning the amp is internal so we didn't hook up anything wrong or feed too much power to it). The speaker should not have blown out. They will not replace it under any warranty. We did not play it over about 75% volume as it distorted at higher sound levels. Now it is completely busted and sounds awful. We would not recommend this product. It is too weak to withstand even light use. We might have played it for about 20 minutes per day on average over the course of the four months we had it. Amazon really should cover their own products with a year warranty. We do not recommend buying the Echo Dot 3rd Gen speaker made by Amazon. Trying to figure out what to buy to replace it since Amazon does not stand behind their own products.

I have been an Apple buyer for many years, and never would have considered purchasing anything electronic from Amazon for control of my electronics. I still only use iPhones, iPad, Mac, Apple tv, etc., but I am very impressed with the build quality, the price, the packaging and skills of Alexa. I cannot even get the Siri on my phone to answer me! I have now used products with Alexa in my thermostats and purchased plugs to control other electronic devices such as light in the home. It is very easy to install, and Alexa continues to add skills which makes the product a better value. It even lets you add your Amazon account to purchase products and listen to Amazon music just by talking to it. I am surprised Apple allowed or sat back and let Amazon pass it up significantly with Alexa as in my opinion, Siri doesn't come close, and I am an Apple loyal customer. Also, the sound quality is quite good for such a small little speaker, which is amazing considering everything this does, and the price being as low as it is during the holiday sales.

The new Echo Dot is far Superior to the last model. I loved the last generation Dot But this one has it beat. The new Echo Dot looks better, sound quality and base sounds are improved and the new Dot is more responsive to voice commands at a greater distance. I guess you can tell I am an Amazon Echo fan. Good Job Amazon!!!

I’ve had 2nd gen Dots for a few years. I love the new cloth design. The old covers were a bit ridiculous. Also a dust magnet.
I’m not going to be rough on a product I got for .99¢. A promotion for signing up with Amazon Music Ul. I was ditching another service anyways.
The speaker has a fuller and more immersive sound. Keep your expectations realistic. Music is more enjoyable and less tinny.
Alexa falls flat. Not the service, but when she interacts. The voice sounds like she’s underwater. Even worse if you have a slight echo. Picture the bathroom. Not a deal-breaker, but still annoying. I’m more sensitive to tones with my blindness. Hopefully a correction for the next generation. Also, Google Mini doesn’t suffer from this. Relatively similar in size.
My REAL issue is the AC adapter. Who’s brilliant idea was it to ditch the micro USB? Less intrusive over this monstrosity that plugs in. Not practical for areas like a bathroom. Certainly not dealing with a Johnny I’ve design aesthetic. Yeah, I know it’s a $50 product. Aesthetics bring a sense of zen into their respective placement.
All said, an overall decent product. Which has a definite fuller sound.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Short Unhappy Life of My Echo Dot
reviews.reviewText:
I only got the Echo Dot because Amazon customer service told me I could not control my second AmazonBasics microwave with my Amazon Tap, which worked fine with my first microwave. That was incorrect. All I had to do was change my vocal command from "Alexa, two minutes microwave" to "Alexa, two minutes ON microwave." Of course, I only found that out AFTER I bought two Echo devices as a result of the conversation with Amazon.

Because Amazon had a $99 deal for Echo and Echo Dot together, I pounced. I didn't realize you needed the same Echo model to use two of them to produce stereo sound. I have two new Echo devices that cannot produce stereo sound together. With that realization, both devices lost value.

My Amazon Tap -- whose mention the Amazon customer service people found funny for some reason -- has a rechargeable battery and a charging base as well as a micro-USB port in the actual unit. I use it as a portable device throughout my house and outside. Really well-designed, portable and flexible. Both the Echo and Echo dot require a/c power, lowering further the value of both for my purposes.

The increase in sound quality between the Echo and the Dot is easily worth the price difference. I was dumb to get the Dot.

In a logical progression of a product that lost utility the longer I owned it, I dropped it, the sound stopped working (the lights responded to my vocal commands and it started the microwave though) and I threw it out. In venting my frustration with a hammer, I learned the unit is sturdy and I could only put a slight hole in it after about 10 hard whacks on a concrete floor.

I feel better now. All that stress and disappointment only cost me $29.

I've tried really hard to like this and make it work but the alexa service is very inconsistent at best. The device hears and recognizes commands correctly, just doesn't do them or does something else more often than not. Turning lights on or off can take anywhere from instant up to a minute with no discernible cause. Every rep insists on starting over with troubleshooting the network that has previously been cleared of fault and weeks later higher tier support haven't responded. What music you get seems to be pretty random and will change anytime you give it any other command during playback and the advertised "pizza alarm" might burn your house down since all alarms & timers seem to be forgotten about 20% of the time, sometimes executing much later but mostly as if never set (even though confirmed when set). Feel free to ask it anything anytime you want to hear "I don't know that".

reviews.reviewTitle: Impressive sound quality and voice recognition.
reviews.reviewText:
So, this is my first Alexa device. I'd been holding out because I'd witnessed my friends struggle with earlier versions of Alexa, yelling at it when it didn't obey a voice command and I wasn't impressed by the sound.
But, Amazon had a great sale on the Dot so I figured I'd try it out. The sound quality is amazing. I can't believe this little thing has such a big sound.
The voice recognition is really good too. I rarely have to repeat a command and it recognizes even the most brief command from me. For instance, first thing in the morning I'm groggy and mumble "Computer, Lana DelRay" and it plays Lana DelRay easily.
I call it "Computer" because you can change the wake word options on this model. Your choices are Alexa, Amazon, Echo or Computer. I chose Computer because I'm a Trekkie and addressing the device like Jean-Luc Picard makes my inner nerd happy. I assume that's why they made that option available in the first place.
I like the Skills. Particularly the morning skill. I can say Good Morning and it gives me the weather, calendar and news.
I don't use the "Tell Me Joke" skill or anything like that, but there are a couple of fun Star Trek skills you can add that are fun.
All in all I'm very happy with this device. I may have to buy a smart plug for my lamp and expand Alexa's responsibilities.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Sound from a Tiny Speaker With the same options of the first gen.
reviews.reviewText: Loved the fuller sound. The only thing I hated is that the plug it plugs into takes up a whole regular outlet.

I have two 3rd generation Echo Dots. I bought them right before Christmas as gifts for my husband. At first they were both great! We still do enjoy them, especially for the music, but the speakers in both are junk. If I listen to music for more than 15-20 minutes, then sound and Alexa become distorted and static like. If I turn them off for a couple hours the sound returns to normal, but only for a short while. I have posted a video with this review as an example of what you will get if you purchase an Echo Dot 3rd generation. I have searched Amazon to see if I can get them replaced, but I can't get anywhere. I hit one wall after another. If it were just one of the dots I would just figure I got a bad one, but it's both! We have a regular Echo also and have had no trouble.

Just received my Alexa eco last week. I was soooo excited when it came but I expected a Bluetooth speaker that I could connect my Apple Music with but I guess my wrong doing for not reading more into it. I do agree with a few reviews that it seems Alexa can not hear that well. I’d have to repeat myself even in close range. The adapter is pretty big and bulky. Why do I have to download so many apps just to use this 1 thing??! Amazon music is okay but doesn’t carry as much music as I’d like. I thought I’d at least be able to use Pandora but couldn’t find that option although it seems the older ones do. All in all may be returning I’ll give her another week but I’m not Impressed. The design and sandstone color is very nice and goes with my decor.

*I did return my Alexa but Amazon then attempt to contact me but I was so busy with work and then the holidays it was just a hassle because I would have to be home for the assistance right lol. Thanks anyway Amazon*

Alexa, big or small, is nearly useless. She has massive problems finding any useful information. She plays trivia games well, orders things off amazon, and the speakers sound good, thats about the end of what it does well. All of those wonderful apps that make it useful...music, podcast, controlling other devices, etc, etc....all of that costs more money. $2 a month here, $5 a month there, $9 a month for this, $12 a month for that. You want this thing to be useful...it'll end up costing you about a $100 a month.

Update:
Wow ... beware "Big Brother". If you give Amazon a bad review, they will call you and call you. They will harass you and pressure you into changing your review. They won't actually do anything about the reasons you gave them a bad review, but they will flex their corporate muscle and remind you how big they are.

reviews.reviewTitle: Alexa, "How do I return a 3rd Gen Echo Dot to Amazon???"
reviews.reviewText:
I was impressed by the sound of my Google Home Mini, but Amazon's 3rd Gen Echo Dot sounds MUCH BETTER. This is our 5th Amazon device we ordered. All have Alexa enabled.
Ask Alexa "Where is "Ludowici"?" Answer: "31°42′38″N 81°44′40″W" + "Does that ANSWER your question???" Reply: 'NO!" Alexa replies "Thank you for helping us improve our database." [="Oh, it's what I LIVE FOR, Alexa. I paid money, bought Echo Dot 3 so I could HELP YOU!!!" I can ALWAYS ask Google Home Assistant when I want USEFUL information! ] I even took the time to run the speech setup so Alexa better recognizes my voice.
Alexa needs to take special ed courses with the trade school kids. Meanwhile our Google Assistant performs very well.
[An hour after posting this Amazon called me asking if they might help me with my device. I replied, "NO it's all packaged up for return." Caller then asked if I "Might re-read my review and MODERATE my negative comments somewhat. =So many people tell US it's such an extremely helpful device. " >>>DEAR AMAZON: I call them THE WAY I SEE THEM. You want BETTER REVIEWS? ...DO NOT peddle half-baked, not ready to use, crap. Note: I moderated. Crap was NOT the word I had in mind. ]

I've had several Echo Dots for a while, but last year my son took my living room dot to his room, so I finally decided to replace it. WOW! The sound quality and overall heft of the 3rd gen is leaps and bounds above gen 2! I'm seriously trying to decide if I should replace all our gen 2s with 3s because it is markedly better. The volume is louder, the sound richer and deeper, and the time it took to connect was much faster.
All that said, if you're on the fence about getting one, let me tell you what a lifesaver they have been to my family. I easily juggle large meal prep with my multiple timers and quick conversions from Alexa while jamming to my customized cooking playlist. We all use the shopping list function - even my youngest knows when he's used the last of whatever he needs to tell it to Alexa so I can replace it. But the best perk of all has been seeing my 19 year old brain injury survivor utilize it to remind himself of... everything. She is his alarm when he needs to get up for an appointment, she reminds him to shower and put on clean clothes, she reminds him of appointments and activities, she even plays his favorite music and tells him jokes. But seriously, she has helped him start adulting, and that has been priceless!

We added the 3rd generation Echo Dot to two existing Echo Dots (not sure if 1st or 2nd gen). I'm not sure what they had in mind besides trying to make it more appealing looking and sound better. Yes, it looks more refined than the previous iterations. Sound? There definitely is more bass- but at the expense of treble. You can hear it when Alexa speaks and even after a couple weeks I prefer the voice on the earlier generations. I suppose music is a bit better- and one can argue that you can beam to bluetooth speakers, etc.

Gen 3 Dot is heavier than the first two and requires a bulkier power supply. I suppose it draws more power as well. With the earlier versions you could use any 5v charger with enough amperage to drive the Dot. So should the power supply fail it would be more of a challenge to replace. A huge worry? No. But a concern nonetheless.

Don't get me wrong, we love having Alexa in 3 rooms. We've converted most of the switches throughout the house to smart dimmers, have smart bulbs in other areas and smart switches for coffee, tea, cabinet lights. For the most part we think the Alexa concept is genius with so many vendors on board now. I think it's a little pricey for what it is, but I guess Amazon sells millions at this price, so who am I to argue?

Bottom line: If you're looking to see what Echo and Alexa are about but unsure, maybe find a refurbished earlier generation. If you want to jump in you probably won't be disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Got This For My 86 Year Old Grandmother
reviews.reviewText:
My grandfather died a few years ago and my grandmother is now in an assisted living facility.

We were trying to figure out what to get her for Christmas which is tough since her room is fairly small and really what do you get someone in their 80's?

Well, this Echo Dot was on sale and we thought maybe we could program it with all of her kid's and grandkid's birthdays and install some bible stuff on it for her. We also thought maybe it would give her someone to talk to and pass the time if she could figure out how to use it. She's not a big computer or smart phone fan but figured what the heck, if she doesn't like it we'll give it to one of the kids lol.

I did install a daily bible verse app and everyone's birthdays along with some other custom routines for her so every morning it goes through birthday reminders and reads her daily bible verse.

I also printed out a sheet of common things to ask it so she could get started.

It started off a little rough when we first gave it to her, I did program it to say it was a Christian if you ask it what religion it is but I did tell her not to baptize it as the little woman named Alexa that lives inside it would die.

She had a hard time with calling it Alexa at first, she kept wanting to call her Alexis and then would get frustrated that it wouldn't listen to her.

I also had to explain to her that she couldn't really have a full conversation with her and that she had to stick to simple commands. She initially would say stuff like "Alexis, this is Esther" so Alexa would just say "hmm, I'm not sure about that" so she would respond "well I am".

I figured if nothing else at least it would go through the every morning routine with her even if she couldn't get the hang of asking it things.

The staff at the assisted living facility found out she had this and they started playing with it. I got a Spotify subscription for it so she could listen to music if she wanted but I figured I'd probably just end up cancelling it since I doubted she would use it. Turns out that's now what she uses it for the most. One of the nurses started asking it to play old Roger Miller songs when she came in to give her pills and my grandma thought that was pretty cool.

Now anytime someone goes to visit her she tells them all about her Alexis. It was probably the best gift we could have gotten her for Christmas lol.

reviews.reviewTitle: impossible to understand intercom messages and other problems
reviews.reviewText:
The echo dot 2nd generation worked perfectly as an intercom using the “drop in” command . The 3rd generation echo dot has the audio going in and out mid sentence making it impossible to understand the echo as an intercom. As time went on the 3rd generation speaker did not get any clearer. Swapping out one 3rd generation for another did not solve the problems with clarity. The 3rd generation has problems when two people are talking more than the 2nd generation. Also music playing on either side of the connection will cause problems with message clarity on the 3rd generation echo dot. The 3rd generation device rather than learning your voice and distinguishing when you talk and subtracting out background noise has the background noise interfere with message clarity. The 2nd generation echo dot does not have as much background noise, music or both people talking at the same time causing the speaker to garble the message as the 3rd generation. The 3rd generation relies on training the user to turn down the music, background noise and to wait patiently while the person on the other end talks. As customers, We expect more from our "artificial intelligent" devices.

Service was responsive and polite and made overtures to correct any problems. However, promised call backs were not made even though they were scheduled. The service representative did NOT give us a call back number or email to respond or add additional concerns. When additional concerns were raised on the phone, the service representative listened patiently, but did not give us any solutions or answers. Hindsight suggests that perhaps the service representative was more concerned with the low rating of the device than correcting the problem?

Other problems, the turn in policy on the 1st and 2nd generation echo when upgrading to the 3rd generation must be made at the time of purchase and does not reduced bargain pricing such as the buy one get on free deal that was advertised. We are still not clear how the turn in your old to get a discount on the new works, even after talking to the service representative.

The 3rd generation echo dot appears to be just as dumb as the other echo devices. This means that the ability to answer questions with answers other than "sorry, i dont understand" or "sorry I cannot help you with that" has not improved. We have both the echo dots which we use primarily as an intercom device, and the ok google device. The ok google device does not appear to work as an intercom or an announcement device, but it answers many more questions with actual practical answers from wikipedia and the irs.gov websites. So other than the intercom and broadcast announcement function, the ok google is the more useful device.

Another problem we have encountered is that the echo dot devices often disconnect from the WiFi and require reconnection much more often than the ok google device. Unfortunately, these "artificial intelligence" digital assistants are not smart enough to reconnect to the WiFi without human help and the use of a phone, tablet or computer based application or program. The process of reconnection is anything but intuitive and is an avoidable nuisance. We as customers expect that our digital assistants should be smart enough to reconnect to the WiFi without human intervention. Artificial Intelligent devices are not very intelligent if they cannot reconnect to the WiFi without human intervention.

As a customer, we hope that the software upgrades will address these problems. As a loyal Amazon customer and supporter of the echo devices and technology, we expect more from our "artificial intelligent" devices. At the very least the devices should become smarter, more useful, and less of a pain in the ass as time goes on. So far our experience has been the opposite, the devices seem a bit dumber, less useful and more of a pain in the ass.

We purchased a TP-link home mesh system with three channels (the expensive one) because our echo dot version 3 network kept disconnecting. The description of the mesh network device said it was compatible with the Alexa. The devices keep disconnecting and now the drop in function between the home office echo dot 3 and the bedroom echo dot 3 no longer functions even though the echo dot 3 (ED3) in the bedroom can drop in on the ED3 in the home office. Considering the only reason we purchased this system for over $1000 for all equipment was to get a functioning intercom.

The sound quality and volume are SIGNIFICANTLY different from the 2nd gen. However, once you begin to really pump this up (turn the volume up) the bass comes through so much that the voice of the artist turns down way too much.

**ALSO, MY BIGGEST ISSUE SO FAR HAS BEEN THE MICROPHONE ARRAY ON THIS THIRD GEN. I FIND MYSELF CONSTANTLY HAVING TO REPEAT MYSELF TO GET ITS ATTENTION ESPECIALLY IF I HAVE THE TV ON OR MUSIC PLAYING. THE SECOND GEN COULD HEAR ME FINE WHEN THOSE THINGS WERE PLAYING HOWEVER WITH ONLY FOUR MICS, THE THIRD GEN DOESN'T SEEM TO BE HANDLING THIS SO WELL. I HAVE THIS IN MY ROOM WHICH IS A VERY SMALL ROOM SO I THINK THIS IS PRETTY UNEXCUSABLE.**

Withthat in mind this is a good pick up if you're coming from the second generation echo.. I hope that Amazon can fix the microphone issues I've been having

We have children that constantly ask us questions -trivia type questions: what's a bowling ball made of? How do birds migrate? etc. We bought an Amazon Echo Dot and a Google Home Mini to compare how they would rise to the challenge. Without doubt, the Amazon Echo is completely unsatisfactory. I gather they have no rights to access google search algorithms and it shows. Question after question is answered with "Hmmm, I don't know that one".

If you are in the mood to spend money, however, it appears that Echo DOT is your device. It will let you buy things with ease. You can also access anything in Prime (music for instance).

The kids have quickly gravitated to the Google Mini as the "go to" device. Alexa may just get returned.

UPDATE: I really tried to make this work. The architecture of the device and the HMI is all wrong from what I wanted. I guess I wanted a personal assistant and Alexa is not that. After scrolling through countless "skills" that all seem to just spout useless data, I loaded three that I thought would be useful and helpful; Pandora, Airport Weather, and the skills needed to control switches in the house. Starting with the last, over half of the switches I own already were not recognized by the device. Not that I need to use my voice to control anything. They are all programmed with timers. It's actually easier to open the app on my phone and do what I want rather than go through the vocal gymnastics to get Alexa to understand anything.

Pandora seemed to play what it wanted rather than my stations. Very frustrating.

The Airport Weather skill simply reported it was installed every time I asked for the weather at a local station. My family, in complete frustration, yelled at me to get rid of the thing rather than keep trying to use it over and over and not get what I wanted.

As for the mini, we plugged it in and asked it to give us information, and while not perfect, it responded more along the lines of what was expected.

I'm updating this to a one-star as I couldn't find a single useful thing to do with this device after spending way too much time looking at "skills". It does nothing in a better or more efficient way than that which already do. Perhaps it is a indication of what a data-rich world we live in that a device that supposedly is a source of information and help is nothing more than frustrating noise. Too bad.

The device is being returned as unsatisfactory and not doing what it was described to do.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great device for Nursing Home Residents!!!
reviews.reviewText:
This small device has brought my dad so much happiness - he lives in a nursing home and wasn’t able to have your typical phone and would lose his cell phone. He loves music and reading books and so after using a dot at home I bought one for him.

He is so much more upbeat now because he is able to call us when he wants and if he needs something. He listens to music all the time and he can even enjoy a book if he wants since his eyesight is no longer that great. I can’t say enough great things about this device and technology. We just wrote up a list of most frequently used commands so my dad would always be able to have them available if he didn’t remember because of his dementia.

The echo dot is the absolute best!! I would highly reccomend to anyone for home use .... and most of all... for a nursing home setting.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great sound, keep it away from the kitchen.
reviews.reviewText:
Update: Really Amazon? Was it *completely* necessary to make the plug so huge you can’t plug in anything else? Just like Apple, you guys are turning into a bunch of money grubbing jerks who make everything so specific that it cant be used with anything else, and you have to buy even more stuff to make it compatible to even make the attempt. (see photo of 3 outlet adapter)

The appearance and sound are better than expected. But the reason I gave only 3 stars is: if you are going to use this device in a kitchen or even near one, WHYYYYYY would Amazon choose to make it from a textile material that you can’t clean? This unit WAS destined for the kitchen area, but now I have to do some shuffling to put it away from where moisture and grease will make it all gross.

Also, the non-slip (silicone?) material on the bottom REEKS. The smell will hopefully fade, but it currently stinks like mold and rubber, and it’s been out of the packaging for over an hour.

Also, Amazon has gone the way of money-grubbing Apple, in making the power cable unit-specific. I took note because of a cable-chewing kitten we have, and with the gen-2s, you can replace the micro cable. This one is one cable, from unit to outlet. I haven’t checked the price of a replacement yet, but I’m certain it is more expensive than a 3 pack of amazon basic 6’ micro cables.

reviews.reviewTitle: The price just doubled for the same product.......yikes Amazon
reviews.reviewText:
Review Update 2/13/19
Below I will praise this product for all it's amazing features for it's price, but bear in mind this review was written before Amazon decided to DOUBLE the price of the device. At it's current price, I cannot recommend the product because in all honesty you are fully capable of living a normal life without it. Sure it's novel in many ways, and it was well worth it just to toy with before....but I can't say it is now. It's a shame because I initially bought just two, but I was planning to buy more to put around the house very soon. Not anymore. I feel cheated in a way because I already invested into this whole Alexa thing with the intention to expand and buy more. That's not going to happen unless I can buy more Dots at the same price I paid for the others. Until then I'm removing 4 stars.

Review Update 3/12/19
I came back to check prices a month after revising my review to find that prices have increased yet again. When I bought my first 2 echo dot 3rd gen devices they were $29 each, and 2 for $50. A couple months later they were $49 each and 2 for $60. Now they're $49 each and 2 for $80. I've invested in an Echo Connect so my Mom can use these to call 911 should she fall, and I would love to add a couple more Echo Dots to the network to increase coverage of our home. I just logged in to buy 2 more for $60 only to find that it's now 2 for $80. I guess I'll just wait till next Christmas when Google and Amazon are competing more aggressively.

Original Review:

(I have removed my original review which praised this product as a must have device based on value. With Amazon constantly upping the price for the exact same product, I can no longer suggest people invest in this product line. My advice now is to not get sucked in to the whole Alexa thing because you cannot rely on Amazon to maintain consistent pricing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fantastic technology - but one HUGE flaw that makes it worthless
reviews.reviewText:
I loved this fantastic piece of home automation/personal assistant technology...for about two days. That’s when we experienced one of our, all too frequent (two - three time daily)
Momentary WiFi signal service drops - from our only one choice, D- rated local internet service provider (which caused ALL our Echo devices to drop offline - and these devices do NOTHING without a WIFI signal. Zip! Moments or hours later when the same WiFi signal was restored, NOTHING we tried could get the Echos to simply reacquire that same unchanged WiFi signal. After a 40minute tech support call to Amazon none of our Echo devices was able to reconnect... and Alexa can’t do ——- without a WiFi signal. Seriously, an Apollo moon launch seemed easier than getting any one of our Echo devices back to tea quite a simple WiFi signal. After 15 minutes w tech support, we had DELETED every Echo device in our house (and deleted all our playlists, preferences and EVERYTHIG else we spent HOURS setting up. Really! I asked after the tech call went past 20 minutes with no results... Reacquiring a dropped out WiFi SHOULD be one simple voice command or button push (if the WiFi signal /credentials hasn’t changed since it was last connected). After working 45 min w tech support we still had no luck on reconnecting ANY Echo device to our lame WiFi (which can drop in and out several times a day) at which point I asked the Amazon agent - do we have to go through this entire procedure EVERY TIME our lame WiFi signal drops out for even a second, to which she replied YES - at which point I told the agent to initiate a return for all of our Echo devices and related home automation devices. They were completely worthless to me with this one GLARING flaw. (And I had all the latest 2nd and 3rd gen High end Echo devices. No one thought to fix the huge flaw in three generations of the product line)? Well maybe I’m the only one who has WiFi that comes and goes.

I love amazon and regularly place orders over $1000 a month just because it’s SO easy to do and always flawlessly fufilled...except the one MAJOR, MAJOR flaw in the whole, otherwise FANTASTIC Echo series of devices. The entire dropped WiFi signal SHOULD be fixed (provided the WiFi credentials haven’t changed) with a simple ALEXA, Reconnect to WiFi voice command or a one button push...and be back online and in business right away without the need of a 45 minute PLUS tech support call.

Echo and Alexa are my favorite home Automation /personal assistant/ direct audio command to buy anything and everything from my beloved Amazon account, but this one flaw RUINED EVERYTHING. Other than that flaw I was fully investing into the whole Amazon Echo lifestyle, but unfortunately if your WiFi drops in and out your hosed and the entire investment in time and resources was for NOTHING!

reviews.reviewTitle: Works fine for most things, but not for what I actually bought it for.
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased two of these for my children for xmas. I thought they'd be fun for them to have. They enjoy listening to music and asking Alexa questions.

The problems arises when we try to use it for the main reason I purchased it: drop in/calling. My children are young and my wife and I work opposite schedules so I really liked the idea of them both having something they can use if they ever need to get in touch with us since they're still too young for cell phones.

The first day I set up the Echo's they were both working totally fine. They were able to drop in/call and receive as well. But later that night they both stopped working in that way. Everything else worked fine still.

I tried troubleshooting myself for a couple of hours. I'm 35 years old and consider myself advanced with tech, so this wasn't a mysterious contraption I was unfamiliar with. I have all sorts of smart devices, sound systems and AV stuff in my house and I've set it all up myself without trouble. But I couldn't get these to work properly. If I try to use the echo to call someone it just says "that person isn't in your contacts. An adult can add contacts in the Alexa app" and won't make the call. No matter who I try. I've reimported the contacts. I've made separate contacts within the Alexa app. I tried factory restoring the Echo's and starting from scratch. Nothing helped.

So I finally contacted Amazon support. After just about an hour on chat with someone trying various "fixes", none of which worked, the support member suddenly said "Oh, I see you're in the US. This is Amazon support India, we cannot help you. Contact Amazon USA." Then the chat stopped. They didn't give me any contact info of who I should be communicating with about it. I'm in SoCal and I got to the chat through the Amazon website so I have no idea why I would've been speaking with the wrong continent for support.

Since then I haven't tried fixing them anymore. In total I spent around 4 hours trying to get them working again to no avail. I haven't contacted Amazon support again because I just don't have anymore time to wast in my life. At least the kids still enjoy them for music, but I'm not happy at all with the purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: The sound just crackled at minimal volume!!!
reviews.reviewText:
Update: customer service reached out to me about my issue.

Tonight (Jan 20th, 2018) I noticed the speaker crackled and had trouble playing the songs "Lost Boys" and a few other songs at 30% volume. I was able to record and will post a video. I did get a great holiday deal on the speaker, however it appears the speaker might not even last a year if this is the quality it provides!!! This doesn't even seem worth the money if it can't play lullabies without distortion NOT at 100% volume...

reviews.reviewTitle: terrible attention from Mexico if you bought at amazon.com USA
reviews.reviewText:
Today I am very happy to buy the echo dot at amazon.com, very excited as I arrive I have called amazon USA because I bought it on amazon.com, I asked with my little English that if I could contact someone who speaks in Spanish, very kindly transferred me to amazon mexico and the person who attended me totally refused to help me, I begged him to help me, wanted to know what he was doing, what could be done with ECHO, nothing technical, nothing configuration, just wanted to know functionalities , but the amazon area echo in mexico refused to give me any information, that if he did not speak in English then he would use the chat.

I'm going sad with amazon echo support, I do not recommend any Spanish-speaking person to buy the product in the USA because they will close the doors to the telephone support in Spanish when they transfer you to mexico, unless you love the long talks via written chat that is where they recommend giving support if you do not speak English.

I will wait for my device echo, very sure the device will work wonderfully, but I give it a star for the bad attitude of the support area of ​​Mexico who refused to answer basic questions about the product, I just wanted to know only what I could do with Alexa.

the product and the support go united if one of the two fails is as if everything failed.

IMPORTANT NOTE: I was then taken care of by a young man in Spanish in amazon USA in the sales area, he was very careful to help me, to try locate someone who speaks Spanish in the area of ​​echo USA, very sure if they exist but at the moment of my call or they were not or were attending to other users, the good attitude of the amazon youth USA has calmed my spirits, I will remain faithful to amazon USA.

Love my Echo Dot, had been thinking about purchasing one for a while, but what finally convinced me to purchase it was a notice on the Amazon.com website on the Echo Dot details and purchase page. It said with this purchase you will receive 3 months free membership to Amazon music unlimited. That was the deal maker! It said the promo code for my free membership would be included in the notification email that my item had shipped. Received the notification email but no promo code. Contacted Amazon customer service, was transferred 3 times, to end up back with one of the original reps just to be told this promotion was not available with my purchase & I dont what other bs blah blah blah excuse. Not happy at all...and funny thing is I can't find that promo ad anywhere now. If anyone sees this when purchasing, do yourself a favor and take a screenshot. Hate being petty but hate bs promotion scams more. I was very excited about my free membership!

reviews.reviewTitle: Love the Echo dot, but there is on caveat...
reviews.reviewText:
Pros:
I love my Echos. I have one in each bedroom to control lights, play music, wake me up, report the weather or news, get notifications on Amazon orders, play games, create calendar events and reminders, set timers, you name it. These are wonderful little devices. There is a phone app that goes with it that allows you do do all sorts of neat things like set up routines that do multiple things. For example, when I say "Alexa, Good Morning," and she turns on the lights, plays the weather, and then turns on my favorite music.

Cons:
After I bought three Echos, I discovered that if you have multiple Echos playing Prime Music, you can play the same music to all Echos in a group, but you cannot play different music on each device unless you pay for a family subscription to Prime Music or you set up the Echos to play music from other sources (such as Pandora or Spotify). So if my son and I want to listen to music in our respective room's at the same time, one of us has to use a source other than Prime Music, or we have to pay $10/mo for a family Prime Music subscription. I was a little irked by this discovery.

Wishlist:
I wish that Amazon would not require a monthly subscription to enjoy Prime Music on multiple Echo devices simultaneously.

I wish there was a separate volume setting for the Alexa's voice verses music. Sometimes I want the music at a low volume, but then you can barely hear her when she talks.

I wish there were a few more options for wake words or even a custom wake word. When all my Echo's had the default wake word, "Alexa," they would all wake up when I wanted to speak to the one in my room, so I decided to rename my daughter's and son's Echos. However, there are only four names to choose from.

I want to say my Dad had an accident last November and Alexa made our lives so much better. He was paralyzed and now he has more movement but not much. Alexa and the Alexa plugs made it where he could turn on the TV and lamp. You don’t think about those simple things much but when you can’t even turn on a light when you wake up until someone else does it you could be laying in the dark for 30 minutes if your caregivers are busy. If you want to go to bed but can’t turn off the tv or light you’re at someone else’s mercy. My dad couldn’t use his phone but Alexa made it where he could call people. My kids even got to drop in on their Grandpa when they wanted. He was able to hear the news if he wanted and his favorite was listening to music. When all you can do it lay in bed it’s amazing to be able to have those simple freedoms and abilities. I am beyond thankful for Alexa. My dad is at a facility now doing acute physical therapy and they don’t have good WIFI and Alexa. Any connect and it’s so sad to us but for the last year it was his lifeline and once he is well enough to come home (if he ever is) then I’m sure she will be very valuable again. Thanks Amazon for such a user friendly product.

reviews.reviewTitle: I don't know why I've resisted, I can't believe I'm writing this review :-)
reviews.reviewText:
Ok, a little back story. I purchased the Ecobee4 last year and one of the 1st things I did after installing was turn off Alexa. I didn't want to use it and I didn't want it "listening in" on my conversations.

A few months ago, my TV died and I purchased the Fire TV stick to work with a flat screen TV that no one was using. I had a Roku on the older TV and was always frustrated that I couldn't just tell it what I wanted to watch. When I got the Fire TV stick, it was soooooo easy just to say what I wanted without having to go through the online keyboard to type out my message (I always felt like I was typing out morse code or something).

Anyway, I was amazed at how easy the Fire stick was, so I turned on Alexa in the Ecobee. OMG, the first time I used it, my hands were full and I was coming into the house in the evening. I couldn't get to my phone to use the app to turn on the lights. I remembered the Ecobee and had Alexa turn on the lights. WOW, WOW, WOW. I know for some, this may seem like a bit of overkill, but before that night I never realized how easy using Alexa could be. To turn on/off my lights, I would get out my phone, use the app. I would get out my phone, use the app, adjust the thermostat. I did everything from my phone. I know I can say "Hey Siri" for my phone to respond without taking the phone out, but Siri has NEVER been able to find my devices or Siri indicates the device aren't responding, very frustrating.

After a few days of the Ecobee use, I ordered a Dot!!! I don't know why I resisted this technology for so long. I've had it on my Kindle and never used it. It didn't seem intuitive to use, I felt like I was manufacturing a reason to say "Alexa". OMG #2, today I created a grocery list, WHILE I WAS IN THE KITCHEN, without having to find my phone or pencil/paper. I added to that grocery list during the day with just my voice!!! I went to the store and USED THAT SHOPPING LIST and didn't forget anything!!!!! I left the store thinking, Alexa, where have you been all my life :-).

Now, I've purchased a dot for my elderly mom and I got some of the Alexa outlets so she can control the lights, TV, etc. from her device.

I really want the Echo for my car!!! I tried asking Siri to look something up while I was driving and Siri COULDN'T DO IT!!!! The information I Siri provided was incorrect. As a test, when I came home I gave the same instructions to the Echo and was given the correct info!!!! I know Alexa in the car would have been able to provide the correct info!!!!

If you're on the fence about the usefulness of this device, try it and you'll be convinced it's well worth the purchase. Complementary products seem to integrate smoothly and efficiently with Alexa. I've never had a problem with Alexa finding the lights and Apple doesn't work with Nest or Ecobee. If you're concerned about what Alexa records, I've viewed the recordings and there's was nothing there of concern and if there were, I could delete the information.

BUY THIS DEVICE!!!! :-)

You tell Alexa “turn off the lights” and she says “I didn’t find a device named lights”. When you say “turn off the lights in the bedroom” she says “there are no devices name lights bedroom”. But if you phrase it differently like “turn on the lights in the bedroom” she suddenly realizes I have Hue, and Lutron hubs and does something. It seems like Alexa should be smart enough to know the room she is assigned to, and without being specific the generic term “lights” should automatically refer to the ones in that same assigned room.

I also use a Logitech Harmony with hub. With the media control specifically, the Alexa and Logitech don’t seem to integrate well with “activities”, so when you want to do something like “Watch Netflix” (which is an activity on my Logitech remote that turns on the TV, Xbox, and the audio amplifier), once again Alexa I gets stupid and claims I have no devices that can do that operation. Instead I must generically say turn on the Xbox (which also turns on the other devices), But doesn’t switch the inputs automatically.

In general it just feels like she needs to understand more slang, and metaphorical terms... the current implementation is very frustrating to use because you have to memorize specific phrases and talk like a computer.

I had seven (7) Echo devices (in my home) before purchasing this one (24 bucks was just too good to pass up). This one was easier to set up (not that the previous generations were hard...). I have both Gen 1 and Gen 2 Dots but this one is a big improvement because it looks and feels like a better product (pure aesthetics) but in concrete terms it sounds MUCH better than the previous two Dots have sounded. I bought JBL Flip 4's which I have hard-wired to the others in order to get acceptable sound (while still in a small space). They have worked out well and sound great (best BlueTooth speakers I've had), but the 3rd generation sounds fully acceptable (with music) on it's own and I'm not sure I would have bought a JBL to go with it had the others been this good. That, in addition to a more refined "look & feel" make this most popular Echo model a clear winner from my point of view. Over the almost 3 years that I've had Echos, they have continually expanded in usefulness. I live alone (am 74) and frankly enjoy having a voice in the house...but she handles music, lights, thermostat, garage door, ordering pizza, reordering Amazon items (previously ordered), etc. So I get a lot of use out of these units in every room in my house that I frequently occupy. The total lack of latency problems in music groups is, frankly, quite amazing to me. Basically, I'm an Apple guy, but the Echo products were first to market and I'm very satisfied with the products and the progress that they've made over these 3 years. Also, I'm very appreciative of the fact that each new version of Echo does NOT obsolete the previous versions...I have the original Echo "tower"... it's on the nightstand in my bedroom ... it still sounds great and responds to my every (Alexa specific) command. Don't get me wrong, this is not AI in the purest sense...you really can't hold a conversation with Alexa...but for what she does, I am fully satisfied...and she does a lot...all day long (and into the night).

reviews.reviewTitle: Quality look and feel, but spoken word audio quality is not as good as gen 2 units
reviews.reviewText: Received as a gift. Looks really nice and much better than gen 2. However the sound quality for spoken word is not as good. Alexa Sounds muffled, not crisp and clear. Some suggest turning bass down and mid-range and high up. This helps, but not enough. I actually put my old gen 2 in the next room, and I went back and forth asking each unit to tell me the weather, so I could listen to a sentence or two. The new gen 3 unit is not as crisp or clear as the older unit, and is actually difficult to understand at low volumes. The older Gen 2 units sounds great! I think music may sound a bit better on version 3, especially bass, but spoken word sounds muffled. I'm really disappointed since I use it to listen to Audible books and podcasts. I actually thought mine was defective, and I ordered a second unit, but they both sound the same. Very disappointing. I do think the gen 3 unit hears me better and responds more consistently. But to me the poor sound quality of spoken word is enough to cause me not to use it.

Get 2! The stereo pairing is impressive. I don't have the sub (yet) - but can say the sound quality is really quite good and an immeasurable improvement over the prior Dot's. If you have your existing dots plugged into external speakers this may not be that big a deal - but if you're using the original Dot standalone - DO NOT HESITATE... No this is not audiophile quality, but seriously impressive for the size. I would say the sound is equivalent to what the Tap is able to do.

I haven't studied what all the Echo Dot can do and how to program it. I use it to listen to my favorite radio station, either directly or through one of 5 bluetooth speakers I have in different parts of the house. After a couple of weeks I find that it is more work to adjust manually than what it saves with voice commands. First, bluetooth speakers always come on at full volume (which is very loud and annoying) so I have to go to the speaker and turn down volumes manually. Second, every time I want to switch bluetooth speakers I need to turn the app on at my phone and go in & out of 5 windows to select a different speaker. And that's after going to the speaker I want and manually turning it on (I could have old fashioned radios placed around the house and turned them on manually in less time). Third, the Echo Dot does not have a battery so it must be placed against a wall and outlet, rather than in the middle of a room where it would be better able to hear my voice. Fourth, it doesn't always understand what I'm saying even though I speak quite clearly. I played a trivia game a few times and it didn't recognize the correct answers quite a few times.

I understand that Echo will turn electrical devices (such as lights) on or off with a voice command, but that requires purchase of special outlets for each device and I only have one lamp that I regularly turn off & on when I leave or go to bed, and I walk right by that lamp all the time.

The speaker has quite good sound quality, so I'm happy with that when I want to play anything directly from the Echo.

reviews.reviewTitle: Lack of support w/ Echo team. & Pore English
reviews.reviewText:
Technical support is basically nonexistent, I’ve called more than a dozen times every single time they put me on hold and or the call dropped for no reason, I have called and tried to find out if there are records that I’ve called and yes, no answer why the long waits . I tried complaining to supervisor, again I never get through. My questions are easy and simple. I needed to hear previous sound tracks using the Amazon streaming service using the command, and never went through. I called more than six times regarding the same issue. Not a single individual figured out how to fix this?. Again there’s been other simple commands that I can’t issues with the device I witch is not executing. Technical support is basically nonexistent, I’ve called more than a dozen times every time I tried calling I’ve ask for a supervisor, again I never get through. My question is still the same, I needed to hear Previous Music using Amazon streaming .. and my commands were not going through. Still the lack of support that you get from the echo department is disgusting. I finally had to call the sales and returns Development to file a complaint.
If anyone is having the same call center issues I encourage you to write about it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Echo Dot is just the coolest product!
reviews.reviewText:
This device is so handy! Some months ago I originally bought a 2nd generation Echo Dot from Amazon (it worked great), but it is has mysteriously gone missing in the meantime, probably got pushed under a sofa accidentally somewhere here in the house. So I bought this 3rd generation Dot a couple of weeks ago. The initial setup was a little clumsy--probably my own fault--but once I completed the setup (calling the device "David's 2nd Echo Dot" in the setup procedure carried out using my cellphone's installed Alexa app), it has performed beautifully. The sound out of this little guy is superb; the Alexa app includes an equalizer that actually works quite well. Every day I get music (from Amazon and Pandora), news, reminders, to-do lists, etc., via a simple shout-out to "Alexa". There are loads of other Alexa "skills" and "routines" I still have to check out.

I just received my second 3rd generation Echo Dot today, and its setup went quickly (< 1 minute) and flawlessly without even invoking the cellphone's Alexa app. It registered itself automatically as "David's 3rd Echo Dot". Both 3rd generation Echo Dots can run simultaneously, e.g., with two different music sources. I changed the "Wake Word" on one of the Dots to "Amazon" (the other is the default "Alexa") so that the two devices (and I) don't get confused.

I would recommend the Echo Dot without hesitation, and this seller, too. BTW, I have a third Echo Dot on order from Amazon right now, so each of the three (and the original 2nd generation Echo Dot, too, if it ever resurfaces) will soon be set up in separate parts of the house (my wi-fi router blasts out a good-quality signal around the whole place).

So I am now an Echo Dot junkie. I have no need to get the fancier Echo devices with their visual displays, as all that I ever need in this regard I can get via the cellphone-based Alexa app.

If you’ve ever owned an echo before and weren’t impressed maybe it’s time to look at the third generation as I did. As a speaker it shines as one of the best mini voice assistance out there, don’t expect the type of sound you would get out of the bigger models but it’s a very good small speaker. Amazons own long list of skills make it almost impossible to purchase something for the smart home that this little device can’t handle. As for smart home the Echo Dot is the beginning and yes the little one can do everything the big ones can. Now for what it doesn’t do well it’s search engine for random questions isn’t google but that’s it, The basics are handled well with the echo it’s the advanced search where you may have a problem. Overall I’ve purchased two and looking to purchase an additional two. Be prepared to enter the world of smart home with this device, bulbs, switches and the accessories to automate your home these items aren’t as expensive as you may think, there will always be something you can buy and not break the bank.
If you have a big home with multiple rooms you will need more than two, I could stay with experience maybe more. It has an intercom feature that’s super convenient, it allows us to drop in on another room instead of having to scream through the house for your kids to come to eat. My family has adapted to it extremely fast and everyone in the family seems to enjoy using it, it’s already became a part of our life. The only person who will be turning out the light in your house will soon be Alexa . Four stars not five because of search engine.

This new unit has tried to push a bassier sound more than anything. Alexa used to be crisp and clean - very easy to understand. Now she sounds like she's talking into a carpet and it's extremely hard to hear her. I've tried changing the EQ settings (which are great) but apparently they don't work on Alexa's voice. The response time is also noticeably slower than the second generation.

If you already have an Echo Dot (2nd Gen), don't waste your time. If you're looking for better music quality, I would suggest one of the MANY third-party ad-on speakers instead of this 'upgrade'.

reviews.reviewTitle: Awesome Product gets even AWESOMER <---- New word but it fits!
reviews.reviewText:
Just received my another 3rd Gen Echo Dot today (I have 2 now) along with my 2nd Gen Echo Dots we now have 8. Honestly our house is too small for that many but I really enjoy having the music everywhere fill the house. I'm very pleased with the richness of the sound with the 3rd Gen Echo Dots. I have one Dot linked to my Yamaha stereo with 4 Bose speakers but now that I have the 3rd Gen Echo Dot I use the stereo a lot less often.

The heather gray 3rd Gen was purchased for a client of mine who has memory issues from a car accident. Until I met him I thought my echo's were useful to help me remember typical stuff. Upon gaining an understanding of his situation I realized how important this could be for him. We've setup daily reminders, one of which is to remind him to set other reminders and it has helped him to remember crucial things, like to eat (he sometimes forgets for hours that his food is in the microwave). While I realize that there could be issues relying on a device it is very helpful for him.

I think the biggest problem with the whole "Alexa" enabled category of products is that a lot of people don't realize all it can do and the great potential for special or particular needs. I hear a lot of people say "oh, isn't that the thing that plays music?". It's a Great Product in a line of Great Products (I have various other Alexa enabled products).

So, i highly recommend you give it a try!

reviews.reviewTitle: It failed & the taller Echo (older) is a pain
reviews.reviewText: On Father's day 2018 I received an Echo as a gift, seemed great. Couple of months later I added a couple plugs for lamps. Then nearing Thanksgiving I added more plugs and a single pole light switch. So naturally I added a DOT on the opposite end of the house. I was ALL IN, right? No, not any longer! Just before I setup the Dot my Echo began have issues not finding devices, not understanding all this means it is losing connection. I had the Dot right so that got me through the next couple of months while I try multiple resets, even a hard reset, moved it closer, yada yada yada. Finally tech support agrees to send me a new power supply. Just received yesterday 1/22/2019 and guess what? Now the Dot is dead as a door nail. No lights, no button response, no command response, nothing just DEAD. Well I'm really getting sick of this. AND who sells electronics but won't show you there telephone number? Huh what is up with that crap. You have to forage around till you stumble on the this help page where you can press a button and plug in YOUR phone number and then you talk but Amazon number is a SECRET. JEFF, that is one thing you are NOT doing right. The Dot is going back to Amazon as a piece of garbage which it is. If the ehco does not straighten up it is going in the garbage and I'll upgrade to the Google Home. Kinda like the sound of Home, ya Google Home. Then I'll email Jeff and tell him what he needs to fix.

I don't know how I lived without Alexa all those years! I am 72 years old and purchased 3 echo dots. 2 if them are at home with me. The other one I put in my husbands room at the nursing home. He frequently looses or forgets to charge his cell phone. I can drop in and have a conversation with him any time from home or through the app on my smart phone. He has finally realized he can drop in on me too if he wants to or needs help. It has been such a help.
At home I am able to control my alarm system and my thermostat and I plan to get some smart plugs and expand her uses around the house.
When I want to relax I play some soothing spa music and drift off easily.
I am finding more and more uses for her the longer I have her. Personally it is like having an assistant.
Oh and I had company the other day and we were trying to remember a song from childhood. I asked Alexa and she pulled it up and played it almost instantly! We were both amazed!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Sound, Learns your voice, Fun to Have
reviews.reviewText:
I normally would not have purchased this, but it was offered for an absurdly low amount of money for getting one of Amazon's Credit cards. I waited until Christmas Day *2018) to open and plug it in, and since have purchased two more! The sound quality, for me, is fabulous. Once I got it working through the ALEXA APP on my Android phone, went through the short set-up, and started asking it questions (this is the way it learns your voice, BTW), I am EXTREMELY pleased with this device. It is in my kitchen, and I use it every time I'm in there, cooking, washing dishes, putting groceries away, looking up recipes.

Sure, you have to add some SKILLS to it, such as games, sounds for alarms/ timers, and other SKILLS / APPS, yet what it can provide in an instant once that is done, is well worth it. Recipes that call for items in metric? Ask ALEXA for the conversion. If you're waiting for something to cook and have to watch it, play "TWENTY QUESTIONS" or "TRUE OR FALSE."

The only slightly amusing issue? If you have more than one ALEXA operating device in the same area -- they both "hear" you say the "on word" ALEXA and talk at the same time. oops. I *think* there might be a way to change the "on word" (my term for it), so that your devices will know which one you mean. If I'm using my FIRE for recipes, both of the machines activate with the ALEXA word.

Highly Recommend, and may buy for friends, if they don't have one.

Is 'Alexa Guard' really coming? I would like to hear any and all reply comments.

I have two 3rd Gen Echo Dots and a Ring Alarm system ... but Amazon will not provide a 'specific date' when it will be made available to paying longterm customers like me. All they for the last 4 months is 'coming soon'

Here's what ADT is officially saying. IMHO ... I think Amazon has 'Guard Issues'

In September, ADT announced it had expanded its relationship with Amazon by supporting the integration of the Alexa Guard feature with the ADT Pulse security system. The intent is Alexa Guard will turn the Echo and Dot voice assistants into audio sensors that can be integrated with the Pulse system. ADT’s professional installation and monitoring solutions are expected to be offered to customers through the Alexa Guard website and Amazon mobile app.

“We’re working with Amazon to refine the go-to-market strategy. They have been strong partners to us, but the full launch will be made when Amazon and ADT are ready, and we don’t yet have a date for that,” DeVries said. “We have a very high bar. As you would expect, this is life safety for us. And when our standards are met and fully tested, as well as Amazon’s, they also have a high bar, we’ll be ready to launch, but we’re not quite there yet

reviews.reviewTitle: Echo...turn on the review of 3rd generation dot
reviews.reviewText: Well i wanted to like it because i figured the new 3rd generation would be better than the previous 2nd generation as far as features and appearance... I basically hide mine and and ask it stupid questions about weather ,the time, whats 5 x5 when paying bills online or play some music . i will get to that ! ........the real reason i purchased this was to control smart plugs around the house..i think it the best thing since sliced bread... turn on the Christmas tree ...done its good to wake up smelling hot coffee ..you get it... anyway thats that ..now the musical part of this review is after playing music since i owned this 3rd gen i noticed that the speaker has started getting crackly and the bass has made the device sound like a really loud stereo in a honda civic thats rattling from all the bass shaking it apart..anyway on the alexa app you do have many features to control everything from light to sounds and no matter how i change the bass , treble,or midrange it has started sounding like the civic...im debating weather tk send it back and keep the 2nd generation insted of this one . The dot to me dosent have to have all this upgrading and appearance enhanced look for what its capable of based on the size and it functionality if you demand higher audio quality and want to keep it on the coffee table like a vase of flowers than go with the larger models amazon offers. But for the basics of its intent the 2nd generation is fine

reviews.reviewTitle: A very nice upgrade but would have liked to see more than the 3.5 out for older sound systems
reviews.reviewText:
Sound quality is not bad, better than the earlier generations of the echo dot but still not as good as say, a 1st generation Echo. I like to keep the volume at 5 on the 3rd gen echo dot, any louder and the sound limitations become more noticeable like the earlier gen dots, but the sound at 5 is perfectly adequate for a smaller room such as a bathroom where you do not want to place a large speaker for a multi-room music setup. For the price of $24 though (black friday), the 3rd gen dot is a steal.

I would give this 5 stars, but I am deducting a star due to the lack of optical out or even coax.

Getting a dot to work with various sound systems that don't have bluetooth has been a chore to say the least, a digital optical out would be nice on future generations for older sound systems that don't have bluetooth or even a special edition dot that has digital out with coax/optical/hdmi.

For those with a Logitech Z5500, don't bother with an analog to digital converter. There will be a delay with multi-room music and from what I read, converting may decrease the sound quality. Best option I can see is to use a 3.5 stereo male to 3 aux female and use the included analog cable for the Z5500 to get the dot to play on the Logitech on all speakers. I couldn't find any info anywhere about this so troubleshooted it myself and sharing it here to save others the 2 hours I spent googling and searching various amazon products for a solution.

Also, for stereo connections on other systems, such as an older Bose Solo, make sure you get a 3.5 to 2 cable stereo and not a 1 cord coax cord. The mono cords or 3.5 to coax will not work (I believe because the echo dot outputs to analog and coax is digital).

After Amazon deleted my original post for supposedly cursing- I've cleaned it up a bit- no bad words in the original just didn't like what I said!
