Just received today and out the box. I downloaded the Alexa app, connected Alexa to the power and now I have been waiting for an hour and half for the verification code.... I restarted my phone and have requested the code to be sent 5 different times and I have not received a single one... Its annoying! I figure it would take the most 15 mins to set up but this waiting is ridiculous! One of the most advance company in the world cannot send me an instant code to set up one of their most used devices! Come on Amazon get it together... I'm about to return this if I don't the code in the next 15 mins and that's being generous with the time!

Dec. 18. 2018 - though I have a working device the phone verification has no purpose- unless it is so I can call and text people on my phone- if this is the case- It has been 12 days and I have yet to receive a verification code on my phone so I can set this feature. NO CODE at all after 12 days and I have tried it numerous times- what is the purpose of the phone verification? it does not work for me!

I'm giving it 1 star because it has wasted a lot of my time and it has been annoying. I'm not sure if I have a defective device. I'm not sure. I'll be more than happy to return if they pay for the return and get me a new one. I'm just annoyed that no idea why there's a phone number verification if it has no purpose.

This device has a long way to go. I like the drop in feature, and the smart home features, but the main reason why I bought it was to control my Arlo cameras (Mainly just turning on or off.) The only way to view a camera is to have some sort of Amazon fire tv or echo show device. It doesn’t even allow you to view the cameras on your phone using the Alexa App. Regardless if you have fire tv or similar device, It doesn’t turn cameras on/off or arms/disarms camera. If you have a LG TV, you can control the TV except turning it on. Not sure if that’s a Alexa or LG issue, but other brand TVs work. I can live without the TV issue, but Amazon needs to fix the Arlo issue!

reviews.reviewTitle: Stopped working after 2 weeks - would not connect to internet any more
reviews.reviewText:
I believe either the Echo Dot we received is defective or the Amazon software to set it up is buggy. We set up the Echo Dot on Dec 25, 2018 using a laptop and going to alexa.amazon.com web page. Echo Dot worked for about 2 weeks. Then it announced it could not connect to our ATT wifi (router model 5268AC) even though our internet did not change. I made several attempts to reconnect (I tried 2 different Amazon accounts) but without success. I contacted Amazon Help Desk and I worked with someone over the phone for 38 minutes without success. Per her instructions, I did try using a different PC to set up the Echo Dot without success. I asked if it was defective and if I should send it back. She said it was not defective. But it that were true, she should have been able to help me connect it to the internet. It’s not like I am stupid. I connected our Echo Dot to the internet on Dec 25, 2018. Also, in some of my attempts to connect it, when I clicked the CONTINUE button on the setup web page, I received the message “Hmmm...can’t reach this page” – making me believe there is a bug in the code of the setup page.

I am happy that many people are happily using their Echo Dot. But it failed for us because of what I believe are either bugs or defects.

reviews.reviewTitle: Have issues? Just send it back!
reviews.reviewText: I tried to to do the right thing. Our entire home is connected to the Amazon ecosystem and dependent on the Dot as our main hub. The 3rd gen was failing to respond so I called tech support and after an hour on the phone nothing had changed. They wanted to start a repair ticket and it will take up to three days for a response. So now my automated home is on it's knees since I'm unable to use Alexa to control functions. Now, if tech support determines it's to be replaced, I'll have to wait even longer for a replacement for a device still under warranty! Next time I will just start a return and have a new one in two days. Not impressed Amazon, you need to rethink how you handle your adapters of your tech when they have invested time and money into your system.

I purchased the device because the product description advertised as blue tooth speaker. Well it does not work as a blue tooth speaker with my TV set, which it stated that it did. Works with one TV as expected but not my other set. Both are Samsung Smart Tvs. Very disappointing. Returned it. Beware that it does not work as described with all devices. Look before you leap. Was very impressed with the sound quality . Very nice. No battery must have a power soucre another negative. Customer support is lacking for this device. They run you around in circles and a little reluctant to admit the unit might be defective and reluctant to refund. But they will. Most features work well.

Well I purchased a different bluetooth speaker for half the price and it works great. First try and all paired and connected perfectly. The sound is great to. I would consider an echo Dot again for all the other features if they can get this problem squared away. It a shame that it can't be used a a regular bluebooth speaker. I hope some of their engineers are listening. I invited Amazon engineers to contact me to help resolve this issue.

reviews.reviewTitle: A review of the device not Alexa. Microphone sucks... that aside
reviews.reviewText:
I'd review Alexa but I feel she is adequate this is purely my feelings about the current gen Echo Dot.

I've had this(5 months) and the 2nd generation (1yr and 5months) for sometime now and I can honestly say I'm not overly impressed with the third generation. I had the 2nd gen in my bathroom and the 3rd in my kitchen. Walking through the front door the 2nd gen two rooms away was more likely to pick up my voice than the 3rd gen that was much closer and on top of a counter so it could be unreconstructed. The speaker is about the only thing I really have liked about this Dot as the 2nd gen was definitely really weak. I almost wonder if the mic on my 3rd gen in particular is just damaged. Even freshly unpacked the microphone was weak. It is so poor and the 2nd gen mic so good I had to move the 2nd gen to a back room where wifi is weaker but I can close a door so it won't pick up my voice.

As a home assistant it is more important to have a functioning microphone than a speaker. Speakers can be bought and/or added on. Microphones can't.

I have Google Mini's throughout my house, but purchased the new Echo Dot (3rd gen) to compare with the Mini. The Echo Dot (3rd gen) has definitely surpassed the Google Mini as far as sound goes. The sound from the Dot is louder, fuller and as many reviews have already stated has a much better base. You're still not going to rock the house with this little speaker, but it does sound better for some good background music. You definitely can tell the difference with the orientation of the speakers. While the Mini's speaker faces up, the Dot's speakers face out and as a result tend to fill the space with sound a bit better.

The look is also much improved and I would say on par with the Google Mini now. I do like the light ring on the Dot better than the Mini's lights on the top which can be hard to see at times.

I thought the Dot's 3.5mm audio jack would end up being a big advantage, but I've learned that I actually prefer Google's approach where I use their Chromecast audio to connect my quality, standalone speakers to my Mini. The reason I like this approach better is that I can locate my good speakers up on a shelf where I wouldn't necessarily want my voice assistant. I want to put my voice assistant a little closer to where I work so I don't have to holler across the room where my good speakers are. But of course, you have to pay $35 extra for that Chromecast Audio. So that 3.5mm jack feature on the Dot will really depend on your situation.

In the end though...I returned the Echo Dot for one reason. The voice commands are just more natural and seem to work better on the Google Mini. And that's what you end up doing with these speakers...you talk to them, and the more natural that speech is the more the voice assistant just merges into your lifestyle and day-to-day usage. If Alexa was on par with Google Assistant so far as natural speech goes, I'd have to say this Echo Dot (3rd gen) takes the cake, but Google Assistant makes enough of a difference to keep gabbing at my Mini's.

Let me preface this with I have three Gen 2 dots and they work perfectly and have for the past year or so. We ordered two Gen 3s as a Christmas deal and have had nothing but issues with one or both everyday since installing them (they have been installed for one month). Every day one or both will be disconnected from the internet in the morning and usually at least one other time during the day, this means you have to unplug and replug just to get it to reconnect to the internet and have any functionality. We have tried resetting our router like the hints say but nothing seems to help. Normally I would just think it was my equipment since two new devices normally do not fail at the same time, but I have three other Gen 2 dots that work perfectly so it makes me suspect the new dots. Guess they make a fancy $30 paperweight! I know there a a lot of people here that have had nothing but good luck with the Gen 3s, but for me, I'll be returning these and looking at new Gen 2s or the Google product.

Update:
Spoke to the Amazon Echo customer service and they sent me two Echo Gen 3 replacement units. They were very helpful and got the units sent out right away. Unfortunately we set them up last night we are having the exact same issues. They went offline within the first couple hours and then again overnight. We are done.

reviews.reviewTitle: 3rd Gen is TRASH - Don't buy this!
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased three of these during Prime Days. First, it took FOREVER for me to receive them, and I still have not received one of the three ordered.

Secondly, the only music platform that seems to work correctly is Amazon music. On any other platform, the song gets about a quarter of the way to halfway finished and it cuts out to dead air. When the music resumes, a new song is playing. I listen to pandora primarily, then apple music and Amazon as my last option. I purchased them to add easily accessible music in my office, gym, and yoga room. I contacted amazon and did troubleshooting with no resolution. They sent me two replacements that are doing the same thing. The funny thing is if I listen to my second-generation dots and plus I have no issues with any of my music platforms. It is only the third-generation with the problem; which tells me there is something wrong with this third-generation. I hope they will take this back and return my money. I would rather have a refurbished second-generation than not to be able to listen to all of my music platforms.

Thirdly, the echo says it is up to date, BUT the tech support representative stated that the software version is not the latest.

Lastly, I have to repeat myself multiple times for this echo to wake up and do what is asked. In my opinion, Amazon had to throw a bunch together to keep up with demand from Prime Days and manufactured a bunch of defective echo dots.

I hardly ever do reviews, but I am so annoyed with this situation that I had to let others know what to expect. This third-generation is not the high-quality Amazon product you have become accustomed. Do yourself a favor and wait until a new generation becomes available or buy an old one.

reviews.reviewTitle: I know Echo Dot does all kinds of things, but I mostly use it for rain sounds
reviews.reviewText: Echo dot with Alexa does all kinds of cool things. I know. I get the emails every week telling me all the new things up with Alexa! I may get around to trying those things out one day...but mostly I use the Echo dot to play rain sounds while I sleep. It does that awesomely! I have seen my husband use the Echo dot to control our firestick. That was pretty cool. Alexa has answered my little ones questions with some quippy remarks a few times; that was fun. The dot has been pretty helpful in telling me the weather outside before I step out in the cold in my underwear--that's been a lifesaver. I think my next purchase is going to be the Echo dot thing that comes with a screen and reads you recipes. I probably won't know how to use that to its fullest capabilities either, but Amazon is still going to get my money because someone in my household will know what they're doing. 10 out of 10 would buy this again...actually, I did...I just bought the kid version...so, yeah, Amazon strikes again. I'm told its worth it. Get you one!

So my box fan randomly burst into flames one night. Imagine a fat girl running through the house with a flaming hot fan, it panties and a night shirt, chucking a pillar of fire into the snow. I tossed at as far as the Cleveland Browns can throw a foot ball, then I had to pick it up and throw it again so it did not catch the house on fire. Anyways without the noise from the fan to lull me to sleep, I grabbed my Echo and brought it up to my room to play ambient noise for the night.

I never slept so good listening to this thing called brown noise, but then my kitchen felt naked because I had no tunes to clean to. I decided we needed more than one Alexa, we needed an upstairs device and a downstairs device. Enter the echo dot. Yes this little baby solved all my problems. She plays the ambient noise at night, plus I linked her to the downstairs Alexa and can drop in to eavesdrop when hubby is talking on the phone. Unfortunately, neither one of us lead exciting lives and he pretty much just talks to his mom.
Oh, the best thing about the dot, well let me tell you. I have two cats who are jerks. I can tell Alexa to open a box of cats and it will meow away. The look of confusion on their furry little faces is priceless!!

Have 2 Echo Inputs connected to stereo systems, 3 Gen 2 Dots, and just purchased a Gen 3 Dot. I have all set up as a group, "Everywhere." We like to play music throughout the house and with everything connected, it has been great moving throughout the house and being able to hear the same thing. The system runs for 8 hours or more per day. Bought the Gen 3 DOT and it worked quite well, for a couple weeks. At first, it would not start playing a song when all the others were playing, but would cut in a few seconds after the song started. Then, it started just shutting off while the others still played. Finally, after two or three songs, it would say it was having trouble playing the music and would shut down everything. Contacted support, and received a replacement today. Changed out the defective Gen 3 with the new one and all worked well, for a while. However, the replacement now has started to just shut down after a couple hours. Both of the new Gen 3 Dots seem to feel warmer to the touch than the older Gen 2s, so don't know if they are overheating after a couple hours or if there is another problem with them. Thinking seriously about just requesting a refund on the Gen 3 and getting another Gen 2. I do like the sound better on the newer Gen 3, but if it keeps shutting down, .............. Will probably use it for a couple more days and see if the problem recurs or if maybe it was just an anomaly.

I'm not a techie by ANY means. I'm also disabled and only have use of one hand. Setting up the Echo Dot was super simple until it came to getting the app and registering my unit. The app would NOT allow me to log into Amazon. I contacted Amazon and chatted with a CS rep who helped me to do it on their site. Took a while but after it found and connected to my WiFi I was able to unplug the Dot and move it into another room and she's been chatting away with me ever since. I have to be careful because I was on the telephone telling my aunt about A L E X A and she started talking to me. I found I have to spell it if I want to discuss her. (Humor here!!) Also if I use talk to chat on my cell. She wants to know what I want.... I'm having a ball! I listened to music this morning. I've gotten the weather, time and back to music. So far I'm ecstatic. Let's see if I need to do an update or if this review stands in a week or two! At this point I would highly recommend her. The sound from the speaker is fantastic for such a small thing. I receive the Dot included when I purchased my Ring2 doorbell. Amazon has it as a package and I got the better end of the deal!!! Go for it if you are in doubt!

reviews.reviewTitle: Not Impressed. Very Horse and Buggie.
reviews.reviewText:
I am a new first time user. Before making my decision to buy I read several reviews and watched several YouTube videos to educate myself. After receiving it and using it, I think it is over rated. There was nothing easy about the set up of the Alexa app or the Echo Dot. The app took over 30 minutes to download and update. When i plugged the Echo Dot in, Alexa said go the the app and follow the directions. What directions? The app opened and all I saw was the outside temperature and the time. I expected to see a start up screen. I had to find the start up in the menu. The Alexa would not discover and connect to my Wifi even though my phone was connected. The app would just sit and spin and say no internet connection. I was sitting 3 feet away from my modem/router. After trying over and over again I finally had to set it up manually. The same thing with my new Vizio Smart TV. I had to call Vizio technical support and get help with that. The only thing this does with my tv is to turn it on and off. It always comes up with the Amazon Prime and I could care less about that. Now if I want full tv function I have to buy a Firestick. The Alexa app does not recognize Netflix, or YouTube, and many other social media outlets. Very limited.
I have a new HP laptop with blue tooth and Alexa or my laptop will not discover each other. Trying to get the Alexa app on my laptop is just an endless circle with the app asking for my phone number to send it to my phone.

I don't think the sound quality is all that great so I added a Vivitar Bluetooth speaker. Alexa did discover that and the sound quality is much better. I tried to plug in a set of Logitech speakers, that worked but Alexa then disconnected from the Bluetooth speaker. Very limited in it's capabilities. I live in a 900 sq ft apartment. If I want to use Alexa I have to move the speaker from room to room or buy more speakers.
Alexa is very Victorian and prudish in her limited answers and almost boring. She has no sense of humor and her jokes are rather juvenile and corny. The developers must be very boring people and limited in creativity. This is nothing but a glorified toy. Alexa grow up. I am an adult and live in the real world. If you don't want to hear swear words or talk about sexuality then put on more filters. Get real. If we can't have open honest conversation with real answers about anything then what is the point?
Most of the things this does I can do on my phone and more. Setting timers, making lists, searching for trivia, printing documents, searching websites...
The is a money pit. If I wanted to turn my apartment into a smart home then I would need a smart hub, smart switches, smart receptacles, smart light bulbs, more speakers, more Echo Dots, etc. This all seams very expensive, limited, archaic and horse and buggy. But is has to start someplace.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect inexpensive entry into a 'smart house' monitor!
reviews.reviewText:
My first Alexa product... wow. I am soooo impressed!
Along with most other people, I am also concerned about eavesdropping. So I have installed it into a spare bedroom that we rarely have conversation in. I'm not sure we ever say anything that would bother me terribly to have someone overhear, but that thought still bothers me enough to keep it out of common areas til I'm more comfortable with it.

What I marveled at was how you can ask Alexa to make calls from my contact list. I know some people are worried about sharing that info with Alexa, but take a look at how many apps already have access to your contact list, none of which (other than phone and text) enhance your experience. Alexa makes calls for you while lying in bed!!! This feature made me so happy, I bought one for my mom immediately. She has a rescue alert downstairs, but insists on sleeping upstairs, where rescue alert may not hear her. Now, she can tell Alexa to call me from bed if she needs me!! The peace of mind is priceless.

I haven't explored all of Alexa's features, but the ones I like best are the ability to control lights (Alexa lights on, lights off), and the thermostat, while laying in bed. From the guest room, I can turn the ac up simply by telling Alexa to do it, and my husband is none the wiser. HAAAA!!! The ability to make calls or emergency calls while in bed is wonderful! I can have my cell charging on the table, and make calls from Alexa! The sleep assistance skills which include meditation, sounds (forest, waterfall, rain, thunderstorm - all free). Music on demand... Amazon already has my extensive playlist, so I can have it play a pretty large variety already, plus the Prime Music (and if you have Amazon Music, there's literally no limit to what it can play on demand). Let me expand on the meditation.... this actually does a guided meditation that changes daily to help you calm and relax. It's remarkable, and the perfect ending to a hectic day! I LOVE this!

Because it's in a spare bedroom, I haven't spent a lot of time talking to it for it to get fully used to my voice. I have noticed that when I'm slurring my speech from sleepiness, it doesn't always recognize me, and sometimes when it does, I'm surprised because I know I'm groggy and slurring. I imagine that if I had a cold or flu, the problem would get worse, but perhaps that will improve over time as the recognition grows.

I am definitely glad I got this, and looking forward to exploring all the new features! At this price, I would recommend it to anyone to try (along with a light switch or plug, so you can get instant light turn on off gratification). What a great intro to a smart house!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Really awesome sound quality, creeps the crap outta the cats and the husband though
reviews.reviewText:
Pros: Fantastic sound quality. It's barely 2 inches tall, yet fills out the room. It gets loouud for my apartment. It is hard to find a preset with good mids these days, but I can hear all the parts nice and clear. The bass isn't that big, but the unit is frikking teeny. Buy a subwoofer you purist. It's also really good at telling me the time and temperature without being bitchy about it. I call it computer.

Cons: It weirds out the cats. They arent used to some oddly cheerful voice coming from the corner. We've only had it a week though, time shall tell. The husband has a grumbly voice and doesnt always enunciate so he triggers it at random, and these days, when grumbles set off the wire tap, unease is understandable. I am still uneasy with an "always on" microphone but we shall see if Amazon keeps their covenant to only look a little bit, I might not freak out and burn it.

I love my little dot! We're still "learning" each other but so far, the AskMyBuddy App made this purchase worth it all! The monthly payment plan made it possibly - I could not have paid full price up front, so for that, I thank Amazon immensely. I did purchase a wall mount that I am very pleased with - it's truly portable to be used in any room. Planning on purchasing a second one after this one is paid off. One for the kitchen, one for the bedroom. I live in a 915sq ft apt, so having one at both ends makes more sense.

PROS: Great features. I use the time, temperature/weather/ daily flash news, Amazon music and reminders more than anything else so far. I bought a smart plug for the bedroom light and that works brilliantly. I've played with skills, but she is way smarter than I am. That's a hit to the ego frankly, so I've left it alone after being owned so many times. LOL

I love being able to create my own skills. I've had fun with that! (I had an 8-second .mp4 video of a new skill, but when I tried to upload the vid to this review, it said it could not process the .mp4 file)

Having compatible security products adds another layer of awesome for this little dot. So many different uses for so many different items makes this Dot a great addition to the home.

CONS:
1. Smart Plugs are overpriced. I did buy one on a flash sale for $6 - but otherwise, they are $25. WAY too much.
2. I have a Galaxy S4 phone and the app is not compatible. Having to use my Galaxy Tab A tablet for the App - but since that is reliant only on Wi-fi, I am limited to those parameters to update the app or create a new skill.
3. Set up was a bear! I use my desktop PC for EVERYTHING. The PC doesn't have wi-fi. Having an old phone didn't help either, and setup was impossible over the tablet because it has no carrier. Had I not had a laptop that I could hard-wire to the router AND that had wi-fi, I could not have set this up. So beware of that. If you have out of date tech stuff - and can't afford to update it, it may prove to be difficult. Borrow a friends laptop that can be hard-wired to the router AND use wifi - you have to go in hardwired then during setup, turn on wifi at the same time. Once it is set up though - it's a well-greased machine!
4. With it being mounted in the wall mount, the sound range is increased, IMO, but it's bass-y. I've told it to turn the bass down; it's all the way down now and still sounds too deep. Perhaps for Alexa, it's all about that bass! LOL - not a deal breaker, just an observation. To be fair, for a little thing, it packs great sound otherwise.
------
Overall, this is a fun tool that is also a life saver when you get the AskMyBuddy app. I paid the extra $3.99 a month to add more contacts, but I'm a senior who lives alone and this app alone, makes it worthwhile for anyone wanting to get their parents that have wi-fi, something fun and useful for any occasion.

I highly recommend a wall mount. I bought the one from "ProudBird" on amazon for $9.99 and it keeps the wires neat and out of the way. Just remember though, when you unplug it from the wall, the plug stays and the mount goes - be careful when pulling out of the wall to be mindful of that. Nice pairing of two great products though.

First of all, I have to say that I’m new to this smart friend. I ordered this because it was on sale on prime day and I want to know what Alexa can do. After I received the dot, I have read the instructions how to set up. But as I said I had know idea what was the dot. The instructions told me to download the app, but did not tell me what the name of the app. I downloaded 2 apps, still not the one because it turned I had to pay to set up. So I searched from YouTube how to setup from what app. I finally found out it was “amazon Alexa” app. I downloaded the app and the setup was easy. Now what Alexa can do? I set up voice recognition, easy too. I asked Alexa to play music, tell me the temperature, time when I have mask on, read me notifications, and now she is my friend. Every time I say hi to her, she says it back. This is the best thing for me. I will try to learn more what else she can do. But for now she is my best friend. One thing that annoys me is every time I have to call her name in order to get response.

reviews.reviewTitle: I wanted to order pizza. Alexa read me the news instead.
reviews.reviewText:
1/9/2018 Edit: This device is a solid 4 star device, maybe even 5-stars. Amazon is vague with describing what the echo can do because it can do a bunch of stuff. I wrote the harsh review below in anger when it couldn't do the one thing I wanted it to do properly, but then after complaining, Amazon reached out to me to offer help in properly setting up my Echo dot and issuing commands. I still feel that the device is not *quite* as intuitive as they make it out to be. You can also change the activation word from "Alexa" to "Computer", which makes me feel like I'm in Star Trek.
In the end, it's a nice addition to a kitchen, as it can function as an extra cooking timer than can also perform any conversion (1/4 cup = 4 tablespoons), play your second-favorite song when your #1 favorite isn't included with your Amazon Music subscription (computer, play the theme song to 'Quantum Leap'), while also telling you what the wind speed is, and casually look up when Friedrich Nietzsche died for you (August 25, 1900) so you don't have to wonder about it while cooking biscuits. I think the Echo dot can also give you recipe & meal ideas to cook, but I already have a recipe for biscuits and for other meals I simply asked it to schedule a delivery of Soylent instead.

Below is my original review for context. As I have said, the Echo Dot is a 4/5 star device, would buy again, but it will still make you angry sometimes.
I BOUGHT THIS SOLELY TO ORDER PIZZA AND IT DOESN’T WORK PROPERLY.

1. Took 45 to set up. That’s 40 minutes too long.
2. Wanted to use Pizza Hut Skill. When I asked Alexa to “Order a pizza from Pizza Hut.” She replied, “Did you mean ‘Amazon Restaurants’?” I said, “No! Pizza Hut!!” Alexa: “Order from Domino’s” Me: “Pizza Hut!” Alexa: “I see your current address is (address of family member who lives 2,000 miles away).” At no point did Alexa even mention that she was ordering from Pizza Hut or Domino’s or w/e. Not to mention, this was another setback because I had to update my address properly, which you can only do from the stupid 2nd-rate Alexa app (3/5 rating for lackluster U/I input). There were other complications along the way but I was so mad I forgot.
3. After properly setting up my address, the Pizza Hut skill, blah blah blah. I instruct Alexa to “Order my favorite pizza.” Which is what they advertise you can do. I went to the trouble of setting up the perfect order online on my Pizza Hut account to make this work. I find out that you can’t use coupons with Alexa. So finally, Alexa reads me my order summary - which is $7 more than it should be cause I can’t use a coupon - Alexa says, “Error: you will have to input your order online.” “WHAT THE *fudge*?!? ARE YOU *fooling* SHIPPING ME?!?
Alexa: “I would prefer not to answer that question.

I added a star because you can ask Alexa to read you the headlines from The Economist.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works well, nice features, appealing aesthetic,
reviews.reviewText:
I received my Echo Dot in the mail and immediately set it up. I had previously purchased an Echo Dot for my parents and also lived with an Echo for a year. I bought this Echo Dot during a deal to see if I'd like it just as much as the Echo.

For overall functionality, I say it works quite well. It can't answer all of your questions yet, but Alexa is generally knowledgeable about most topics and has many useful features related to personalizing your experience. I especially like the app that allows you to customize questions for any guests in your home that may need help finding things. I've been able to utilize many other features such as lists, morning routine, playing podcasts, playing music, setting timers/reminders, and others. I am planning on purchasing some smart home equipment in the future, but for now I don't know how well the integration works.

As part of the deal to purchase the Echo, I also got an Amazon Music subscription. Unfortunately, the Echo Dot does not have speakers as nice as the Echo does. If you looked up the differences, this is a known discrepancy so I wasn't too upset. The quality honestly isn't bad enough for anyone who isn't purchasing it for music specifically to be bothered by.

The other minor annoyance is that the speaker doesn't seem to be 360, as the Echo is, but unidirectional. This isn't a problem for me, currently, as it is set up on a shelf directed towards where I generally am to listen to podcasts, music, and audiobooks. I'm not sure if the microphone is also unidirectional, but I haven't had any problem with Alexa picking up my voice unless I'm in another room around the corner (which is expected).

Overall, I'm happy with my purchase of the Echo Dot. If I decide to add another unit, I will be purchasing the Echo for my main living space, as I do prefer the 360 speaker and increased speaker quality. However, for a budget option or those not too finicky when it comes to speaker quality or direction, the Echo Dot is a great option for a smart home device.

Purschased the Exho for for the music playing ability. Worked flawless in the first 2 weeks then had several issues with volume and connecting to linked skills requiring me to unplug and “reset” Alexa. On 3/30/19 I changed SiriusXM accounts. New account linked in skills but would no longer play on My echo. Contacted customer service who attempted to troubleshoot and was unable. I was told it would be escalated and I would receive a call in 24-hours. No call came and I have since emailed and spoke with customer service 2x/ea. Now 2-weeks later and this has started as just a glitch on my echo that it literally worked one minute but not the next, to a system wide issue with SiriusXM and no anticipation of when it will be resolved. Only information I have received now is that it has been escalated to a Master ticket and it is being worked on.

Constantly having issues with play back, stops playing music randomly. Wont connect to other smart devices. Dont buy this, BUY GOOGLE SMART DEVICES, AMAZON WILL CHEAT YOU!!!!!!!!!

Update:
Still has trouble all the time. currently it randomly forget my network and wont connect to the wifi for ANY REASON, all other devices work fine, even older generation dot works, these new ones are a HUGE RIP OFF!!!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Get one for yourself and for your mom too.
reviews.reviewText: Unfortunately I am now looking at purchasing my 6th Echo. I have now come to the conclusion that I cannot live without them. I have to say Echo instead of the other name (Alexa) because she will hear me and asked to help me. Oops! We have them connected to our lights music everything. We play games with her when we have company. Or just as a family. They are fabulous and are probably making us a bit lazy. We have not had any problems with them. My mother has one that I gave her as a Christmas gift. Now to call me all she has to do is tell it to call me. It has made life easier for her since she is on a walker. She doesn't have to worry about seeing the numbers on a phone which she cannot see anyway. All she has to do is tell it to call her do your son. Needless to say, I am a fan and should probably get paid for such a ringing endorsement.

reviews.reviewTitle: Monthly fees?? What is that all about?
reviews.reviewText: I like this product reasonably well for what I am intending to use it for. I do not anticipate connecting my entire life to the thing at this point, but music, timer, phone calls are all on the docket. I don’t know whether or not to be concerned about the “listening ability” of this device, but then again I am happy to let anyone listening know what I think on virtually any topic, so do your worst. The only drawback on the music is that much of what I would like to hear requires joining Apple Music, or whatever they call it, for a monthly fee, and I am not going down that rabbit hole. As with most of my technology gadgets, I probably won’t live long enough to figure it all out, but so be it. For the price this puppy delivers good sound and that’s about all one can ask these days.
I like it better than the 2nd gen dot and echo. Glad I waited for it to be released. Now I need a battery base for it.

reviews.reviewTitle: A Caveat or two awaits you
reviews.reviewText:
Be advised hat the more devices you have connectivity to the internet becomes an issue. I have 4 of these. When I can stay connected to the internet the Echo Dot is pretty awesome. Problem right now is that somewhere between the number of smart plugs I have (quite a few, maybe 10) and the number of echo dots (4) I find myself offline, i.e. NOT connected to the internet. It is ANNOYING to hear the all-to-familiar to me chime, followed by a red halo of light atop Alexa; followed by the also all-to-familiar "I'm having trouble connecting to the internet. Check the help section of the Alexa app..." at which time by now I'm yelling for it to shut up before I can unplug it in order to reboot it in an effort to reconnect to the net.

Go to my i-phone to check my network and the scene i the same. That being a constantly spinning icon trying desperately and taking forever at it to establish a connection to the internet. The point here is that as I started to say from the beginning the more devices you have the more internet speed is required. THAT has been my personal experience.

I presently have a download speed of only 20Mb. If all goes well it will be at 4Mb TOMORROW which can't get hee so enough. I will update this review as soon as I can in case you or anyone else following along here and have the same issue. If you only have one Echo Dot and maybe 3Smart Plugs 20 Mb download speed should be sufficient. Finally, so far what I just explained here is not in the Help Section of the Alexa app WHICH incidentally CANNOT be accessed if you're not connected to the internet.

So if you are for example a brainy type or student focused on something and the room begins to lose its light and in an effort to stay focused say 'Alexa, turn on the light," you want the light to come on so you can continue on uninterrupted, right? Good luck with that. My patience have worn so completely thin from instead of a light coming on but instead hearing the chime; the message etc; they tear easily now. GONE.

So hopefully the faster internet speed will remedy my personal nightmare here. As for the answers to many of the questions asked in the questions section above I'm a little confused because the main issue I have is connectivity issues. As for giving Alexa different name if they are within earshot of each other: every now and then I will say; e.g. "Alexa, turn on the hallway light," and Alexa will answer from the other room the she's having trouble connecting to the internet, while the one in the room in which my request originated will turn on the light.

To me a lot of all this is pretty intuitive. If you are the type to have found, let's say earlier versions of MS Windows to be very intuitive your problems will be fewer and you will likely recognize the cause of problems within software apps for the Echo Dot. I was a lot happier with this before making my house pretty smart and life more convenient WHICH IT WILL BE ONCE I GET THIS F*ING THING TO STAY ONLINE.

Again, if you're getting your first one in addition to maybe 3 smart plugs and you have a mere 20Mb download connection you SHOULD be okay and problem free UNTIL you start adding more devices and you most likely will do eventually, little by little or otherwise. But for starters, like I just said you should be fine with just 1 Echo Dot 3 smart plugs and I will say a minimum 20Mb internet connection. Me? Hopefully 40Mb will be enough. If not, then I will have to go with the max available in my area WHICH is not a whole lot more than 50Mb best I remember Soooooo...

Good luck. It's a cool product and once you are up and running smoothly think 2001 Space Odyssey almost 20 years late. Seriously.

William F. Nappi

Easy to setup but echo takes multiple attempts to turn on the light that is connected to smart adapter (amazon brand or 3rd party brand. I tried both)
Even after echo confirms the command by responding “ok”. Light still isn’t turned on.
It takes 2-3 tries. One time it took 5 attempts to finally truly turn on the light.

The voice recognization is becoming worse each day. It doesn’t respond to Alexa or Echo. Often we had to raise the voice loudly.
It is not next to wall and it has problem hearing even during quiet night time.
However, weird thing is that once it hears me the first time, then subsequent commands can be heard and acknowledged even with very low voice volume.
Very inconsistent in responding wake command.

Echo does not know most of questions asked. For example, can you recommend a national park to visit?
Try google home. You will get better answers most of the time.

Update:
Received a call from Amazon to resolve the device issue. I requested to get a call back at a specific time but never received a call back.

The device problem is still there and not getting better. It doesn’t respond often with first call of “Alex”. Repeating it with same tone, same voice level, and same direction and it responses second or 3rd time. Just not the first.
Turning light on is still terrible that it ticks us off sometimes. Alexa says “ok” after the command and nothing turns on. After 2nd it 3rd time, then the light actually turns on.

Reset doesn’t resolve the issue.

I have an Echo Dot 2nd generation. I ordered this because of the new clock feature and better sound (and since it was on sale). I just returned it for a refund.

The sound quality was much improved -- richer and more bass. The earlier Dot sounded tinny or shrill. This latest one was much more pleasing. This isn't to criticize the earlier Dot (since it wasn't designed as a great speaker), but to compliment this latest version.

The clock feature is a great new feature. However, when the brightness is set to Auto (or maybe that's called Adaptive), I couldn't adjust the level of this setting. I spent over an hour in an online chat w/ Amazon to resolve this. We did a hardware update, both Android and iOS Alexa application updates. This setting still wouldn't change through either of the apps or by saying "Alexa, set brightness to 1; set brightness to 10"). The Dot would briefly show "1"" or "10" after sliding the brightness control in the apps or by requesting by voice, but there wasn't any difference in the brightness.

I was able to change the brightness when Auto (Adaptive?) was switched off. So, it could be set to say level "2" or whatever, but then it wouldn't adjust based on the room light.

I'd like the brightness to automatically dim in a dark room such as at night; and be brighter during sunlight. And, it seemed to do so, it's just that it was way too dim for me in all these cases. I'd like to bump it up, but couldn't despite that seeming to be a feature. Either Amazon should clarify that this can't be done or fix it.

If it wasn't for this apparent flaw, I'd give a 5 star rating.

If anyone has this feature working -- suggesting I just had a bad device -- replies would help others. As for myself, I went back to my 2nd generation Dot and will wait till this is clearly fixed or is a non-issue. My Dot works fine, so I'm in no rush.

reviews.reviewTitle: Disappointed and worried about the security issues
reviews.reviewText:
I bought these (several) because they were supposed to work with my Sonos to play Apple Music. I have invested heavily in Sonos, so I’m stuck but I’m increasingly frustrated by the app and difficulty of playing my music.

The Echo will play Apple Music on its tiny little speaker but it STILL cannot play it on the connected Sonos. It keeps telling me that service is not supported.

And, this part is the worst, when Alexa’s internet brain is offline or slowed down, the error messages make you think you have screwed up. It’s like, you have suddenly forgotten how Alexa works and haven’t said things exactly right. Internet search for “Is Alexa down” and you find out that it’s not you, it’s her. This happened right after I bought them I almost burned them in the fireplace.

BTW, I bought Apple’s HomePod when it was a hundred dollars on sale this Christmas, and at that price, it is totally worth it. It sounds great, set-up is far easier, Siri will set timers just fine, and control over my Hue lights etc is flawless. It synchronizes music with other HomePods and with the speakers you have plugged into your Apple TVs. (And Amazon has had some astounding privacy and security violations from Ring doorbell to Alexa laughing to recording hours of audio to send to unknown servers.) If you subscribe to AppleMusic the HomePod really the best choice.
