BTW, it's a real cool looking speaker.
Lesson...read everything before buying to make sure you can use it. 😂😂😂❤❤❤

reviews.reviewTitle: Ironically, everything except Alexa sounds good.
reviews.reviewText: I'm not going to comment on all the wonderful features of this device. Everything seems to work well, except the sound of Alexa's voice. I have listened to a few voices on news feeds & Jimmy Kimmel jokes & the voices sound OK. Alexa, on the other hand sounds very muffled & chesty. I have treble & mid all the way up & bass all the way down trying to get rid of the tubby/muffled sound of her voice. EQ didn't help. In my opinion, this device should get the voice right first & foremost. I don't expect to play music through it with any fidelity, so it's primary purpose is to talk to me & Amazon got this wrong in their attempt to have it all. Hopefully this can be fixed with their tweaking her voice, or giving us alternative voices that are more intelligible. Disclaimer, I am an audiophile & am used to listening to high quality equipment. My expectations for the Echo Dot's sound quality was low, but I was surprised that the Alexa voice was so bad. I am extremely grateful that they included an audio out though. It's so ironic that Alexa's voice is so poorly implemented. Please give us a new voice or a better EQ. Thanks for that & all the other features. Well worth the money.

I received 2 of these free with my recent purchases of Amazon Blink cameras. The blink cameras were actually easier to set up than the echo dot. After spending 2 hours trying to set it up and figure it out, I finally gave up. Both are now sitting in boxes. It's totally useless in my opinion. It basically is just a voice command station which my phone already does. Everyone talks of what a wonderful speaker it has but I never got it to work with music. Thats the most disappointing part of all. All I heard was "I'm sorry. I dont understand that command." Smart??? My dog is smarter! I wish I could return them and get money back for them but they were free. Glad I didn't have to pay for them.

reviews.reviewTitle: Audio sounds like it's covered by a blanket
reviews.reviewText:
These devices have EQ settings, which was good to discover, but even with the treble maxed, the bass all the way down, and the mids set for best clarity, the audio is muffled. I have $10 radios that sound better. The music is so so. The voice sounds like it's talking through a pillow.

We do enjoy these devices for some things - music at dinner, "flash briefings" in the morning, and occasional time and weather checks. It's rare to check traffic but it seems to work well.

What prompted this review was something I read somewhere that said the audio was better if you ordered premium service. I don't know what that's about - I'm already paying for Prime, I guess now Prime has it's own audio version of Prime, for more money, and I can see where Amazon is going with this.

The audio stinks. The device is nothing but a paper weight without audio, and they designed the audio to stink. And if you want improved audio, you have to pay extra? Seriously?

reviews.reviewTitle: Finally, a clock that doesn't light up my room like the sun at night.
reviews.reviewText: Finally, a clock that dims to the perfect brightness at night and brightens perfectly during the day and it comes with everything Alexa has to offer. I have bought and thrown out so many alarm clocks because none of them can seem to get the bright enough to see during the day but dim enough to actually be able to sleep next to at night setting right. But finally, with this echo all that is possible. It is small but the numbers are distinct enough that they can be viewed from a long distance away. Perfectly dims/brightens with changes in light. And with Alexa you can set alarms listen to music, control lights, thermostat settings, get the weather, news etc. all from the comfort of your own bed. Love it, just wish it came in more colors.

reviews.reviewTitle: A great innovation by Amazon but there's a long way to go to....
reviews.reviewText: Well, I am happy that I kept myself up with the newest product I found very useful and practical and these smart speakers are just one of them. Unlike many others, I am using the echo environment in parallel with the Google assistant. The main reason of doing so comes from the compatibility issues and what these devices are programmed to cover. Yes, there are many similarities that you can get from both but if you are really into the smart assistant devices then you realize that the differences are remarkable and I wanted to have everything covered and connected so I am using both (Amazon echo and Google assistant). For obvious reasons, way bigger than what I can even encounter in here, Google is dominating the market when it comes to the speed and ease of use smart assistants and Alexa which is still quite better than Siri, Cortana and Bixby are still way far from Google on the second place. A great example of the differences here is like,when you are talking to an adult person vs you are talking to a kid! So with an adult you can speak freely and expect to get a response most likely than you are talking to a kid. I personally can't blame Amazon for what Google has been dominating solely for years and years ahead of everyone else so if you learned how to speak with this kid (Alexa in here), she is going to get the job done accurately and there's more, as I mentioned on the very beginning. It comes from the area of what one particular device covers and it's that important to get your attention to have the more compatible smart assistant for the tasks or other services you are planning to use. The bottom line here is the third generation of echo dot devices are the best of it's own kind and having them in parallel with Google assistant will do almost everything for what is doable in 2019 technology relm.

reviews.reviewTitle: Dot Quality and Stability Not The Same As Echo
reviews.reviewText:
I had been wanting to play the same music stream in multiple rooms of our townhouse but didn't really want to invest in another Echo solely for that purpose (it's loud enough to hear the music upstairs). Amazon put the new Dot's on sale earlier this year for $29 so I figured the time was right. The first one I ordered had a ship date of about 30 days from when I placed the order, so I thought the demand was high. I noticed a week later I could place a new order and get one in 2 days, so after talking to support for a while, they canceled the first order and I placed a new order at the discounted price.

The on-sale Dot arrived and set up as expected. I noticed a lag in response time slowly growing over the course of about two weeks. It also would connect to the external speaker I paired it to, but would never put sound out through it (or itself) after the initial pairing the next time the speaker was turned on. All I needed to do was unplug the device and it started working again. After doing this several times over a few weeks I felt like there was a larger issue so I reached out to support - the website recommended the online chat. That session with Shashi lasted 58 minutes and resulted in a full reset of the Dot and I was told it would resolve the issue but to feel free to reach back out if it happened again.

The about-every-two-weeks lag continued and I unplugged/replugged it in again and even reset it again but the cycle remained the same until it recently just started throwing a red ring at me and said to try again later.

I again contacted support and after a harrowing recount of the experience, I was told by "Iris" the unit was defective and that I'd have to BUY ANOTHER unit. Iris offered me the following consolation (quotes included), "While this isn't a common issue, Echo is a physical electronic device, and there's always a possibility something can happen. We realize this and offer a 90-day Limited Warranty that covers any defect not caused by physical damage. We also know accidents happen so we have special options available to purchase a new device at a discount."

While it was nice to have a Dot in another room to localize commands, the spotty performance, inability to maintain a Bluetooth connection to an external speaker, and a sketchy sale followed by a lengthy troubleshooting process that took the unit out of warranty and mandated a second purchase, I'd recommend that you pay full price and log any issues and troubleshooting steps immediately, keeping in mind the 90-day window.

You are probably better off just getting a more expensive Echo to accomplish the second Alexa goal since they seem to perform flawlessly (in my experience).

Buyer beware!

I cannot emphasize enough how much distain I have for Amazon's Alexa. Half the time she doesn't understand what I am asking the other half of the time she cannot search the internet besides wikipedia for things, which apparently she can only now do as of 12/8 via setting up skills. Skills are also required to have her control fire TV related link like hulu and Netflix. With every new rendition she becomes less helpful not more helpful or harder to set up and then use and this is also not an age related thing as I have worked in tech for years I have 2 dots and 3 echos currently all but one are in use, when I ask her to play music from Amazon music and play it on a group set up for multi room speakers she can't seem to do that even and I have tried naming the group numerous different things in Hopes she will understand me better. Fortunately I am able to return a few of these things still and plan on doing just that. So beware, I for one am Extremely disappointed in the sound quality, I understand that the speaker is small but honest to GOD my Samsung smart watch phone and Apple Beats speakers have better quality. I have purchased and tried every generation of these so far and will not be buying any future ones. Depending on what you are buying for and expectations, I would suggest going with a google home rather than these Good luck and happy disappointment to all

This is my families first Alexa hardware product and boy does it produce. She’s quick and surprisingly knowledgeable. She has answers for everything and a great trivia knowledge which is fun. I like that you can change the wake word to four predetermined ones (computer is an option for Star Trek fans). If someone in your family is named Alexa you can still use it without it driving you nuts.

It gets loud enough to hear in other rooms and the amount of automation, which Amazon calls “routines,” is extensive. I have it a set up to lower the volume to 3 (out of 10) at 9pm and raise it back up to 5 at 9am. This keeps our kids from waking us up and we don’t have to constantly change the volume. There are plenty more options if you have other smart lighting even not in the Ring universe. Ex. It can control my IKEA TRÅDFRI smart plugs I use for lighting. All of this without setting it up.

It is a little creepy to have it always listening to us and it knows a surprising amount about my other accounts (Pandora worked with my account without setup). My wife and I don’t talk about anything work confidential at home but it may bother others if they work from home. There is a physical mute button on the top of the echo dot but it’s only a software switch and not a hardware one. If that makes a difference to you be ware.

Overall, we got ours free with the Ring Alarm system as a promo and the echo dot is a surprisingly good voice assistant and we all use it more often than I figured. Definitely a good buy.

Works as advertised, sound is better than I expected (based on size and price) and with a little research and tinkering, I had a smart home in no time (bulbs, plugs, etc.). However, if I had the extra funds and the Black Friday sale price were a tad lower, I would've bought the Echo Plus due to it's built-in 'smart hub,' meaning I could have used various other smart devices together without having to purchase their hubs as well.

Only drawback for me is the voice recognition when asking Alexa to play my Spotify playlists-- to be fair, my playlist names are unconventional and I have discovered that the simpler the name the better. Also-- don't use punctuation and words not germane to the dialect you've chosen in the language settings (Indian accent, UK, etc.). No stars off for renaming playlists, just a lesson learned.

On a side note, if you set Alexa to Australian/New Zealand accent and then, in your infinte jest, ask her to 'put another shrimp on the barbie,' she will absolutely let you know how she feels about that hackneyed and clichéd stereotype. Good on ya, Alexa.

Initially I was going to write a higher review but I have had some issues with the New Dit. Unfortunately at times it sounds Very Fuzzy, like a Buzzing sound. This will be during any random song. Sometimes the Same song will sound fine. Other times it can just sound horrible and I just yell for Alexa to STOP because I can't stand that sound. Almost seems like the speakers are just messed up half the time. When it works, it sounds Way better than the Echo 2. When it gets fuzzy, it's just awful. Also, I paid $30 New and NOW they're charging $50. THAT Is why I also Can NOT give it more than 3☆.

reviews.reviewTitle: Dots Just Keep on Getting Better
reviews.reviewText: I am a fan of Alexa. I have or have had just about every Echo device Amazon has manufactured, plus some third party...for my car, Bose 500 Speaker, and the Bose 700 Soundbar. Throughout this, since the release of the first Dot, there have been Alexa Dots in my life. This is the best yet. Sure the footprint is a little bigger, but I like that. The cloth cover is attractive and has a nice feel. This Dot 3E connected to my household WiFi immediately. The sound is much improved. Overall a better Dot. In fact, after the first, I went back and bought two more. I travel frequently in my work, and one of them will go in my suitcase. These days Dot works well in an hotel room. Highly recommended.

We've only had our Alexa devices setup for about two weeks now, so we're definitely still working out the kinks. With that said, this is a review of everything I've noticed of our entire Alexa ecosystem, which includes 2x Echo Dots, 2x Echo Spots, 2x refurbished Echos, and 1x Echo Sub:

Pros: Individually, they all work exactly as they should ALMOST all the time (more on that in the cons section). They all look good, and aren't big, ugly hunks of metal and plastic taking up space in your house. They were all incredibly easy to get through initial setup (except the Echo Sub, more below). Music sounds good in all of them, to include the Echo Dots (but it sounds GREAT on the Echos, and fantastic on the Echo/Sub pair).

Cons: The voice recognition is almost too good for its own good. We have a fairly open floor plan, with an Echo Spot in the living room and an Echo in the kitchen. Sometimes they both hear a demand, and the wrong device (meaning the one farther away) will respond. I find myself occasionally whispering to an Echo device so its friends don't butt in to the convo.

The Echo Sub needed to be reset 3x when I first got it/went to set it up. I had to log in/out of the app a couple times as well before it was recognized and would actually pair to an Echo.

Sometimes Alexa tells me she can't complete a request, then my wife (who uses Alexa far less often than I do) will ask the same request and it works...and vice versa. We haven't figured out what we're doing/saying or not doing/not saying for these discrepancies to happen, but hopefully that'll work itself out with time.

The most irritating issue I have so far is getting music to play on the "Everywhere" group. Sometimes I say "Alexa play music everywhere" and it just doesn't do it. Sometimes it'll play on only some of the devices, and sometimes it'll only play on the device I was speaking to. Our house is two stories, and we have two kids and a dog, so we spend a ridiculous amount of our time cleaning/walking up and down the stairs. A big part of the reason I bought these was for the music to fill the house while cleaning, and it oftentimes requires me to spend some time arguing with Alexa to get that to happen. It's even gotten to the point where I've had to go into the app and manually select "Everywhere," because the voice command just won't work.

Individual components:

2x Echo Dots (w/ separately purchased wall mounts): No complaints. They setup just fine, and work perfectly. They're actually bigger than I thought they would be, and look a little clunky mounted to the wall, but overall they don't mess up our aesthetic enough for me to dock them a star or anything. 5/5 would recommend.

2x Echo Spots: No complaints again. These were the first two devices we bought, and they worked so well I decided to buy the other devices. My favorite part of these is their ability to pull up security cam footage. My desk is in the basement, so it's nice to say "Alexa show me the driveway" and see who just pulled in, or to say "Alexa show me the front door" when the doorbell rings. I paired these will some web cam covers (also bought on Amazon, of course) so Jeffy and his crew can't record me all day long.

2x refurbished Echos (in charcoal): I bought these to play music, and they sound amazing. We'll see how they hold up, given that they're refurbished equipment, but I have my fingers crossed. They also look great, and are not an eye sore like other speakers.

1x Echo Sub: The only device that gave me an issue with the setup process. For that, I'd honestly give the Sub 4/5 stars because it really was a pain in the butt getting it properly hooked up. It gave me issues not just connecting to Wifi, but also when pairing with an Echo. Lots of logging in/out of the app, resetting the Sub. Irritating, to say the least. However, with that one star docked, I'd give it a SOLID 4/5 stars. This thing sounds GREAT. I'm a huge music lover, but hip hop/rap is really where my loyalty lies. And I NEED bass when I jam, and this thing delivers bass in spades. Even with the setup issue, I'm planning on buying another for in the basement. If Amazon ever makes a waterproof version, I'll buy one for outside for bbqs/parties too.

The 3rd Gen Echo Dot is neat enough. It's considerably louder if you're just using the base unit. I sat it side by side with a 2nd Gen and linked them to play the same song at the same time, and I had to turn the 3rd Gen to Volume 3 to even hear the 2nd Gen. I don't use either of my Dots with their built-in speaker, so that's not really a selling point for me.

The main problem I have with the 3rd Gen is that it seems to be a little slower to respond to the wake word - sometimes. The delay between "Alexa" and the light ring lighting up definitely seems to be slower - but it's a minor note because it doesn't affect the operation of the device. It'll still hear you say whatever you say after the wake word, and I've only had one time where I struggled to get it to listen to me for a moment.

There was one other issue where it became unresponsive and went into setup mode for no apparent reason. In order to make it work again I had to de-register it in the app and reconnect it. It was odd, and I've never had that happen with a 2nd Gen.

Still, for my purposes (having it connected to external speakers via 3.5mm cable), there's more or less nothing that makes the 3rd Gen any better than the 2nd. The mic seems to work just as well, though I haven't tried talking to it from across my home yet. My 2nd Gen can hear me through a closed door in the next room, so I'd assume the 3rd Gen is even better, but I haven't needed to try that yet. As I said before, the 3rd Gen's volume is greatly increased over the 2nd, so if you don't have yours connected to an external speaker, it would probably be well worth upgrading.

I have several Dots - this being my 1st 3rd Gen. I didn't have to do anything using the app - I plugged it in and it started up all by itself......nice surprise. Since each of mine are in separate rooms and not connected by Bluetooth, they basically work individually. To be honest, I see no difference except for looks, in this and its' previous Generation 2 model. I know for those of you who have several working as a unit some of the new added features might be important.

reviews.reviewTitle: We absolutely LOVE our Alexa devices, Dots Fill Out Your House so Alexa is Everywhere
reviews.reviewText:
We absolutely LOVE our Alexa devices at our house, have 20 in active use, and actually own 26, 3 of them being this Echo Dot (3rd-gen). There are uses for all the types. We have most of our lighting standardized on TP-Link smart outlets, smart switches, & smart bulbs. In rare occasions the bridge between the two has gone down a few times over the years, and then you are forced to remember how much effort it is to walk over and turn everything on and off yourself versus Alexa doing it all for you :) . Our most convenient use has been the backyard lighting all on smart bulbs to it is just a shout to turn them all on or off because each were on separate light switches in different sides of the house. The point of Dots is so that they are cheap enough to put one in every room, so Alexa will hear and respond from the closest, wherever you may be in your house.

The Echo Dot itself is great. The 3rd-gen dot is a little bigger than the 2nd gen, is slightly upgraded but functions the same, and fits subtly nearly anywhere. I have one on an outlet mount in a bathroom, which is nice to get the news, or weather, or anything while you get ready for bed or get up in the morning. The speaker itself is just fine. My wife honestly listens to music on it sometimes when it is just more convenient than when she is near a full Echo, and doesn't mind. It is better than the speaker on my smart phone. You can pair it with a Bluetooth speaker or headphones, which I find most convenient for my portable dot that I have on top of a portable battery for it. That's what I use for toting into the garage or backyard to work on stuff. Inside, I usually have an Echo or Show nearby that I use when I really want great sounding music.

FYI: We have 4 Echos (original), 2 Echo Shows (original), 1 Echo Spot , 6 Echo Dots (2nd-gen) + 3 more not in current use displaced by our Echo Shows & Spot, these 3 Echo Dots (3rd-gen), 1 ecobee SmartThermostat with Voice Control (with 9 room sensors) + 1 ecobee4 with Alexa that it replaced, 1 Fire TV with Voice Remote, 1 Echo Auto, 1 Garmin Speak, and 1 smart watch with Alexa as default -- all of which listen and respond as a smart speaker. I honestly miss it when I'm in the garage or out outside my house when I start to say Alexa to ask something and she's not there :) . Yes, I even have a dot with a portable battery for such cases.

reviews.reviewTitle: Alexa is a fun device that is useful every day
reviews.reviewText: Okay, Alexa is not perfect but she is amazing. The pros are the small size, the attractive appearance, the ability to use the devices as intercoms between rooms, and in general the fun of finding out all the useful things you can do with the device. I like Alexa for setting a timer, or two, serving as an alarm clock, giving me all kinds of reminders to do tasks and take my medicine, she does a bang up job making grocery and shopping lists and sending them. to my smartphone, helping us cook by doing all kinds of recipe conversions, acting as a calculator, playing music of the type you like, telling you the weather and forecast, telling you the time, looking up word definitions, it’s really a lot of fun to use.. My husband built a little robot and works on getting them to talk to each other with hilarious results. I keep finding items in my amazon shopping cart Alexa put there because Little Bot told her to. , There was a refrigerator in there yesterday, I must be careful when I check out! I have enjoyed playing games like Jeopardy with her.. I am sure there are many more things Alexa can do that I have not hit on yet, but when in doubt if she can do something I give it a try. . A couple things that could be better. Alexa can’t deal with the “past” if it’s more than a few seconds later.. I can’t ask her to tell me say, what time she reminded me to take my medicine...She can’t do repeated reminders unless they are in a calendar. Sometimes playing a game I cannot understand her voice, and she cannot understand mine. So I might give the correct answer in Jeopardy but it was not heard correctly. Music in the kitchen, like oldies or rock sounds fine,but when I had her play a sleep story at night, the sound was slightly distorted. I would rather listen to,it from my iPad. Sometimes it gets confusing trying to tell her to stop a timer or add things to the grocery list. You have to remember the right way to ask. Sometimes she shuts off really fast, and I think I am talking to her from the next room, but she’s already off. We have not had our devices long, so I imagine there is a lot more to learn.. We know she is “spying” on us, but generally it is not a concern. We can always just shut her off. I am peeved that every time you play Jeopardy , she tries to sell you hints! No way I know to turn this function off! I feel like I am finally in the 21st century and I am enjoying it.

reviews.reviewTitle: I bought the 3rd Gen for better sound and Stereo Pairing
reviews.reviewText: I grew up in an era of sound appreciation where the stereo norm was to have Bose or Advent speakers and super high quality hi-fidelity equipment. When reviewers said the Echo Dot 3rd gen had better sound I should have known better. The echo 3 might have shifted its frequencies to the lower end compared to the weak tea Echo-2, but the price of more bass was clarity. The midtones and lows are muddy and in my opinion less favorable to listen to than the 2nd gen echo dots. As for stereo pairing, at first it was nice waking up to having two Echo Dot 3rd gens in stereo 40 inches apart placed on my bed Head Board. But then they kept slipping out of synch. Then you have two roque echos basically doing what they want, making random selections and the sound going up and down and in and out. So you have to re-synch or unplug one, which is what I did. Another disappointment is the Echo Subwoofer. Ughh ! I will just have to wait until Amazon takes High Fidelity and Stereo-phonics seriously.

Update 10-6-19.. I have really come to strongly dislike the Alexa platform, from skills that do not work or are programmed by juvinlies that babble for ever, to the updates and annoyances.
Moved to a new apartment this week and put everything back in the corresponding rooms.. Apparently the Dots and android app updated because now upon entering a room with a Echo and saying "turn on the lights", all the bloody thing says is "Can't find a device called Lights"... and its not just one Dot, its all of them.. I then went back to the app to check the group settings.. None of the Dots were assigned to Groups, nor could any of the dots be assigned to a group! I deleted groups, reset the echo's..just about anything I could think of.. NONE of them could be assigned to a group/room..
It was easy to get to link up with the Sonoff/Itead switches in use throughout the house.. Set up was near flawless..
The CONS...
Noisy environments or a few friends talkin... the Echos generally require us to ask people to be quiet so that a command can be issued.. even conversations in another room will cause a Sorry I don't understand that..
Skills.. Tried the Pizza Hut skill.. it just drops.. a few other skills do let ya stop the interaction, instead its an endless loop of annoying Do you want to enable..whatever... the only way out is to unplug the bloody things..
Location within the house.. I asked the echo's what room they were in, (prior to the assignments being undone after an update).. it just says "I am here" one would think they'd have it respond accordingly...
Commands: There is a setting to tell Alexa to wait for other questions after one is posed but as for commands each separate command must be singular.. For instance, once all my devices were setup and put into their respective "rooms" telling Alexa to turn on that room turns on ALL those devices.. There are a few that don't need to be on, like the consoles, wax warmers and a few other items.. One could program scenes and/or routines but that isn't the point.. We should be able to say "Alexa, turn off XXX AND turn on XXC"
The Alexa App... requires the Amazon Shopping App.. but if the shopping app is removed then Alexa will not start AND keep spying in the background. The combined apps are a HUGE drain on battery life.. My phone fell to about 5 hours when the apps were installed..
While mobile browsers and PC browsers are all using html5 and other technology [apps included].. Amazon has taken another page from the big "G's" playbook and deliberately limited the ability to manage the Alexa devices and other functions from a PC.. They want those apps on our phones.
Censoring: I had asked what a Spanish word meant, and it replied "I'd rather not answer that".. Now I knew it was a bit of a naughty word.. however I do expect a proper translation/answer to ANY query thrown at the device.. I do not appreciate Amazon taking on a Nanny cap and limiting my access to future requests.
Overall the Dots are a bit of fun and some convenience... but the ever so slight manipulation that prevent me from using the PC to manage my home automation through Alexa platform is BIG Frown for me..

We have been using our new Dot for a few weeks. Overall, it is awesome. We love the HUGE number of skills that are available to use with it. So far, favorites are the flash briefing, lists, trivia skills, reminders...just to name a few. We use ours in the kitchen, as it is sort of the central hub of our home, and so far it’s been great. One thing to note, once you get one of these, if you love it, you’re probably going to want a few of them for different locations if your house, as it doesn’t pick up your voice that great from another room (unless you yell).
This device makes my life so much easier with making grocery lists, as I can just tell it what to add as I’m going through my day and I realize we need something. I create different lists for the different places we go (grocery, Target, etc.) and it’s so nice to just ask Alexa to add items as I think of them. I do wish you could add multiple items at one time...if there’s a way to do this, I haven’t figured it out yet.
Also, really love the timer; big help with cooking, as you don’t have to stop and wash your hands to set a timer.
I really love the reminders! These have been a great help, from daily reminders to take my vitamins to things that I don’t want to forget in the upcoming days or weeks.
I love that I can play music on it while making dinner. The sound quality is great, in my opinion. Our children get a kick out of Alexa saying grace before meals with us too.
It’s also super convenient if you want to reorder something from amazon too.
A few of the things that could be improved on are Alexa’s pronunciation of certain words; sometimes with the vocabulary skills I’ve enabled, she’s hard to understand. Sometimes she doesn’t hear you when you call her name. And sometimes the way you need to ask something in order for her to give an answer is a bit annoying. She relies heavily on Wikipedia for things as well, which is not the greatest. It would be awesome if she used a search engine like google, although I understand why it can’t.
Overall, we like it and enjoy finding new things to use it for to make day to day life easier. If you are into technology and want something to assist you, this would likely be right up your alley.

Definitely plays music well, as long as you aren't too worried about amazing sound quality. For the size of the speaker, it's prettty awesome.

Alexa is very helpful, we use her to set timers for TV/Computer time limits, cooking. I have a reminder to take my vitamins set in, which is excellent since I am always forgetting. Every day she helps me remember things. We have a grocery list set up, so I can add items to the grocery list as I use them, which helps us keep from running out of essentials. If I see something is low, like the peanut butter, I simply say 'Alexa, add peanut butter to grocery list' and it's there. If I have already added, she lets me know and asks if I need to add it again. You can access the lists in real time from the app on your cell phone, so if my husband stops on his way home from work, he can see everything we need right in the store, and check it off the list as he picks it up.

As long as you don't mind the marketing that comes along with being listened to constantly, it's great. (Husband and I discussed getting oil for our new house in the kitchen and immediately after I had an ad for an oil company on Instagram. Could have also been our phones. Hard to tell what is triggering these events anymore nowadays.)

We also got one for the kids to have in their playroom and they love it. I know there are more features that I can access for them. I just have to find a good description of what they are.

One drawback is that you can only link one music service account (that I can tell). Amazon music will only play on one speaker at a time for me, so if the kids ask for a song downstairs, my music stops upstairs. We have gotten around this (upstairs adults) by listening to another app, like iHeartRadio's generic radio stations (since you can't log in and customize likes/stations to multiple music services that I can tell), or TuneIn will play public radio by asking for the program automatically.

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazon needs to add a few things.
reviews.reviewText:
I had the Google mini and Google wifi but I do a lot of shopping at Amazon, and I have an Amazon music subscription so it made sense to get one of these. I have a dot and the bigger echo 2nd gen.
Set up is easy and Alexa immediately recognizes my smart plugs and switches. Integration with smart devices and smart homes works really well. Alexa has some issues tho. She has problems understanding things sometimes. Google rarely has issues but Alexa has them more often than not. She sometimes has a problem understanding what is said. I can go to Google and say the same thing and boom, no problem. I'm a DJ so I speak very well and that's not the issue at all. That can be fixed in time I'm sure tho. Not a deal breaker.
The sound... As a DJ I have to say this speaker sounds good for its size. I think Google mini sounds better but not much better. They recently updated a software issue which would distort the sound when played over level 6 for 10 minutes or more and it sounds much better now at higher volumes.
The things they need to add.
1) Alexa really needs some voice options! Google mini has about 6 and they added John Legend. I think if Amazon could add Jarvis from the Avengers-IronMan then Alexa would be a huge hit! Not being able to change voices definitely hurts Alexa.
2) Alexa needs to be able to call anyone even 911.
3) Its my device, if I want to call it mini me I should be able to do so. Let us name the devices wake word. It really shouldn't be that hard to do. I would even pay money to be able to do that.
Those aren't deal breakers but they should definitely be doable! All in all this Dot is cool and looks good and for the size the sound works. Integration with Amazon music is the bomb! Being a DJ its nice to command Alexa to play anything I want because I'm usually the one getting the requests! Lol
Routines are also a nice touch! Being able to say Alexa, shut it down and she shuts off all my lights, electronics etc is the bomb! With a few improvements Alexa could really be something special! Please Amazon give us voice options...Jarvis voice from Iron man would be huge! Just saying...

The Echo dot itself works well and is a real convenience. However, I'm a very tech-savvy person, and I had to call tech support to get it set up. Even with the tech guiding me, it took over an hour to set it up. The instructions he was giving were simply not working with my equipment for some reason. We tried the Alexa app on my phone and on my Mac computer. Finally got it working. Took two more weeks for me to get Alexa to recognize and control the two smart plugs I bought. I'm not stupid. The Alexa app on my phone would not allow me to enable skills. Just freezes up. Tried tech support, but a gal with a heavy Indian accent, was worse than frustrating. Trial and error, two weeks later, allowed me to finally figure out how to enable skills from the computer. Phone app, still useless after re-installing several times. A neighbor of mine is also having trouble getting Alexa to work with her smart plugs. The technology is not as slick as it should be. Without skills, echo dot is a fancy toy, no more.

reviews.reviewTitle: Alexa Hard at work example Video
reviews.reviewText: Alexa is fun! Having a semi smart home is fairly easy to set up once you get used to the device setup. She does misunderstand daily ( That’s why not 5 stars) but best on the market ( I have 1 google mini which is pretty much useless) but our 5 Echo Dots are awesome

reviews.reviewTitle: Terrible sound with 3rd Gen Echo Dot
reviews.reviewText: I already had two 2nd gen Echo Dots and was happy with them. Nevertheless I eagerly bought two more 3rd Gen Echo Dots when I heard that Amazon had improved the sound. What a huge disappointment. The Alexa functionality is the same (which is great) but the sound is absolutely terrible. At times Alexa's response is unintelligible, even after repeated attempts. The voice is very muffled as if it is covered by a thick blanket, and this is even after trying to tweak the base/treble using the app. I equate Amazon's attempt to improve the 2nd gen Echo Dot to New Coke (which failed terribly)! Trust me, given the choice, get the 2nd gen Echo Dot, or wait until a 4th gen comes out and keep your fingers crossed. The 2 new Echo Dots I bought will be stored away in a box as last resort spares in case my 2nd gens ever fail.

reviews.reviewTitle: What a complete waste of my time
reviews.reviewText: I received this product free as Amazon had some promotional thing going when I ordered my Blink camera. I have tried in vain to set this thing up numerous times. I should point out that I'm fairly tech savvy and can program all my other tech type stuff without any issues. But this thing can't seem to locate my televisions no matter what I do. I only have so much in patience and I reached it today. I really don't like the fact that you have to provide so much personal information in setting it up. I thought I'd give it a try to use it to run the televisions in the house. But after so many tries I'm fed up. I am already greatly uncomfortable with the reach that Google has into our lives. I have embraced technology pretty well but I refuse to rely on the intrusion of this device to do things for me that I am completely capable of doing. I wanted to return it but it appears that I'm stuck with it and thank goodness I didn't shell out any money on this paper weight.

Ok so I have seen these commercials were people can ask Alexa something and she gives this genius answer that is just as good as me using google but thats not the case here. Yes with some difficulty I was able to connect the firesticks and smart plugs with her and I do plan to get some bulbs as well for stuff thats out of reach. I have a reptile room and being able to tell her when to turn lights, heat, etc off is very helpful.

Another thing I really like is the guard option, if she hears glass break or a smoke alarm she will call me or notify me on my phone. This is wonderful because again a huge reptile room with lots of heat and light and that I have teenagers that stay home while I am work. I wake them before I leave but I am always sure they wait till Im gone from the driveaway and go back to sleep. My husband lives 3 minutes away from our house so if we knew smoke alarms were going off he could get there right away.

I also have a small dog who is very attached and experiences separation anxiety and Alexa very easily hooked up to a camera (ring) and let me put it where I could see my dog. I can check on him throughout the day and talk to him or even have alexa call his name and he loves it.

Finally I was offered a 3 month unlimited amazon music trial. Me, my husband, and 4 teens are loving it. I wish the volume was a bit louder but thats not an issue since I can connect another speaker. I love to be able to just say any song title and she plays it. I can tell her to skip or cancel and she hears my voice over the music. My daughter has a 2nd gen and it just isnt as great as this new third gen. I cleaned my entire house and worked with the animals listening to music the entire time, my husband even enjoyed it enough to leave the tv off and he isnt into music as much as I am. I think I may actually keep the amazon music once the trial is over. Im loving it.

reviews.reviewTitle: An absolute dream for any tech enthusiast!
reviews.reviewText:
I bought the Echo Dot 2 over a year ago. Put it in my van, and tinkered.
I now have 2 of the third generation. I miss the USB cord. But other than that, it's a great improvement over the 2nd gen.

I recently bought 2 on prime day and now wish I would have purchased 2 more. My real purpose was just something to help me keep track of my appointments and it does that OK.. I still have to tell Alexa to add an appointment or add it in my calendar myself, but it does a pretty good job of reminding me.. if I do my part. Some of the things I like, that really didn't interest me before include shopping list maker. I can tell her to add something to my shopping list and she does! So I'm cooking, run out of something- Alexa add butter to my shopping list. Really works very well. I also like turning on and off my lights with Alexa. I did need to add smart plugs to do it, but it was super easy and now I can turn on or off a light with the sound of my voice or the push of a button. Word to the wise-- if your husband turns off the light at the regular switch because he won't remember alexa bedroom light off, it's not going to work for you. I did choose to set up different commands-- bedroom lamp, bedroom light, and just bedroom in hopes that it will make it less painful to remember 1 phrase. If you find something close enough to the phrase, it will still work. I sometimes said bedroom lamp instead of bedroom light. Now either will work. Of course you can't have 2 plugs named the same. Alexa is smart, but not a mind reader. We also have reptiles and I can now program their lights the same way. So I can say Alexa Mortimer day and Alexa knows to switch the routine. I can automate it further to just do it at a certain time, BUT I haven't done that yet. I also like that I can have my audio book read to me, I can set a sleep timer so it will automatically go off. There are a ton of different apps to try like daily meditation. Really Some very cool features!

reviews.reviewTitle: List of Changes compared to 2nd gen
reviews.reviewText:
The 3rd generation doesn't do anything new in terms of core functionality (2nd gen can do everything 3rd gen can do), but made some enhancements to the overall design

Going to put my original review of 2nd gen Echo Dot at the end, in that review i compared it to the original echo (with speakers) and go through most of the features. Now let's list the changes compared to 3rd gen:

1. New look

Bigger and weightier

Feels more premium. Visually it blends in better with your home decor rather than a hockey puck sitting on the table.

No Amazon logo instead has this fabric-like material around it. Very similar to the top of the Google Home Mini.

2. 4 microphones

Has 4 microphones; one around each of the buttons. 2nd gen only had one in the center.

Able to hear you better, especially in the morning as you don't have to raise your voice to tell Alexa to turn off the alarm.

Has higher pick up range by a few feet. Very similar to mic pickup on Google Home Mini

3. Better sound

Speakers on the device is a night-and-day difference compared to the 2nd generation especially when instrumentals are playing. Still not as good as the original echo with speaker built in

4. DC power

Uses a proprietary DC cable instead of micro-usb, which i'm not in favor of.

Can take up outlet plug. May be troublesome if you plan to use it on a power brick/stick

5. LED

LED lights has changed. Has a more fluid movement when lights circle around the device.

Light is also dimmer, but still visible. Good if you have to use Alexa at night when it's on the nightstand, doesn't strain your eyes.

Has a more pink-ish ring instead of a red ring when there's an error.

6. Tactile buttons.

All buttons are tactile so you can blind feel what you're pressing in the dark. Before, only the action button has raised symbols.

Other than that. Everything else functions the same. Still disappointed it doesn't have back up battery power in case you set up an alarm and the power outage occurs. Unless you don't have a good blueooth or wired speaker to pair with your second generation echo, or you can't raise your voice in far distances then the functionality is basically the same and it's not worth the upgrade in my opinion.

If you never owned an Amazon Echo device, want another one around the house, or plan to give as a gift then it's worth considering

===
Original Echo Dot 2nd gen review:

Yes, it's a slim down version of the Amazon Echo* without the speaker.

*For this review I'm going to refer this item as the 'Dot' and the 'Amazon Echo' as the one with the speakers incorporated in the device

It functions exactly the same except the voice for Alexa is not as smooth (probably due to the speakers in Amazon Echo).

You CAN play music on the Echo Dot without a speaker plugged in. Compared to the Amazon Echo you won't get the surround sound feature, but it's pretty decent if you're one who focus more on lyrics than instrumentals. There's an optional Aux 3mm plug in and bluetooth compatibility if you find the sound coming from the dot less sufficient and want to use an external speaker

The Echo is very portable. Fits in the palm of your hand. Love how the plug on the Dot is detachable unlike the Amazon Echo so it's easy to tranfer to a new location when you need to.

Setup is very easy, just download the Alexa App and following the directions included in the box.

Features wise, it's similar to Siri, Ok Google or Cortana: you can ask it questions, make shopping lists, schedule appointments, play music, set alarms, link it to Pandora/Spotify/iheartradio, see traffic updates, sports updates, news briefings, use as smart phone device, voice purchasing off amazon, among other of features. For full list of features or suggestions are present in the app and the e-mail news letter if you sign up for it.

Going to go through some of the features now and what you should look out for:
-Alarms: If you own multiple echo devices (Dot, Amazon Echo, and/or Amazon Tap), alarms is device specific. Good for if you have one in the master bedroom, the alarm will not go off in the child's room for example. Whatever you voice set the alarm with, it will go off on that device. Also note that the Echo devices are wifi and power dependent. If there's a blackout or if your wifi is down the alarm will not go off

-Voice activation: if you own multiple echo devices and they're within the same proximity of each other, best to assign different wake words for each so both won't go off the same time. You have the option for 3 wake words: Amazon, Alexa and Echo.

-Voice purchasing: look out for Alexa only deals. There are variety of discounts only offered through Alexa like how the special offers on Amazon Tablet works

-Smart Home. By far the best feature in my personal opinion is the smart phone feature. You do need a smart plug or thermostat that's Alexa compatible, but it makes your life much easier by just using your voice to control the temperature, TV, or on/off the lights without having to walk up to the switch or console.

Overall very good device to have around you home as it improves on your quality of life, and makes life similar if you own a smart home device. I'd get this over the Amazon Echo if you own your own high quality speakers as it's essentially the same device without the speaker. If you can chip in a little more I'd go for the upgrade as the speakers on the Amazon Echo is really good, if you want to compare it to your own home speakers I'd go check out the display demo that are available at some retail electronic stores.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Future Has Arrived...We are Now "The Jetsons" With Echo Dot...So Useful!
reviews.reviewText:
The Future is here with Echo, Echo Dot and Alexa. I got Echo Dot at a fantastic price during Prime Day--my son was SO excited when he saw me pull Echo Dot out of the box. I am amazed at all the free skills available for Alexa--this little dot can do so many things. Other skills are available at a nominal cost. You can configure Alexa to do almost anything you want, provided some items (like your car, appliances) are Alexa-ready.

It is extremely easy to set up Alexa--Amazon sends you an email with instructions. Click on the links and follow the step-by-step instructions. In a few minutes I was set up and enabling skills. Last night we went to sleep to the sound of ocean waves. With Echo Dot comes a 30-day trial of Amazon Music Unlimited and access to 50 MILLION songs. I have Prime Music with my Prime account, so I'll have access to only 2 million...that's enough for us!

You can command Alexa to play any genre music you like. I found harp music, Christmas music, and even Hanukkah music! We can't even find Hanukkah music on the cable TV music channels where we live, so it was fun listening to the selections on Echo Dot. Not only was traditional Hanukkah music played, but also contemporary. Again, you need to be a Prime member to get Prime music or purchase a subscription to Amazon Music Unlimited (a bargain at $119.00/year) for Alexa to play music. BUT--if you subscribe to another music service like Spotify, Pandora, Apple Music, etc you can still use Echo Dot and Alexa to play music. All you need to do is enable the particular skill for your music service in your Amazon account. What could be easier?

Echo Dot and Alexa offers incredible flexibility, thousands of skills and more are added every day. I highly recommend Echo Dot. I have friends who use regular Echo and are extremely pleased with it--they have their whole house set up with Echo. One friend even has Echo with a monitor, so at any time they command a certain show or movie to be played.

As a kid I used to watched "The Jetsons" and was amazed by all the gadgets they had in their house. Now I feel I'm in the age of "The Jetsons" with Echo Dot. It's such an awesome little device that has unlimited possibilities!

reviews.reviewTitle: New amazon generations do not work in my house
reviews.reviewText: I have the craziest thing is happening in my house I can't use the 3rd gen dot or the new 4k stick. They both reboot and never get to the setup. Im using the supplied power adapters. I've even gone to the extent of shutting off the main breaker to my house and using a battery backup still doesn't get to the orange setup. If I put the 3rd gen dot in my car and leave my house a couple blocks away it will finally boot to the orange setup. I must have a radio signal interference near my house that's causing the new Amazon devices to freak out and not boot. I currently have 3 fire tv cubes, a fire tv pendant, 3 2nd gen echos and 3 2nd echo dots. Those all work fine so its really hard to understand why the new amazon generations are failing.

Got it for the great amazon music unlimited deal, price is really unbeatable! And I really like the color!

Pros:

1. Great size
My apartment is rather small so I don’t need a big speaker for easy music, the little echo dot is pretty powerful!

2. Many skills
Alexa has many skills that can be played around with, like Kungfu panda game with kids is so fun! Also, they have games and news for adults too.

3. Tightly integrates with Amazon music limited
It works very well with the amazon music app, I can just select music on the app and play on echo dot.

4. Smart home
It really helps a lot with the light and heater situation. Quick response as well. I can just have the light on or off on the bed.

Cons:

1. Bugs/ lags
Sometimes it will stop playing music or stop responding, it’s not often and I’m not sure if it’s because of my WiFi.

2. Hard to understand sometimes
Sometimes Alexa doesn’t speak smoothly, like a heavy robot sound, there are some words that I couldn’t understand.
And it’s weird that Alexa can’t respond to the same question sometimes.

3. Voice control
When you’re playing loud music, you pretty much have to yell so that Alexa can hear you.

I'm completely in love with alexa. As lazy as it may sound, this tiny device and the app on my phone does so much for me. I've paired it with smart bulbs, my Bluetooth bose, and smart plugs. I'm pretty sure this is one of the best devices Amazon has to offer. We caught them again on sale and for 22.00 at bestbuy and was able to get one for every room in the house. The sound quality is excellent, it's so good sometimes I fail to tell her to connect to the Bluetooth because it's loud enough. Now my drawback is even tho we have one in every room, you have to buy a family subscription to Amazon music to play music more than one device at the time. But if you want her to broadcast the news, the weather, read you a book or the kids a bedtime story, she's amazing. When we leave home, we can tell her to cut the lights on or off by using the app. Now she has a feature I don't quite understand, when you leave you tell her you are leaving, she says OK I will start guarding. But if and when there is noise in the house, she doesn't record the sounds of voices and she doesn't notify you about it either. I had it set to guard, my son and his girlfriend came in from out of town walking taking laughing etc, she did nothing. I come home and tell her I'm home, and she says OK I'll stop guarding. I think the away features should be tweeked. At least let the guard mode send you a notification and a clip of the sounds involved, or send a notification and let you listen to the background so you can decide if it's someone who is supposed to be there or something isn't right. Maybe the technology is still too new but I really hope this feature gets addressed.. It could be valuable and it definitely needs some attention. I've also purchased these at 22.00 for my family members and some friends but with the sale, there was a limit on how many I could buy. At full price, I would only have the one device. I have a Sonos speaker with alexa built-in in my living room but on the other side, I have an echo dot as well. I brag about the features to any friends unfamiliar with it and some of them have bought them and love them just as much as we do. I also bought a 2nd generation from eBay for 10.00 for my grandson whose still little, he likes it but she doesn't understand a word he says..lol. But his mom can walk in his room and tell alexa to read him a book, or tell him a story. They also come with their own phone number which I really like and you can talk room to room. It's hard to get use to calling from it instead of using facetime but it's still handy. Sometimes when you ask for a specific song, you have to pronounce it very proper or she won't understand it. Sometimes she won't understand it or say she can't find it or she will just play some off the wall song that has the same phonics as the title. But to solve that, when I ask for a hard to understand title, I just use the search in my app. I can leave it playing music when I go to work and it plays til I get home. My dog doesn't have to sit in silence. This review ended up being very long but I hope it's helpful. I still haven't learned all she can do yet but I'm working on it... Mad at Amazon right now because they have a stand alone alexa for your car, my friend got hers for 19 bucks but they tell me, I have to be on a waiting list. I don't like the waiting part and who knows how long it will be lol. So for now I have to use the app and my car Bluetooth, but I will survive. If I get comfortable with using just the app in the car, I might not even need the stand alone device.

So I've always maintained I have no intention of talking to a computer. I hate phone trees that force you to talk.
Siri? No way am I ever gonna do that!
But in my new little house I have a bedside lamp behind a plant and it was a total pain trying to turn it off at night without knocking over the lamp. Well, I broke down and ordered an echo dot with a smart plug. By the next month I had 2 dots and two smart plugs. Alexa and I have about figured each other out! She knows which music I like and I know I have to speak up a bit for her to hear me. (Maybe she has a slight hearing problem?)
Anyhow she turns my lamp on and off and turns my tv on and off and switches channels in the living room.
In my craft room she turns my glue gun and lamp on and off and plays music in the background while I play. What more could you want?

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazing product yet niche and unnecessary for most people
reviews.reviewText: Awesome and fun. So many great features. I bought it for smart home use and it's been a charm. I wish it didn't need internet but I understand how it works so its fine. My biggest gripe is that their still aren't enough skills available for various interests. One that stands out is that theirs no weather skill for my area or a news skill for many areas, but I can't fault amazon for that since most of these skills seem to be independently developed. If the internet is too slow it sometimes hiccups and might take awhile to speak back or if a song is playing through it might lower the quality but those are to be expected. My second gripe is that the bass is sounds a little off but all in all it's a great product that works great for its main purposes, if you want better audio just buy the version that hooks up to your stereo system.

It takes 4 minutes to locate the Echo. Then it says to setup wifi manually, even tho my wifi works fine. Then when I select their amazon wifi it says it's connected and the light changes to red or pink and the app bails out to the start page. It does this over and over and never connects. Nice packing too, Th small Dot box was thrown in a 12x12x12 box with no packing and had a very rough ride. Pitiful.

reviews.reviewTitle: Had a first generation and this replaced it
reviews.reviewText:
We are using this in the bathroom and it's great. Hears well over background noise, hooked up with our Bluetooth speaker light easily, but plays well on its own. It's great to be able to add stuff to the shopping list, and hear music and news when you need it. Works well and set up was simple
Update - speaker volume. As we already had a speaker/light combination in the bathroom we hadn't really tested the volume of the echo dot. When the speaker light failed we were planning to replace the light/speaker combo. While we were debating on the purchase of a new light I told the dot to increase volume to 10, needless to say we found we didn't need to order a replacement speaker, the echo is PERFECT without one. Crisp and clear sound and excellent volume. Excellent quality for news and podcast, acceptable quality for music but... Still loving have more light and better sound quality.

reviews.reviewTitle: The easiest (& cheapest) way to get a house-wide sound system!
reviews.reviewText:
I just bought a new house that's 2 stories and I've always wanted a home-wide speaker system. The house also came with a number of smart-enabled features and after some research, I found that the Alexa system was the best and most affordable option for smart home integration (thanks, wirecutter!). The most shocking thing to me was how incredibly easy it was to set up. I had already set up the main Echo (which was also easy af), so I plugged in the Dot, and it immediately set itself up. I renamed it, and then set up Multi-Room Speakers, and then I played one of my Spotify playlists all over my house at once. GLORIOUS!!
I've seen a couple of people saying that the sound quality isn't great -- whatever man, maybe to a sound snob, but I guess my standards aren't that high because I think they sound great. It's not a Sonos system, but for $25 a pop, who cares?! I love that I don't have to worry about my phone being out of range of a bluetooth speaker when I'm hosting a party or working on stuff in the house.
Another great thing? The devices can troubleshoot themselves. I wasn't sure how to set up multi room speakers so I literally just asked it, "Echo (I changed it from Alexa), how do I set up multi-room speakers," and it just told me. They were also flashing yellow and I didn't know why, so I asked "Echo, why are you yellow?" and it freaking TOLD ME? What a time to be alive.

PS: Originally I had some trouble setting up multi-room speakers. For whatever reason, when I first tried to set it up, it only let me select 1 device at a time. I went and checked the settings of each device and confirmed that they were all on the same wifi signal (they were), and then when I tried again it worked for some reason. Idk. Just a weird bug I guess.

reviews.reviewTitle: Practical! How did we ever survive without this luxury?
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased with intent to use as an intercom for home. Everyone quickly found various uses. I was surprised it needs an app to be downloaded on a phone or tablet to work.

I assumed this device could be plugged and Ready to go but first you must download tthe alexa app on a tablet or phone in order to sync to wifi.

Pay attention when in app store! Two different amazons popped up in my apps. The wrong one asked for a monthly payment of some sort.

This would make for an excellent gift for kids 7 on up or any grown up who likes gadgets of any kind. I purchased these at a discounted rate for prime members at only 20ish a piece. I intend to purchase 4 more if prices ever reflect similar rates.

My daughters enjoyed hearing children stories fully animated with sounds!
They also enjoy the soothing music it played at bedtime.
I enjoyed being able to use the app to text a message to alexa who announces the message to the entire family. I could have just asked Alexa out loud to make the announcement but this allows for the element of surprise! I am curious if i can set it up to sing happy Birthday in the morning....
The possibilities are endless so this has been a sweet delight! I will be purchasing as Christmas gifts for my nieces and nephews.

Lastly it has a handful of unusual features. One is you can look at history on your phone and see every request spoken to Alexa.

Another unusual feature on the app is “drop in” which gives you the option to listen in which i wouldn't turn that option on.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works as expected, can't connect to BT speakers
reviews.reviewText:
So, knowing full well that Amazon listens to and records everything said in earshot of these things and keeps said records forever and lets humans listen to the recordings, I bought one of these to put in my wood shop. All it will ever hear is me 'singing' along to music and the sound of lots of saws running. Hooked up to my 70's Pioneer receiver and a pair of speakers from the same era that are big enough to be night stands. It's nice to be able to just yell at the thing to play music, adjust volume, and tell it that I hate or love this song, and it does it without me having to stop what I'm doing to do so. It's honestly kind of amazing how well it can hear me given how loud I am usually blaring music, and it's sitting right on top of the receiver, which is sitting right on top of the speakers.

That said, I am disappointed that it doesn't seem to be able to actually pair with other bluetooth devices to play music through. The pamplet it came with seemed to indicate that it could, and the Alexa app (that needs more permissions than you have to give and wants every antenna your phone has enabled to install) also seems to indicate it should be possible, but after querying Alexa, the app, and google, I haven't been able to figure out how to pair my Dot with a pair of BT headphones. I have a pair of worktunes headphones that are hearing protection with BT headphones built into them that I would love to be able to play music from the Dot into, but oh well. Can just use my phone like I had been anyway.

Not sure if I really need this device?

It work well for simple things like setting timers or asking for weather or sports stats. We even played a few interesting games on it. The voice recognition is fine, the sound quality if fine so long as you are not really wanting it to play music on it. If you are ok with music coming from a tiny box with no dynamic range, no bass, etc, then you will be fine. For me, I like a real stereo system.

Wrt integration with and control of other devices, so far not overly impressed. I got the Echo Dot to control my new Denon high end receiver. It can turn it on an off, but only with a complex set of words referring to the receiver. And beyond that it is quite limited. I can't play any particular song over the receiver, only itself....so fairly useless in that regard...or maybe I just haven't worked hard enough to make it work. But largely, as I am using Apple AirPlay from iphone, it won't integrate with that separate system.

I have not yet made the investment in other devices like light control, but have noted my daughter has done that at their house, and use it very little. It is a lot of investment for little return. Maybe some day, when I am old and can't move, it can turn off the lights for me.

Maybe over time I will find more uses for it. At this point, it has marginal value for me. It is an ok value for the a low price. I would definately not pay much more money for it. For example, the Apple equivalent, is very costly, might have better sound and integrate a bit better with Apple Music components....but again, at that cost, not for me either.

reviews.reviewTitle: Better sound than I thought I would find
reviews.reviewText:
I was hesitant to buy one of these because some purists had remarked the sound was imperfect. Well, the Echo Dot sounds like a much more expensive speaker. Of course, it cannot compete with Bose Speakers. But for the price and the voice recognition feature plus Alexa integration, I am definitely impressed at the value for money. I must say that the voice recognition is not yet perfect, but it is very good at this skill as well. I have had the device misunderstand my command several times when the air conditioner is running in the room.
There is one little drawback to this device. The skills software routines are incapable of running every app you may have or wish to activate. I have a favorite app that runs a music service that is not Amazon, Apple, Spotify, etc. I must start that app manually. Another drawback with the Alexa integrated environment is the Fire Tablet cannot be used as one of the stations in a music group, for example when I want to play music across multiple rooms. For that, you MUST purchase Echo of one model or another. That bothers me since I use a Fire Tablet on a Show Mode Stand to control my integrated home system, but in order for me to have true house-wide music, I must purchase an Echo device for the room in which I have my Fire Tablet on Show Mode setup. In any case, the system is maturing and I am hopeful the Amazon Software Weenies will repair this oversight.

Setup was very straight-forward using my iPad and the iOS Alexa app. Of particular note, the Echo Dot can connect to WiFi at either 2.4 or 5 GHz, but connection at 5 GHz may require setting your router to manually assign a channel. Initially, the Echo Dot did not see the 5 GHz network on my Apple Airport Extreme, but after an online search, the solution was found. I changed the channel selection on the Airport Extreme from automatic to manual, selecting channel 161, and the Dot connected without issue.

As I also use smart bulbs, a smart wall switch and a smart wall plug, these were integrated into the Echo Dot and Alexa using the iOS TuyaSmart app, and the SmartLife skill. The skill will link to a TuyaSmart account and integrate the smart devices registered there into Alexa. Similarly, the August Smart Home skill connected an August door lock into Alexa.

Some Alexa skills that may be of interest are Big Sky Weather (local weather and forecast), Relax My Cat (nice background music) and AnyList (shopping list).

Skills that I found that do not work are the Anova sous vide (many reports of it not working; Anova may have changed something on their side) and SmartThings to control Samsung devices. The issue with the Samsung device is with a TV; although the device is listed in the Echo, Alexa can turn it off, but cannot turn it on. This dysfunctional control appears to be related to the power state of the TV and the ‘wake on LAN’ control provided by Samsung; however, if a Roku or Firestick (but not AppleTV) is connected to the Samsung TV, Alexa can access them and indirectly turn the TV on when they become active (via HDMI-CEC).

I almost returned this to seller as I wasn't able to get it to connect to my wifi. After getting an error message from the app to scan I of course called the help line. I hung up on two of the Indonesia people I talked to as the first wanted me to purchase security software for my router. BS.. The second time I told them I was going to through it away and they hu g up on me and the third time i asked for someone who could speak English. He said there all busy but he did attempt to help me which led me to going to alexa.amazon.com and syncing it up there. After a few minutes of going through the links I got it to scan. Keep in mind I did restart my router before this but not sure if that had anything to do with fixing it. Anyway go to the link above and sign in with your amazon account and try that before the Alexa App on your phone. YOU WILL HAVE TO CONNECT YOUR WIFI ON YOUR COMPUTER TO Amazon Alexa Wifi. This is not permanent it's just to get your Alexa to connect on it's own. Kinda dumb and confusing. Don't expect Alexa to play Amazon music as it wont connect if it's not a paid service from what I gather. I have a free Pandora account which one can connect from the app then Alexa will let one play music from there once you give it permission to access your account. Plan on at least an hour to get the gist on how all this is done and once you get it working you'll feel pretty good about it and you'll be saying oh that so cool! That's cool too and so on. I'm about 30 feet away from mine in a bedroom and Alexa in the kitchen and she can hear my commands. The sound is pretty decent for such a small size hockey puck. You can get some free stuff such as woof woof for your dog and have a few giggle. (through the app.)
Please don't contact me on how to connect it.

So far I’m not overly impressed with the Echo system first off its a pain to set up literally worse than the Fire tablet it is limited to do very basic commands I was expecting a more interactive content available. Second it can’t even pronounce my name properly or hear my commands to make a list example errands comes up as Aron’s simple things like that are irritating. Forces you to sign up for Amazon music due to not having some basic classics like Free Allright now in Prime and limited classical music in Prime. I found out the hard way that it does stay constantly on at times and if you set it for drop in don’t be surprised with what you get... being highly sensitive to sound and noise my hearing is superior to most people so it was very annoying to hear the constant hum of the speaker even when not in use. I’m not impressed by the features boring content who needs an app for making you feel good aka damn girl? It is good for daily weather (won’t give you long term forecast) limited news (hate fox had to change it who’s pocket are they in?) little tidbits are ok but I wanted a more intelligent conversation and can’t stand the female only voice either but that’s tolerable. All in all I have unplugged it to shut down the constant hum from the speaker the speaker itself is great very good quality sound and we do enjoy the music very much. Keep working on this Amazon you’ll improve hopefully it was worth the price on Prime day.

reviews.reviewTitle: Some major improvements over 2nd generation, but Alexa is a bit hard of hearing!
reviews.reviewText:
There are some major improvements to the 3rd generation echo dot as compared to the 2nd, first off, it looks a lot less like something that would be on the ice at an NHL game, not that hockey pucks are necessarily a bad thing, but the 1st and 2nd generation dots just looked cheap. The 3rd generation has a smoother, more curved shape, with MUCH more attractive cloth covering that resembles speaker cloth.

The sound quality compared to earlier models is substantially better. Mind you it's still a tiny little speaker that lacks the physical capacity to really pound out great sound, but for casual ambiance listeneing and voice it is beyond ideal. If you expect more out of a speaker this small, you need to readjust your expectations, it really does sound great considering its size. You want better? Buy an echo input and set up a Bose L1. It will be a TON bigger, but you will have fantastic sound!

Now we run into problems, and they are no small problems. My wife uses the dot to play music through the living room, dining room, and kitchen as she goes around the house, and keeps it cranked up. But the microphones can't hear over the sound of the music, so I have to SHOUT at Alexa to turn down the volume... Even at no music being played, it just doesn't pick up as well as my 2nd gen echo dots.. This is a HUGE operability problem,

My other complaint with it is that they changed the power input from USB to one of those round input things. Probably necessary for the added power, but it makes getting power to it less flexible, and the plug part is REALLY chunky on a standard wall outlet. Kind of annoying.

Lastly I purchased this hoping to get Alexa Guard integration, still not available to me for some reason. Amazon is taking forever getting Alexa Guard set up. I am hoping that they work a deal with ADT to monitor Alexa Guard with ADT SmartThings and not just Pulse once Alexa Guard is setup for everyone...

Overall I like it, but the items mentioned above are genuinely annoying.

I bought a total of four dots recently. I originally bought two black dots and was over the moon with them so I immediately hopped back on to Amazon and tried to buy two more but all they had left at the time was the white version. I figured the only difference was the color. I was wrong...and the white ones are AWFUL.
I have to unplug and restart them every other day because Alexa will say "I'm having a hard time understanding please try later" when we go to use her. We unplug and replug the dot back and she starts working again. until 36-48 hours later when we have to do it again. I have not had to do this with the black version to date (I purchased them on Prime day 2019). Then there is the volume issue with the white ones... If you want to use the "drop in" feature you must have the volume up all the way and the other person still comes through like a whisper. So when you go to play music or listen to an audio book you get blasted. Again, I have do not have this issue with the black dots. The main reason I bought the additional dots was for this issue. I have three kids and we live in a 4400 sq foot home that doesn't have an intercom system. I figured have four dots (and I had purchased an Echo the year before) would cut down on the yelling in the house.
I basically have two great dots and two white paperweights.

reviews.reviewTitle: A helpful device with potential to be even more useful
reviews.reviewText:
First, the third-generation Echo Dot itself, as a device: very good. The main disappointment is the sound quality. It's got more base than our second-generation Dot, but tends to sound more muffled.

Second, the Alexa app, as used on my fifth-generation Kindle: slow and somewhat clunky, although with patience it finally got our Dots connected to the Internet. (And, no, my Kindle is not overloaded with games and junk files.) A comprehensive set of printed directions — with mention of what needs to be done, what to expect, how to deal with problems that can crop up — would better serve Amazon customers than an oh, so brief and wafer thin package insert.

Third, functionality as a communications device: I hope it will become possible to use our Dots as intercoms, not just for "dropping in" to listen to a particular Dot in a particular room, not just to broadcast an announcement to all household Dots that are online. As in "Alexa, intercom to rec room." Alex responds, "Intercom to rec room set." I then say the intercom activation command at my end, which is the room name instead of Alexa, "Rec room, at what time are we going out?" The person in the rec room responds, "Kitchen, let's leave at 5:45." To end this exchange I say, "Alexa, stop intercom."
If there's some way to do this already, I would like to find out how it's done. Maybe, eventually, in a comprehensive user guide that comes in the box.

This works just like any other Alexa type device and does an OK job of not knowing what you're talking about unless it's weather or music, but we're all pretty used to that. The three star rating is for the speaker. It sounds terrible. My daughter has a similar one and it too sounds horrible The speaker is muffled and has no high frequencies. I've asked Alexa to "Turn up the treble" and "Turn down the Bass" and she appears to do it. Doesn't help a bit.
To get an idea of how the speaker may sound if you are thinking of buying one, remove a mono speaker from an old pickup truck (something from the early 60s), hook up some wires from a cheap stereo, wrap it up tightly in a small towel, insert the speaker and towel in a large Ziploc bag, and drop the entire thing into a 5 gallon bucket of water. Note that the truck speaker will sound slightly better but you'll get the idea. The strange thing is the Echo's speaker actually will sound decent if you hold it in your hand with the bottom facing out. This doesn't work if you place it upside down on a surface (I tried all sorts of different surfaces), only if you hold it in your hand. If you just want to hear Alexa's voice the built in speaker will suffice. But if you would like to listen to music on your Echo you should order an external speaker to go with it or prepare to be disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: This 3rd gen Echo Dot is better for music
reviews.reviewText: Compared to the 2rd gen Echo Dot, playback on this 3rd gen Echo Dot has a fuller sound with more bass. But voice intelligibility isn't as good as the 2nd gen, IMO. 3rd gen seems optimized for music playback, 2nd gen better for common Alexa voice interaction. 2nd gen uses USB (5V) for power, 3rd gen uses AC power adapter (12V).
