The stereo pair configuration is a useful new Alexa option which can work on both 2nd and 3rd gen Echo Dot for music playback. I had trouble at first configuring them for stereo pair or multiroom sound. Even though the two 3rd gen Echo Dots were both on the same network, I kept getting Network Connectivity error. I could check one, but immediately the other would show an exclamation mark on Alexa's app. The problem was a setting on my Wireless router. I had "Set AP Enabled" to Off, but I had to change it to On. On allows client devices on my Wireless network to communicate with each other. I was then able to create a stereo pair.

I recently purchased a smart thermostat that came with Alexa integration. Before long, I was thinking of adding an echo dot in the basement where we watch TV/movies. When I saw a promotion, I jumped on it. This device has moved the convenience of the internet from my fingertips to within earshot. This is not a hi-fi device by any stretch of imagination, but has decent enough sound for me to bring it in the workshop and play music occasionally. One possible negative: I had to experiment with the device location, maybe the microphones are too sensitive. The thermostat with Alexa is located on the main floor, close to the staircase. At first I apparently placed it too close to the stairwell in the basement, without realizing. I would query the thermostat and the dot in the basement would respond. After a moment, Alexa in the thermostat apologized that she was having trouble connecting, etc. On that topic, I do have a wi-fi repeater in the house so I can't speak for the signal coverage the unit gets. I am finding myself using Alexa more and more, for reminders, to-do list, calendar, news brief and sports. I am impressed with the ability to speak from across the room where the dot is, and it responds correctly. The thermostat's microphone is not that sensitive, in comparison.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works Well For Even Non-Tech Savvy Parents
reviews.reviewText:
I picked this up because the timer on my mother’s stove was too quiet for her to hear and the last timer I got her broke right away. I figured forget it, I’ll get her an echo since she could use it for music too.

Now my parents are older and not tech savvy in the slightest. They live pretty simply, so I wasn’t sure they’d use this at all. I am surprised to find that they really are enjoying it so far though, and besides calling it Alexus all the time for a while, they’re actually getting a good bit of use out of it right away. They like it for the fact it can play local radio stations clearly that they enjoy, which signal in our area (western PA, very hilly) is bad, and so for that reason and the timer alone was worth the price.

My folks have used it for reminders too, which is good for them for their meds and remembering appointments.

I’m going to wire it into the thermostat for them at some point and some smart bulbs too so they can get some more use from it.

So far I’m pretty impressed with the Echo, but also the fact my parents have basically figured it out on their own with minimal input from me. I mean my old man calls the Internet the “dubya dubya dubya thing”.

I’m also thinking come closer the holidays I’ll get some more for them for in other rooms and out in the shop/garage too.

reviews.reviewTitle: As useless as tests on a Boar Hog
reviews.reviewText:
It always gets things wrong, Alexa " play Witch of the West Moorland by Stan Rogers" it played it once the second generation dots play it. What do I get from the latest and greatest? " I can't find that." I ask for Hank Williams I'm so lonesome I could cry and I get "Move it On Over" 3 trys and I finally get the right song
It recommends the Beatles as a station I might like when I am listening to old time country gospel and bluegrass.
Save your money and get a 2nd gen while they are around. They sound great but not worth the aggravation.

Update after doing simple commands in skills since I bought it. I have to fight to hear not current top 40 or Josh Brogan instead of the preform I wish to hear and Alexa continuing with the performer I don't wish to hear. I have given up and use my CDs or IPod and good power speakers on the night stand. The only reason I haven't used my 8 units as skeet or trap targets is, if I get hurt I can use them to call 911.

Games sometimes go okay, except, Jeopardy I can say "Treaty of Paris" and Alexa goes "No, Treaty of Paris." Other skills it may or my not do okay. Over all I give Alexa minus -5 Stars good try but it should be still on the Developer's Bench. If this is the future of AI they won't kill us just drive us insane. By the way Amazon we should be able to leave no stars if the product deserves it and Alexa deserves negative stars in my opinion. no

reviews.reviewTitle: Louder than previous versions, but not necessarily better quality
reviews.reviewText:
I have had one of the previous generation Echo Dots for the better part of 2 years. I love them, they make turning on and off smart devices a snap. I have fans and lights setup so I can just walk into the house and "Alexa, turn on the living room" and poof, lights, fan, etc.

But the previous versions of the Echo Dot had rather subdued, yet CLEAR audio. It wasn't as loud as the new generation and lacked bass almost entirely, but was perfectly clear. My new 3rd generation Echo Dot has so much bass, even AFTER opening the Alexa app on my phone and turning DOWN the bass and mid-bass in the equalizer settings, that it's kind of annoying.

Before, on previous generations of the Dot, Alexa sounded clear, and clean. Now, her voice tends to vibrate the top of my PC where she's sitting, even with all the bass options turned off and volume at 40 percent. I've read a number of posts online about other people where they said that their new 3rd Gen dots sounded muffled or too bassy, and I have to agree. I'd almost like to turn in my 3rd Gen dot for a previous gen, simply because the VOICE sound quality used to be better. Now with all this extra bass, she sounds muddled. Treble turned up, mid-bass, and bass turned all the way off, and she sounds... weird.

Maybe Amazon can fix this in an update? Give us more than a 3-bar equalizer so I can make more adjustments to sound and maybe then I can fix it.

reviews.reviewTitle: They still have some work to do with the Echo
reviews.reviewText: Ok I got the echo basically because I wanted to control my Amazon Fire TV. I attempted to set it up and downloaded the Alexa app to my iphone 6. It seemed to initially be going well until I tried to pair it, and pair it, and pair it! I gave up and contacted tech support. They went thru the same things I did many times, redoing the setup. After several hours without pairing, they had to contact their tech support. Finally after 9pm I get another call from tech support and they asked me to access the app via my Ipad instead of Iphone. Doing this, it paired just find. For some reason my Iphone 6 didnt connect it. Dont know why, dont care, at least we got that far. Then they ran me thru some simple tests...Alexa turn off the tv...lol nope, didnt respond. Alexa turn on the tv, nope. Alexa open Netflix, nope. Alexa whats the weather ? wow , now yes she answered correctly. Anyway, at one point a tech told me I would need a smart plug to make it work..ok got a smart plug and no, didnt work. So, long story short, Im using the Echo for its general uses, not for a Firetv connection. I do like it, but it doesnt do what I originally wanted it for. Still Im 65, and its kind of cool. Im sure the grandkids will know more about it than Ill ever know.

reviews.reviewTitle: Difficult setup, needless other app required for any use
reviews.reviewText:
Requires Dot app that doesn't work. I thought this was somewhat independent.. but requires an app that is apparently unsupported.

Update, I called support but wasn’t able to get through in a timely manner. They contacted me the next day. I ultimately got through the setup without their help.

reviews.reviewTitle: Can Amazon just, please, fix it!
reviews.reviewText:
Update: I have reduced this to 1 star. I got a phone call that sounded like something was going to happen, but nothing did. I've waited a week. Time to get my money back.
I want to give this a good review. I have purchased so many Echo devices for myself and friends and family, I am obviously a fan. I have 7 active and 3 inactive devices in my house right now, plus Kindles everywhere! However, this one has a problem I cannot get resolved. When I drop in to chat with someone the speaker on the Dot fails after 5 minutes. I can no longer hear the other person, but they can hear me. I've explained this to customer service, but they just don't seem to understand what is wrong and have asked me 3 times now to do the same things which do not fix the issue. I have spent at least 3 hours with them and at this point I just don't want it anymore.
I'm still waiting for them to call back and, probably, ask me to do the same things again. I'm over it. I don't want to help Amazon fix their stuff for hours. I'm beginning to think I backed the wrong dog in the AI race.
I hope I get to update this with an "exceeded expectations" report, but my guess is I'll be lucky to have anyone even meet my expectations: Fix the damn thing!

reviews.reviewTitle: Power Connector is different from Generation 2
reviews.reviewText: Typical Echo Dot. Looks cool and sounds great. Unfortunately this generation 3 uses a different power connector. Prior generations used a Micro USB and I need to use a much shorter power cord connected to a Din Rail power supply. Any idea what voltage and exactly what type of power plug these new devices use?? I can figure it out on my own but if somebody already has this info, you'll save me some research time. This generation uses a push in round power connector. --Greg--

Update:
I wish I had never upgraded to the latest (3rd) generation! The device drives me crazy. I constantly have to yell at it to get any response, and that's after they replaced the original, so evidently it's not just a flaw in a particular device. The old 2nd generation on the opposite end of the house on a different floor hears and responds before the one I'm standing beside. Sometimes, she will initially respond (after some yelling), like when I tell her to stop the music, but then when I walk away, it starts again. Sometimes the blue light will spin and she may even say "okay" but then not follow the command. It's like Siri (dumb) with attitude. The improved speakers are not worth the aggravation. I'm sure my neighbors don't appreciate the yelling either. I'd give it 0 stars, but it does have much better speakers and I loved the 2nd generation. This one is a lot of frustration.

Original Review: I was skeptical about replacing a working prior generation, but WOW--the speakers in this version are SOOO MUCH BETTER! I actually heard it the other day with it in my bedroom upstairs and me in the car, all windows closed! The only problem is that I often have to yell at it repeatedly to get it "to pay attention to me." (That's why it was on while I was in the car--it had not turned off when I told it to do so.) This isn't just when it's at maximum volume, wasn't an issue with the last version, and I have a very loud, strong voice. Sometimes, she doesn't understand basic questions, even about Amazon topics, but her comprehension is far superior to Siri. Changes I'd like to see that could be pushed in firmware include being able to change the name to whatever I want and having a male voice.

I wanted to try this because it’s suppose to understand you better, and a better speaker would be nice. Well, it hears a little better, but still misunderstands a lot, for more than I’d expect from the richest man in the world. The sound is full, but it’s a little too full for the voice coming out of it. There’s just something we don’t like about it, but we can’t put our finger on it. We also weren’t happy that the new speaker design can hide the LED ring a little and it kind of makes it look like it’s gained weight. I like the sleekness of the 2nd gen. But music does sound better. I was hoping to replace some key Alexa’s in my house, but in decided to just stick with one. It’s an upgrade I guess, but not as good as I hoped. Maybe you’ll have a different experience, as I am in a vaulted-ceiling room. But come on, you know Bezos has vaulted ceilings somewhere. Imagine being that rich. Wow. But I digresss.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Voice Recognition & Highly Impressed By Its Sound
reviews.reviewText:
I went into this solely for the smart functionality, but ended up blown away by how capable of a speaker this is for music at this footprint. I wouldn't put it above the Anker Premium Speaker, but the convenience of an always on hands free smart speaker with above average sound...great versatility.

I already had 2 Insignia smart plugs synced to the Amazon ecosystem via the firestick remote and alexa app, so those played well with the Dot right out the box. Nice to have them hands free now. The functionality that was new to me was the integration with Verizon Fios. I expected the skill to be half baked or sluggish but you can really lose your cable remote and not care. "Alexa, switch to Fox Sports 1 (ESPN, ABC, NBC, etc.)". "Alexa, pause (resume, fast forward)". The Dot's voice recognition is very consistent which means all of this so seamless. This is a really great device.

Compared to the old one this thing looks sophisticated....not like a hockey puck. The sound is so much better than the old one. In fact I have my old dot on a little shelf you can buy that attaches to your wall outlet. Its so nice to hear the news or music while shaving/dressing showering. But the older echo sounded pretty crappy even in the bathroom. This one sounds GREAT. I mean it wont replace it taller older brother but the sound is commendable.

Here is my problem. The old one had a cord that pugged into the echo on one end and plugged into the plug on the other. You were thus able to get a real short (3") cord to use when you put the dot on it's little shelf attached to the wall outlet.

The new one, in all its glory is very difficult to put on the little shelf. The wire is part of the plug an cannot be replaced with a shorter cable. Maybe eventually a shortie plug will be sold but for now I have this great looking echo sitting in front of a bunch up cord...it does not look so great...hope it's safe to have the cord continually bound up too!

There are hundreds of reviews for this version so I won't just repeat the obvious or gush about how it is the best thing that ever happened to my life. I'm just going to say a couple of things that aren't usually mentioned.

One is why I replaced my old original Dot. She was going deaf. I have several Dots but for some reason the one on my kitchen counter was having trouble hearing me, she would either ignore me or keep saying she didn't understand me. I finally figured out that all of the microphones are tiny holes on top of the device and just like an old man's ears they would clog up with dust and kitchen grease and gunk to the point I had to get a divorce - um, from her - and look for a younger model.

My new model is more attractive and curvy and sensuous and speaks in a low sultry voice. And that's actually not good. One of the brilliant things about the original design was that Alexa's voice was sharp and shrill and could cut through the commotion of household noise. My new Alexa by comparison sounds muffled, like she has a paper bag over her head. She can hear me fine, better than the old model, but now I can't understand her.

Comparing the white color to the first generation there are pros and cons. First off the new generation is all white with a white cord and white power supply. The original had a white body but the top, cord and transformer were all black. I have mixed feeling about that. It does look more contemporary but the mesh side and matte finish on top show dust and fingerprints much more than the older model and already after a few days it is looking a bit dingy. And as much as I like the new power cord the transformer is substantially larger, it actually prevents me from using the outlets on either side of it on my power strip.

One final thing, you would think with all the money and time spent on developing this product they could have figured out how not to make the two jacks on the back identical in size and shape. The original model had a mini USB power port, the new one has a small round connector that looks just like an audio jack. The user shouldn't be forced to think about which one is the power port and which is the external speaker port.

reviews.reviewTitle: An amendment to my earlier review. Re. Home Automation.
reviews.reviewText:
I alternate between being awestruck and total frustration. It depends on hat you wish to do.

I have to admit I find the technology to be very interesting. The book I read on it led me to believe that I had to go through some sort of Voice Training exercise to get this to recognize and respond to my voice. I found his not to be the case as both me and my wife no had difficulty in communicating with her. She seems to have quite a range of things that she can answer and I often find myself thanking her and later realizing she probably doesn't care.

Some very pleasant surprises like the fact that I can tell her a word and she can give me the proper spelling, very handy for one who cannot spell worth a hoot. Weather reports, major events, time of day, setting alarms and timers are among the many useful things she can do. Got a song you like or want to hear a joke she can do that. She takes the moral high ground so don't ask for anything X Rated. It is truly impressive what she can do!

But there is a down side to this. Many of these issues may have solutions however you will need to be much sharper than this old duck.

My first concern is for security. It is a well known fact that she will occasionally get initiated for no apparent reason. Then there is the fact that I wanted to get local traffic information so I gave here my location and Cell Phone number. I was taken back to find that she had ingested all my contact information without asking! I am not sure where Alexa stores her scripts however I would not be surprised to find it on the Cloud some place (for my money nothing there is secure!).

But since it is such a neat deal we sorta glance the other way and overlook many of those issues. My next great heartbreak is when we decide to utilize it as the Voice Interface for some home automation. I have managed to get a few things to respond to my voice commands however this road is long and filled with many potholes.

Our first pothole came when I was trying to install the Alexa Software. Originally I had intended to install it on my iMac however I could not get the software to install. I was able to get some assistance and the first thing the man told me was to install it on my iPad (I would be willing to bet there are some issues with the Mac version). We began that process and immediately ran into problems. I have to own up to not checking out the router settings as it will not install on anything other than the 2.4 g router setting. Once we switched the router the installation went rather smoothly.

We began our home automation adventure with the Starter Kit from Sengled. It is a very good deal with a couple of lights and and Bridge. However there were some installation and compatibility issues. A common thread with most of this Home Automation stuff is that it is not very intuitive and there are no help options in the software. The bridge will allow you to add quite a few lights however they get pretty pricey (this is where they catch up). Now if you think there is any compatibility among the different manufacturers you have another thing coming.

Bought some other wifi enabled lights and found I needed to install another app! At last count I have eight different apps running in my home automation group on my I pad.

Wireless things that were already on line don't appear to be discoverable and this is also an issue.

Now we have something that was intended to tie all this stuff together however this also seems to be a bit of a train wreck. It is called IFTTT and it was suppose to allow all these different devices to work together. I have been able to use a few of these widgets however I find myself powerless to deal with them. The Alexa Software says that some of them are there however I have little control over when and how they execute! You are suppose to be able to script them and have multiple widgets run from a simple voice command however it looks like this may require another app and that may only run on my phone. There is little help available for IFTTT since it is suppose to be a no brainer (guess where that leaves me).

It appears that the Hype far exceeds the reality. This would make a fine hobby for some nerd however I find that fun just keeps coming.

There could be a few more stars available but some one will need to show me of that intuitive stuff they have been hiding.

An Update regarding home automation. It should be worth noting If you want to use Alexa fore home automation.

Saturday 27 July there was a wide spread internet outage that affected large parts of the Northwest. At first I did not think much about it until I began asking Alexa to do things. Her response was that there was a problem and I should go to the Help Menu in the Alexa app. The did not work as did any of the items I wished to control through Alexa.

If you loose your internet connection Alexa will cease to function. She will direct you to the help menu in the Alexa App. So if you suffer frequent outages this may not be the home automation app for you!

reviews.reviewTitle: Simply refuse to stay connected and play music
reviews.reviewText:
Amazon won't allow pasting my same comments so rather than repeat my 3 of 4 paragraphs check my review on the Echo 2 (Sub Pair.)

Devices continually drop connection to each other and the internet. I have 9 different speakers and problems with all groups and all speakers at times. I've reset, I've deleted and recreated groups and I've reset pairs many times. But after 3 or 4 songs I ALWAYS lose a speaker or a pair or a couple of pairs.

The app is also painfully lacking. A secind rate attempt at best. I'm very disappointed.

I will admit that after my 1st poor review I recueved a call and email from Amazon. But their only advice was to try the things I'd already done. Rest devices. Delete and recreate groups and pairs. Just doesn't work.

And if this was a wifi problem why does my phone Bluetooth connected to either my Bose Mini or HK Onyx 2 play perfectly fine fir hours on end..?

reviews.reviewTitle: I was pretty adament about not buying one... now I am glad I did...
reviews.reviewText:
To be honest, I was originally against such a device in the house and not for all those conspiracy theory things. I just don't like things around me that are not tools when I am working. Still, I bought this as a package deal with something else during Amazon Prime Days. It was cheaper than the other thing alone. But I was curious, so before even setting up the other thing, I had plugged in Alexa. Reviews I had seen had me expecting generally low quality sound and issues with voice recognition. So far it has shocked me. I wouldn't use it for a party speaker, but for just background music it has a good amount of bass and a well-rounded sound. So far it has not had issues with voice commands except for things it simply cannot do.

In things I do not like I can easily list one I do not think Amazon will easily be able to fix: The limitation of the "Wake Words" that are allowed, Alexa, Echo, Computer, or Amazon. Obviously the third word is out of the question since it is too easy to come up in conversation. The same is true for the second and fourth words, but not so frequent. That leaves Alexa. Oh well. Thankfully, it does not easily respond to television sent commands like has been joked about, so at least it won't start playing music I don't ask for just because I have the TV on.

Highly enjoyable despite my reservations.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bluetooth connectivity is terrible, look elsewhere for a speaker.
reviews.reviewText:
Great sound quality once you get into the Alexa app and increase the bass. The microphone picks up me saying the wake word all the way across my home, even in separate rooms. Features and skills are great. The Bluetooth connectivity, however, is dismal. I have owned it for less than 24 hours and have had to reset the Bluetooth connection dozens of times, and it doesn't just drop the connection, it just loses audio and you actually have to disconnect and reconnect to get it back. My $5 Family Dollar speaker is 100 times more stable and has only ever lost the connection once in 4 months. I only bought this because it was on sale and I needed a new Bluetooth speaker and thought that the additional features would be a benefit. I really regret it. Unless Amazon can fix this, you're better off buying something else if you're looking for a Bluetooth speaker. I'm beyond disappointed and I hope Amazon can address this issue, otherwise I'll be returning it. Alexa features are not worth it if the rest of its performance is shoddy and unusable.

Update 8/8/19: Amazon replaced the first one and the second one does exactly the same thing. There is still no resolution and every time I call, they try to make me call in the 2 year warranty I purchased on a brand new product that has never worked properly. At least they gave me a partial refund.

I currently have an older generation Alexa dot in each of my children’s room. My son’s dot had stopped “listening,” to the point where I could hold it six inches from my mouth and it wouldn’t hear it. It would be nice to set the explicit level at each device versus globally.

It is bigger than the older dot. Instead of a usb cable and plug, it is now a regular plug with a barrel connected due to an increase in watts.

The time display is nice, especially with how often I find myself asking Alexa what time is it. I do wish it had a setting to turn completely off at set times (it does an adaptive brightness depending on ambient light).

The voice detection is outstanding. From 10 feet away with music playing it detected “Alexa” even while playing music louder.

The sound has also improved, with much more low end oomph.

I did order it to be already attached to my account. This did not occur. However, this is the first Alexa out of 6 that I successfully used the iPhone app versus getting out the iPad.

I would have preferred a different color. It is a nice color.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fantastic Speaker, Research Shows Microphone Mute Does Work!
reviews.reviewText:
I'm someone who *loves* the convenience technology such as this provides, but I must admit to being a bit skeeved out by the potential for abuse that such a device poses. While Amazon may not have any malevolent intent, the fact that a device, if in the wrong hands, can effectively serve as a cold-war era spy's dream bug in your house -- and one that you pay to have no less -- is disconcerting. However, research has shown that Amazon is being honest with respect to the mute button. Teardowns of the device show that when the mute button is applied, there is no voltage going across the microphone chip. This is very comforting, as there are certain times when having an "always listening" device isn't exactly an inviting thing to have in your home.

As far as acoustics go, this device is excellent. It's quite impressive how Amazon has been able to pack in such a fantastic and well-rounded speaker into such a relatively inexpensive device. It offers enough bass, mid-range, and high-end clarity to easily be able to enjoy music without wishing there was a better speaker lying around. And for that alone, I'm grateful.

reviews.reviewTitle: It works like any Alexa if you can get it set up
reviews.reviewText:
It comes with a fold-out with six steps for setup. One of the mandatory steps is to download the Alexa app onto one of your phones. Android, iOS, and Fire are all supported.

I didn't exactly want to do this, because the app then asks to read all kinds of information from your phone and send to Amazon. I don't really want it to know every person I've ever gotten a phone number from, most of whom I don't call. If I want to talk to someone through Dot -- a big IF -- I just add the number. That's like three people tops.

Continuing ...

One step is to connect to Dot via its WiFi network. It would then use your phone to set it up.

On my Android phone, the wireless network has no internet connection, so the first couple of times it dropped. I eventually got this straightened out, but after it connects the app is supposed to allow you to set up the device instead of not respond. Once I got stuck, I'd have to start over from the top, disconnecting power to Dot and repeating the entire process.

Next I tried to do it via my iMac. There is a web portal to connect to. Clicking on a few buttons, you navigate the same place as the app on Android. The UI is the same, only much bigger. At this point, as with the phone you have to connect to Dot's WiFi network.

I got farther here. I choose a WiFi network for Dot to connect to. And then I click submit. The website unfailingly reports a expired authentication or some such error. Again to retry, you'd have to unpower Dot and repower it.

After giving this nearly ten tries. I gave up.

Good think I have an iPad. It connected and went through on the second try. The app on the iPad crashed the first time.

On paper -- literally on the leaflet -- setup takes five steps. In practice, I have to count all of the times those five steps didn't work, so sixty. If some of the steps are so big that they fail frequently, perhaps they should have split those steps into smaller more reliable ones.

For comparison, I set up my WiFi AP not long ago. You've seen the configuration screens for these things. They're quite complicated. I recalled that it took fewer than 60 steps and less than 1 hour.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not as good as Gen 2 overall due to random connectivity loss
reviews.reviewText:
Would NOT buy again! I bought two (Gen3) Dots and both of them lose connection often. All my Gen 2's do not have this issue. The sound is a "little" better on the Gen3 but that is about the only thing positive I can say regarding the difference on the latest model. NOT a value at the 49.99 regular price at all! I would buy another Gen 2 honestly before I would get a sen 3...thinking about giving them away to the trash collector.

Update 02/10/19:
Going back to a rare one star review! Connectivity loss daily in both the Gen 3's I recently purchased. ALL my Gen 2's are still connecting fine and they, after numerous comparisons, sound better, listen better and in my opinion look better. (Yes, I have eliminated any wifi/bluetooth interferences from the area of the Gen 3's) They simply ARE NOT AS GOOD as Gen 2's...shame on Amazon for selling cheaper tech like this!

I purchased the Echo Dot in March 2019. It worked well for a few weeks then the sound started to degrade. Alexa's voice and any music playing sounded fuzzy and distorted - similar to radio static when a station is not tuned in properly. I tried all the recommended solutions: factory reset of the device, un-registering and re-registering it, resetting my router, downloading the latest software, etc. Nothing worked. At first I thought that maybe the speaker was blown - but sometimes the sound was restored for short periods. I contacted Amazon customer service and they walked me through all of the above mentioned solutions again with no success. The most frustrating part of this adventure is that they notified me that the device was out of warranty. I was expecting them to at least exchange the device for a new functioning one. I expected that it would be warranted for a year minimally. But unfortunately that is not the case, They did offer me a discount on ordering a new device though. TO be fair the Echo Dot is a great little device when it is working. The fact that I received a lemon, combined with a poor warranty policy explains my one-star rating.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very useful piece of technology, and a lot of fun.
reviews.reviewText: I am really enjoying this new piece of technology and was glad I only paid $ 20.00 for it when it came down in price as well as on a gift card that I build up the value on in another program, which essentially made this Echo Dot free to me. I have a plug in that I plug into my lamp and have it setup to turn on and shut off by voice or can set a schedule for waking me up in the morning when I go to work. Also works great when I ask Alexa the time or weather or flash briefing or anything else I want to know. It can also play music from other apps including Amazon Music (which I don't have) but there are other free options other than Amazon Music like TuneIn Radio. I tried to make a phone call to my cell phone, but it did not work. I had my phone in front of me when I called me cell phone. It did not ring the cell phone, but it did leave a message. To avoid having Alexa calling and leaving messages to your contacts, I just put the Alexa app on my tablet that has no contacts on it. I am sure I will find more uses for it when I move out of my current living situation. As I was making this video, Alexa turned on and off my light as I was replaying my video back on my phone. A very enjoyable toy and newly piece of technology for me and I really love it. That is why I am giving this a 5 star rating. I am sure you will all enjoy it as much as I do. If I could add something to this Echo Dot, I would give Echo Dot the ability to upload an alarm sound from my tablet to my Echo Dot for my morning alarm like Star Trek Red Alert, because I am not happy with what few alarms you can use for a morning wake up alarm.

reviews.reviewTitle: I can't believe I waited so long to have one of these
reviews.reviewText: This little gadget is amazing! I'm still learning about the things you can do with this, but so far it's just so much fun and practical. I have one in my living room and one in my bedroom (2nd Gen). I did noticed that the microphone capabilities of the 3rd Gen are not as precise as the 2nd Gen. I think my 2nd Gen picks up the sound of my voice much better and the speakers sound louder. However, the 3rd Gen speakers sound fills the room more (if that makes sense). The tasks, reminders, alarms and communication features are awesome. I don't have a telephone in my house and this device is my new phone. My son calls my phone when he gets home from school through the Echo and I also call him whenever I want using the drop-in feature. I also love my night and morning routine and the sleep sounds options... they help me start my day in a good mood and go to sleep relax. Overall, it's a great investment!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use and get used to having around.
reviews.reviewText: First of all, I bought 5 of these little assistants. They are wonderful and I find new capabilities every day. Sometimes by accident. They are easy to set up if you follow directions. I set up mine from an Apple laptop because my iPhone 5 is not compatible. Once I figured that out, it was easy. Once you set up a "dot" you can unplug and move anywhere you would like one. I have one upstairs (bedrooms), two on the main level (kitchen, family room) and two downstairs (den, bar). So I'm covered no matter where I am in the house. Its function as a timer is great. From pill-taking to wound dressing to cooking all you have to do is ask. Music is everywhere - one dot or all dots - your choice. Extremely good quality as I walk around the house. You can ask a million questions and get an answer immediately. Unlike Siri, Alexa has no sense of humor at all. Ask her a silly question and she will ignore you. Smart approach I guess. I just wish I had enough time to learn to use more features. The next function will be to integrate with "Ring" security systems and integrate with my thermostats so I don't have to do up and downstairs to reset them. All in all, "Dot" is an 11 out of 10 (not a typo). BUY them, don't hesitate.

well hmm i said i would never have one of these or any other like listening device in our house and yet here i am reviewing one we got!! i wouldn't of ordered one myself before, this one came as a free add-on with the ring alarm system kit we bought on here and i honestly had no plan on using the echo 3 and was going to give it away but, curiosity got the best of me and well it only took a day to get hooked on this awesome no-hands device after trying it out. not having to stop doing what i am doing to go turn on music and skip songs or not having to remember to later write something down to buy on a list and just ask alexa to order it has been great since i forget to write things on a list later on 75% of the time. I haven't played around with everything this does, not really into all that game play/etc with alexa stuff. The music, shopping list/cart and phone messaging is all i care about really (am looking at them plugs to turn thing on & off with alexa too now) and there are some issues like everytime i say order/buy something, it gets added to cart and am told to go there instead of alexa ordering/checking out even though one click and all is turned on.. also we first set this up on my ipad and needed a phone number to set up a part in app, being new to this, we didn't realize it would become that ipad's phone number for messages/etc.. and installing app on phone afterwards resulted in us not being able to set up communication on it because cell phone number was already being used by ipad -

anyhow sure others already described everything about this echo 3. i like it, music sounds great to me on it (although not older music) and i can unplug it anytime i want and it easily reconnects by itself within a minute when i plug it back in. i don't bother with that part anymore since i keep it in kitchen corner but, it is nice to know i can unplug it and not have to redo setup when i decide to get more echo's for other areas of our house.

i will say i was suprise at how far/well this echo 3 can hear us, i told alexa to shut off when i was in opposite side of house in living room to see if alexa/echo could hear us there and yup she heard me.. will admit at first that bothered me but, now not so much.

reviews.reviewTitle: Alexa, please write a review for me
reviews.reviewText: I already had a 2nd generation Echo Dot, an Echo Auto and the Alexa app on my laptop. When I plugged in the new Echo, it instantly synced and did everything I needed on its own. I honestly can't remember how difficult it was to set up my first Echo, but I know it wasn't a challenge. The third generation of Echo is really much nicer looking than the second generation. The sound quality is dramatically better. It unobtrusively sits in the living room without looking out of place. It responds really quick to commands. I will probably get a few more to add throughout the house and will simply replace my second generation unit. I'm continually adding skills and find life is much simpler with Alexa around. When Alexa is added to my refrigerator, washer and dryer, and many other appliances, and Amazon grocery arrives in my neighborhood, my life will be fulfilled. I can ask Alexa to microwave my popcorn on my Amazon microwave and ask my refrigerator to reorder milk. The day is coming and i will happily embrace living in an Amazon home. I'm still waiting for Amazon cellular service and an Amazon car. (Hint-hint there, Amazon!) Imagine if we could only have one bill a month for EVERYTHING we need! Ok, yeah, I might be dreaming. But with gadgets as awesome as the third generation of Echo Dot, I think Amazon could make it a reality!

reviews.reviewTitle: It's a nice start, may work well someday.
reviews.reviewText:
My real motivation to get the Dot was to create a connected music system. I have two of them, connected as a "group", each connected to Edifier 1200T powered speaker systems, which are in turn powered by Dot controlled outlets. The quality of sound now is far higher than the little bluetooth speakers, even though I have a couple of nice ones.

The system Will consistently will turn on both outlets by automated "routines" or on command when calling for my "upstairs group", it won't though consistently execute my routine to play music on that group, but often only starts one set of speakers (we typically have well over 20 Mps internet). We don't typically walk around the house shouting commands at each other, so the voice interface is unnatural. I had hoped that the Alexa app might be useful for things like searching for music, but it doesn't have a search function besides again shouting commands it doesn't understand anyway.

One of the most irritating things is that if it does start music, it may play 3 or 4 songs but then just stops. This is NOT an intelligent system, but rather a command line interface. It only understands exact pre-programmed instructions and figures nothing out based on AI. The voice command system is largely an exercise in futility as a search system, and Amazon's song selection and list creation isn't that great (and yes I'm a premium music subscriber). You can ask it to bring up your Pandora or Spotify lists, but adding longer strings of commands that way, then trying to get it to remember to play on both members of the group? No.

If I do get the music group going, you can't ask it to change stations without losing one room or the other. It frequently loses one room or the other, although the laggard will generally come back with the next song.

So it is a nice gee wiz, and yes, I can sometimes get it to play the music I want in two rooms simultaneously. I like that my phone isn't tied up by a bluetooth connection, but frankly, my net result is generally better with bluetooth. I guess I should have sprung for a Sonos system, although that was going to be a lot more money.

Bottom line, I'm suffering from buyers remorse. I have nice sound systems in two rooms. I can't say that I have a multi room setup.

reviews.reviewTitle: So far, having fun, sound a touch muffled, Android app is battery drainer
reviews.reviewText:
Finding new things to do with it each day - Alarms and multiple Timers at once, Reminders like "Alexa, set reminder for lunch at noon on Sunday", 'she' repeats it back and at noon on Sunday, 'she' tells you, Audible books (subscription) which pick up where you left off, Shopping list (shows up on Alexa app on phone), White noise machine at night (lots of free Rain, Thunderstorms, Crackling fire, Ocean Waves, Wind, etc), Games (song trivia, regular trivia, Word of the Day, etc), Flash briefings (easier to set up on laptop than on phone app) which give you are run down of quick news, or weather, or pop culture stuff - what ever you add to your Flash Briefing list, Entertainment (Music (lots free w/ Prime), Radio Mystery Theater, Choose your own Adventure books (interactive), look for new stuff each day.
The voice is bass heavy making it sound a bit muffled but that can be adjusted. You can also tell it to turn up or turn down - these commands are 10 level (out of I think 100) jumps, but buttons on device have smaller adjustments if just want to move a little (louder or softer) at least I think they do.
The Alexa app on Android phone (Galaxy 5 - older phone) doesn't seem fully functional and I ended up removed b/c it kept 'turning on' in background and draining my battery! BUT when it was on there, it was neat having my shopping list right there. I'd say Alexa (or you can use the name Echo, Computer, or Amazon - if you have more than one device, trust me - name them differently) "Add 2 dozen eggs to my shopping list", 'she' (the device voice), says "2 dozen eggs added to your shopping list". Sure enough, open app, and touch "shopping list" there it is. I was also able to dictate a phone number to it and 'she' called it (was a land line) - sounds on my end was good, but the person I was talking to, said it sounded slightly echo-ish.

We now have five Amazon Dots throughout the house, not counting the ones that belong to the kids. Not all are 3rd Gens (yet), I updated three with the new 3rd Gen. because the sound quality is so much better and I love the convenience of listening to my playlists and books on them. I think they also respond better. I am so spoiled by the benefits and features of this technology that I would hate to go back to life without it.

I start my day with a "good morning" to Alexa, which in turn usually gifts me with a laugh and/or a bit of trivia. After providing me with the weather and a little news I usually request a playlist to enjoy during the rest of my morning routine. My dots remind me of my appointments, to take the trash cans down to the street, to take my medication, and to pickup after the dogs before the yard service arrives. (these messages will also display on my cell phone and tablets) At the end of the day, after I'm in bed, I look forward to having "Alexa" turn my fan on and my light off. Then "Alexa," on one of my new 3rd Gens, plays my "bedtime" playlist until I fall asleep.
P.S. I'm 70 years old and wish the Amazon Dot would have been around 50 years ago.

reviews.reviewTitle: Blows the Older Dot Out of the Water
reviews.reviewText: I purchased my 3rd gen Dot from Target. I bought it on a whim not expecting much. I have a 2nd gen Dot in the garage hooked up to a speaker because of the weak sound. Boy was I surprised. Unlike the 2nd gen this bad boy has some serious volume coming out of it and it can actually produce music with sonic value. I was amazed at the sound and volume coming from this tiny speaker. It must think it is a Bose Speaker. I compared it to the Google version and there is no comparison. It now looks like a premium speaker too, also better looking than the Google unit. For a small speaker you can't do any better and the price is right on.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for kids, but it's useless for me as an adult.
reviews.reviewText:
I have owned an echo dot since December of 2017 and this one for over 6 months. Here is what I have experienced.

Pros
- games and stories for kids
- alarms
- apps to expand its capabilities
- music if you pay for prime
- it can answer a few questions
- works great in the kitchen

Cons
- it fails to answer 90% of basic questions
- the alarm fails to sound every once in a while
- it thinks you say it's name when you are talking to someone
- it frequently glitches out

It is good with entertaining kids with stories, games, and jokes. You can use it as a timer when it feels like working. Every once in a while the timer alarm won't go off, but that's rare.

Alexa is by far the dumbest voice assistant ever created. It's not meant to answer questions, it's better for entertainment. The alarm problem is a big issue, my fitbit is the backup because this fails so often. If I want it to play a song from my library I need to say artist and title or else it'll play something else. Some days it's not coherent and I need to unplug it, then plug it back in.

I called Amazon about the issues, they say reset it and also unplug it. That only works for a couple of days. They don't care, it has issues and they are too blind to see their failure to make a good device. Both of my echo dots have issues, this one is the better of the two. Overall this was a waste money. Amazon had a good idea and they assigned a bunch of idiots to make their dream a reality, thanks Amazon.

If you still want to buy this device I'll give you some tips. If you want it to stop glitching out unplug it for a minute once a week and reset it to factory condition once a month. It will touch out every once in a while, but not as much.

This is update since Amazon took off my negative review

the speaker blew out after 7 months and now it doesn't detect my voice as well as it used to. It is frustrating if I have to buy one every few months. The warranty is only 3 months so they must think it will only last that long.
It might be worth getting Google Home since the quality of the product seems to degrade over time.

Update:
Amazon called me to replace my product and they just made everything worse. They promised to replace my item and then did a bait and switch and tried to sell me the same product at 20% off. That's unethical.

1. Amazon called me to replace the product.
2. Amazon system went down and the representive couldn't replace my item. They made notes of our conversation and told me to call back.
3. The new rep who was an overseas customer service center read the notes and told me they couldn't replace my item...they only offered a discount.
4. I spent 2.5 hours with as they told me that they were unable to replce my item only to check their recorded calls and agree they had made a mistake

So basically they called me to tell me to replace my item only to keep me on the phone for 2.5 hours trying to sell me their defective product again. Instead of replacing a $30 device that cost $3 to make they just lost a loyal customer. That's bad basiness, I'll buy Google products instead

I purchased 3 Amazon Echo Dot 3rd gen to use as an intercom and for entertainment around my home and I noticed immediately the Echo Dot has severe Wi-Fi COMPATIBILITY issues that are not so beyond average consumers:

1) Wi-Fi support is advertised as 2.4 Ghz and 5 Ghz connectivity however the dot will not see 'AC' networks that I have set up. The 2.4 Ghz network still inadequate even though signal strength reports FULL. Checking Wi-Fi signal strength from the access point shows that the Echo Dot 3rd Gen has a signal quality of above 80% and even comparing superior, similar, and inferior devices with much lower signal strength and a much higher SNR (Signal to Noise Ratio) the Echo Dot is guaranteed to have issues. I am so astonished by the design of something that can't even stay connected as well as something with batteries!

2) The Echo Dot 3rd Generation does not have a "built-in" battery for a "lightweight speaker" and using the Alexa app for "setting it up" becomes a routine nuisance. It would be much better if voice prompts could be eliminated altogether and "maybe if it just had lights"... must be the ULTRA COOL THERMODYNAMIC DESIGN

It can definitely keep your beer cold!

We’ve had an Echo for a few years. Just one and it was the first that came out. Revisited the tech and updated this year. Added a smart plug, routines, reminders and bought three more dots when they went on sale for Black Friday. Two previous versions and this newer version. A few observations: 1) Sound is WAY better on the newer version. So much better that I wish I’d spent the extra $5 to get the other two newer versions. 2) Easier to connect than previous models 3) Looks nicer 4) picks up sound better and so far understands things said from a greater distance 5) the sound is better ... no matter how many reviews say it’s not, don’t believe it. It’s better. Wish I didn’t believe it and bought the newer models!
Voice commands. Love them! I come in and say, “Alexa- Start my day” I get my calendar read to me, weather, commute times, and my favorite music starts! The smart plug for lights was a good investment too.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great product, recommend everyone have one (or two).
reviews.reviewText:
Overall this is a great product. It works wonderfully for the purposes I need.
I love music so it suits me well to have a song pop into my head and be able to have alexa play it.
It is great for me as I am a heavy aleeper so the alarm and morning routine works amazingly.
I purchased two and put one in my children's room. It allows us to communicate without having to go back and forth across the house.
The announcements feature is amazing because it broadcasts announcements over all connected devices.
I have freetime enabled on my children's so they can request kid friendly music, set up routines, play games and even request bedtime stories.
We love it and will buy more to put throughout the rest of our home. We are also looking into getting more connected devices that are Alexa compatible.

Downfalls: sometimes when thr volume is high while plating music or reading a story, the echo dot has difficulty recognizing or even registering commands. Another thing is that the dot does SOOOO MUCH and I have no idea what it is fully capable of so I feel like I am not using it to its full potential. I wish thete were were more documentation in the box or a complete list of commands and capabilities.

reviews.reviewTitle: Quitting Alexa and Echo Auto - Here's Why.
reviews.reviewText:
We had two Dots in our home for 5 months, and used them daily.

After the new-toy play period wore off, they slowly dropped into mostly being glorified light switches and laundry timers. But took longer to use and were less reliable than actual light switches and just remembering when your laundry was done.

It turned into a case of "item designed for convenience becomes daily frustration". Most mornings this past month found me swearing at Alexa after telling her to stop my wakeup alarm for the third time. Or telling her, "We're leaving," so her Routine would turn off the lights and turn on the camera - and then repeating myself five times from two feet away as she insisted she couldn't understand.

For context - I'm a podcaster and theater trained, I know how to articulate and project.

The final nail in the coffin was getting an Echo Auto this week. You can't leave reviews on it yet, and not surprising. It's a barely functional mess. I returned it after a couple days of road testing.

If any kind of background noise is going on - music playing at reasonable levels, for instance - you have to get louder than the noise to wake Alexa. And then, whatever request you made, Echo Auto would pause 30-60 seconds to think it over, probably due to lag speed in connecting to the net.

In virtual assistants, that's an eternity, and makes you wonder if it heard you at all. When it did finally respond, it mostly got my requests wrong, or started to answer - and then cut off mid-sentence for no obvious reason.

Asking for directions was a joke. I tried asking about businesses I knew had multiple addresses, like gyms and restaurants. I'd say the entire address, and it would ask over and over if I meant some completely different address.

Suggestion to Amazon - you could've bypassed Echo Auto by making the Alexa app completely hands-free and voice-activated on all phones. No idea why hands-free is an option on Fire tablet but not on a cell phone.

Months of building frustration at all things Alexa finally made me pull the plug yesterday. I boxed up my Dots for sale. There's nothing they can do that other voice assistants can't do from a phone more reliably with fewer steps, including controlling my smart home.

Final note: quitting Alexa isn't easy. By which I mean, going back through all her settings to delete your activity history, voice recordings, disabling Skills one at a time to make sure your accounts aren't linked anymore, and finally Deregistering the devices. It took a couple hours of button mashing to make sure everything was wiped, and even then I don't think my actual account was wiped. There doesn't seem to be an option for that. There should be an easy, customer-friendly option to say, "I want out," and know that Amazon will delete everything and cancel your Alexa account.

It's very tempting to give this thing five stars, but there is room for improvement. That said, it is an amazing bit of technology, well worth more than the price. Amazon must have been swamped with orders for these things at Christmas as I see it looks like a little back-ordering is going on. And I understand! If I'd known how cool this was back when they had the 2nd Gen for $20 I'd have bought one for everyone on my shopping list.

Set up is easy, but you do need a phone or other device to set it up. After that, it's voice-activated astonishment. Ask for information about movies, the weather, history, solve math problems - it's all there for free. To fully enjoy the music you need Amazon Prime or Amazon Music, Pandora or similar. Over the holidays Echo kept us a steady supply of Christmas music - "Play Christmas piano music" - "Play Andy Williams Christmas music" - you get the idea.

I keep my 2nd Generation Echo Dot in the kitchen, which is great for setting multiple times, looking up recipes, cooking times, adding items to a shopping list (and you can create multiple lists). The lists are kept updated on your phone, so if my wife needs to add something when I'm on my way to the store, it shows up right there on my list.

Voice recognition is really good, though sometimes it can't provide information on what I'm looking for, something I'm sure will improve in time. Hopefully you'll be able to give it a personal name, right now you're limited to Alexa, Amazon, Echo, and Computer. That's right, "computer." I changed it to that for a day and enjoyed being Captain of a starship. Well, maybe an Ensign.

My wife and I enjoyed the games feature; turns out the guy who never listens to the radio scored higher than the girl that can sing along with anything. Cool. Then there's stories, where Alexa tells you like a story of the day or something.

Alexa has a little bit of a personality, too, which you'll find as you experiment.

Directing Alexa to play specific songs or read books from my purchased library is a little tricky, this is where the phone app helps out. By the way, the app can control multiple devices.

I haven't tried the extra features like appliances and cameras, but they seem affordable and very useful. Nor have I added any extra speakers, this 3rd Gen has really great sound, almost like stereo, and you can call up a simple equalizer on your app to change the sound. Volume control is easy, either by voice or by the up/down button on top.

If you have wifi there is no good reason not to have at least one Echo in your home. It's fun, it's educational, and right now I'd be lost without one. The beauty of it is it available to anyone with a voice; hands-free, no real learning curve. Great for older people, invalids or those with disabilities.

Can't wait to see what future versions will be like.

Love the newer echo dots, we have 3 in our house which is better than one as you can group them and listen to the same song through out the house and we use the drop in feature and we have cloud cams as well that will notify us through the echo dots if there is motion or glass breaking and so forth.

At first I didn't like that the changed the plug in part cause the old echos required the same type of plug as a phone, its the same as a phone charger. But I did have issues with the connection being stable sometimes it would fall out and with this new echo dot the plug is secure and I have grown to like it much better.

I have grouped my in to Multiple speaker group and now if I am cleaning it will play my music or audio books through out the whole house so if I move rooms I will still continue to be able to listen to my echo dots which makes things much more pleasant..

There always updating Alexa with new things to try and privacy seems to have many people canceling or deregistering their echos but you can remove the stored audio on the Alexa and it is just used to help recognize your voice and helps the alexa get smarter, I like this feature as I dont have anything to hide anyways so this does not bother me what so ever.

There are deals you can get through your echo by shopping on Amazon.com through the echo which I love a good deal. I once got $100 off a $300 cole hann purse, ecstatic! This was the discount from ordering with my Echo dot !

You can also have conversations with your Alexa which is fun!

Also it guards your house when your away like if it hears breaking glass or a smoke detector or a carbon monoxide detector go off it will alert your phone, I have pets at home and things like this mean the world to me I am very appreciative of this feature.

Will continue to purchase this item and any newer generations as well.

After going through and listening to the recordings Amazon kept from our two dots, we decided to toss them (put them in a storage box).

Not a passionate review. If I had not found a bunch of recordings that had nothing to do with Alexa stored on Amazon servers I would have kept using the dots. Have no problem with Amazon keeping the recordings of my requests to Alexa but every recording I saw that did not was kept and was even labeled by Amazon to show that it had nothing to do with an Alexa request. If they simply fixed that I would probably use the dots again. Seems like a simple fix if they already know it has nothing to do with an Alexa request - just delete them as a matter of form. And, some of the conversations recorded were perplexing. Not sure how "Alexa" was heard. Seemed random.

That said, we were not huge Alexa users. We found most things it did just as easily or comfortably done in other ways (and I still use Siri for other things and I prefer their privacy policies and practices). I completely understand the 5-star reviews if one is has integrated Alexa into their lives more than we did (If I used Alexa like I use Siri, I would have kept the dots and written a 5-star review). We did not and the privacy concerns were sufficient to get rid of them. All in all, it was a dispassionate decision. Wasn't angry with Amazon and not much attached to the dots.

I will miss the shopping list.

I love my Echo Dot 3rd Gen. I didn't know what I was missing until I helped my neighbor set hers up. We ran into a problem interfacing with Pandora until we discovered they moved that from Music to Skills and Games. Once we set Pandora up I was jumping up and down at the possibilities.

Alexa now keeps my grocery list for me. I feel like I just gained hours a day and never forget to add something. No more getting up in the middle of the night to make a note, no more stopping what I'm doing to add to the list,...Yikes, this is heaven.

I'm totally content with the speaker quality. It's much better than my phone or laptop. I'm going to add more Echo dots after reading other reviews.

I bought 2 smart plugs so I can turn an uplight and space heater on independently. So far no problems. I've only scratched the surface of possibilities. There is no going back.

Oh yeah. I'm using Amazon Smart Plugs. I tried a smart plug from another manufacturer and experienced some problems.

I'm just getting used to the whole Alexa thing so it is still a little early in my overall expectations, but generally speaking, I like it. Disappointed in the Dot speaker quality, way too easy to overdrive it. (Note to Amazon: partner with an outfit like Cambridge Soundworks for your audio; Google is outpacing you for the same dollars)
Speech recognition learning seems slow but it's getting there. And Alexa is somewhat stilted and precise in getting certain commands to work smoothly. You'll be having to memorize the dialogue for your favorite routines since Alexa isn't very intuitive in learning what you want.
I did buy a few smart plugs and I do like being able to turn on/off lights and appliances with ease. If I were a homeowner, I would definitely do my entire house.
Having audio versions of many of the things I typically use my smartphone for I also like, such as medication reminders, upcoming events, birthdays, etc.
In fact, I'm thinking of getting a Dot for an elderly friend, I think these could be invaluable in the home of the elderly.
The basic "Guard Home" feature is a nice touch, although the addition of a dB-based alarm function would be nice and what I would think reasonably simple to code.
In my opinion, a lot to like with a lot of room for improvement. I went in this direction rather than Google out of a certain loyalty to Amazon, I hope they can make the needed improvements.

reviews.reviewTitle: Configure Dot without a second device that also has bluetooth & Alexa app.
reviews.reviewText:
There is an important update to this review below... The new dot looked very cool with the blue led ring. Too bad that as far as it got. The Dot does not have a usb port, and requires you also own fairly new device that can download and install Amazon's Alexa app as well. No way to put DOT on your network without the second Alexa device to talk to it. I was very disappointed to find my brand new 2019 model Fire tablet w/ Alexa can not help configure a Dot (no bluetooth). Google play store says my smartphone is not compatible with the Alexa app. Microsoft says have to have Windows 10 to install the app on a PC. So the only thing I can do is send the Dot back. Dumb way to design a product line.
*Update As a result of my original 2 star rating, Amazon reached out to me and provided a URL to a webpage with instructions on how to configure the Echo dot, without another Alexa device. It briefly puts your home computer on a network the dot creates. Then you can see the dot to configure it using the PC's browser, including giving dot the wi-fi key to get on your network. When finished you then switch the PC back to your network, and the dot does the same. Amazon should probably include these instructions somewhere easy to find.

reviews.reviewTitle: Microphone is horrible on the 3rd Gen vs 2nd Gen
reviews.reviewText:
I have a second generation and even though it had 1 microphone it was better. This is probably because the speaker is louder, but the microphone doesn't pick up my voice most of the time when I am playing music or it is talking. Probably because the music is playing loud. I have to yell at it all the time. This is really stupid and if you search the internet the same feedback has come.

With that said the Google one is not any better and the Alexa has better mic pickup when the music/alexa is not talking so this is still your best bet for a voice product.

Just note, I do use the Amazon Alexa alot and it doesn't mean I don't like the product. It turns on my TV, plays music, etc.

From a technical standpoint they should not allow it to talk back so loud that it blocks the mic from picking up my voice. That defies the whole point. For example, lets say it starts playing a song I don't like. I have to start yellow Alexa, Alexa, Alexa. That is embarrassing and it deters myself and my family members from wanting to use the product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perhaps one of the devices that we use the most
reviews.reviewText:
It integrates beautifully in our home. It is located at my boy's room and from there it controls several devices, it can hear me even from the living room, at 25 feet away and from there it turns on and off the lights at the hallway, for example.
We took it to our lounge room for small meetings with friends and it fun to control and fight over which song we will listen next.
It learns everyday and skills are getting smarter every week. I'm very please with the product, so please that I bought one for my parent house, with my intention to keep it for me, since I thought they will not use it and get bored about Alexa, quite the opposite they love it and now they are asking me for another one to place it in their second floor.

I got an Echo dot as a wedding gift and in one day we liked it so much that we ordered two more for around the house! Alexa makes life so much easier. Need to make a shopping list just tell her what you want when you think of it during the day. Need to set an alarm before you forget just tell her and she will go off when you need it. Need to set a reminder to call the doctor she can do that too.

I use Alexa for so many things. She starts my microwave, she turns off the bedroom lights when I need her to, and she plays music for me at night to help me fall asleep. I also use her all day during work to listen to music.

The echo dot alone has a lot of features and it is extremely easy to set up you can have it up and running in less than 1 minute. If you want to be able to use it with your phone you do have to download an app. The echo dot 3rd Generation has decent sound quality it doesn't hurt my ears when I listen to music all day and it does have adjustable sound feature such as the bass and the treble.

If you really want to maximize the echo dots potential I highly suggest that you get yourself some Alexa compatible light bulbs and Alexa compatible smart plugs. We went all the way and got an Alexa compatible microwave. You will not regret adding the echo dot 3rd Generation to your smart home Arsenal.

It can not pick up your voice from across yhe room, let alone when there is any noise in the room. Let alone music. I have the 2nd gen and 3rs gen. Both same thing. Its like OK google in the car. I just wish it had feelings so I could choke the life out of it.

It's already made our lives better. When we get the smart home set up, it will be super nice to use these to just speak commands and program scheduled household "scenes" (read: ambiance) by fiat. But beware using 2 or more in a single area of the home, unless you have at maximum 3 and name them each differently.

Main con: you can only name this thing Alexa, Computer, or Echo. It would be way better to name them whatever the hell you want! After all, you paid for it! reviews.reviewTitle: A compromise from 2nd Gen Echo, but better speaker
reviews.reviewText:
So I started writing a review the other day, good stuff, but my browser crashed So I'll cut to the chase .

PROS: 1) More powerful speaker, with lower bass, higher max volume as well (although to preserve the integrity of any speaker you shouldn't use it at it's limit consistently). In fact, if you're used to prior generation Echo Dots, in hearing this one it will be as though the engineers granted Alexa a diaphragm -so it takes some getting used to when you hear her speak, but over-all it's a welcome change.

2) Price: is actually more approachable on the newest gen, especially if you purchased at Christmas time 2018 like I did.

Annnnd.. that's about it in terms of "better than the last gen". I did notice that it connected more quickly to the WiFi, but that could also be that I'm more used to the app on my phone and the procedure to connect everything the way it was. So on to CONS.

CONS: As Amazon I'm sure spent more on R&D as well as more material necessary for this model, the bigger speaker as well as the adapter (what a beast) they probably were thinking some parts needed to be cut to balance the cost. This unit has only 4 mics (down from 16 on the gen 2) and while it's not too terrible, I CAN tell the difference. I find myself talking deeper or raising my projected volume in order for "her" to wake. Sometimes I see the Echo Dot frantically "looking" for the direction of my voice even after waking and getting my request all wrong because it probably wasn't "focused" at the best position to receive instructions. I DO think Amazon could of gotten away with 4 less internal mics, I'm also sure they tested things and got reasonable results and that's what I get "reasonable" not terrible, but not at the level they set the bar with either; which feels like a disappointment.

2) It's bigger and heavier and uses more power. This should be expected in going through with a newer generation of the same product especially since most loyal to the product will be doing so for the speaker upgrade. So the only reason I bring this up is because my Echo is mounted from under the cabinet in our kitchen. A clever designer created a plastic mount for the Echo 2nd gen (which fits the 1st gen as well) probably with a CAD program and a makerbot and sells these. They are sold in black and also white (which is my Echo's color so it best matches the kitchen even it you manage to see it). When Amazon changed the physical dimensions, I was forced to purchase a new kit (from the same seller who now had an updated kit for gen 3 Dots). So all this to say: if you're upgrading and it's mounted, you will probably be forced to re-purchase something you thought you already took care of.

3) Volume levels. Volume levels are different on this Echo. Typically if you want to change the volume on your Echo you have a manual button on the Echo (which I'm not a big user of). And there is the verbal command "Alexa, volume 6" (levels go from 1 to 10). On the gen 2 Echo Dot when doing this, the Dot would play a short tone at the level that corresponds with "level 6" -just a helpful feature that allows you to estimate where you need to be with what you're listening to. To my knowledge, Gen3 Echo Dot lost this feature. Surely you can still verbally raise or lower the volume, but there is no audio indicator for what "level 6" is out of the 1-10 volumes. I contacted Amazon about this and they "took it as a suggestion for an option on the Alexa app" So thank you, but it was Amazon's idea to add this in the first place -it's just as likely their idea to remove it -so, not holding my breath.

4)Power brick. Again it was an inevitability with the bigger speaker. This is the most obvious change to the 3rd gen Dot that most reviewers are upset about. So was I, since it took a good bit of planning to make the 2nd gen dot as hidden as possible while not using some kind of battery to sustain it's power requirements. When I did the math I understood. I didn't like the change, but I do realize it was the cheapest way to satisfy the Dot's requirements to function as advertised. You see, 5V is the max voltage a Micro USB cable can safely carry. Even doubling the cables on one side like some older portable hard drive enclosures used to do to get the twice the power to the device wouldn't get the 12V necessary to run the gen 3 Echo Dot. So you go from a fairly ordinary looking USB A/C adapter/charger to a monsterous looking ..."wall brick?" Which could prove a problem for some users depending on how small the space is in the area they are trying to power their Dot in.

So all in all nothing is a deal-breaker for me( I play lots of music from my Dot), however the lesser feature-set confuses me. Amazon built itself on customer service and then later, the ability to purchase almost anything on their platform. They have become a force to look to when considering what sells since they are inventing and selling sometimes "firsts" in technologies. They have even established themselves as reputable technology vendors of products that are at or exceed the level of rival technologies at a reasonable price. So why set the bar and then under-exceed your previous product? As it's said, " Getting to the top is easier than staying on top" I don't believe that was the case this time around. I hope someone over there will read my review and take action to truly exceed the 2nd gen Dot in every way.

These things are great, just 1 Dot got me into the whole conversion to a "smarter" home! I'm just upset I didnt buy a few more Dots at Xmas time when they were at a great price. I'm apprehensive now of buying them new from Amazon for this exact reason, as I think they are too much $ now (at least the Dots...fifty bcuks?!) But there's always eBay, Marcari, and all those other apps where you can find used ones in great shape for cheap. That is what I will probably end up doing for later purchases. They are really cool to have, as you can get them all to sync (like when listening to music), use as intercoms, make calls, stream music, get Amazon notifications and tracking for your purchases, turn lights on/off (If equipped), etc.

If you're converting over to a "smart " home, I surprisingly like Amazon's version over Google's (& I love Google stuff) Alexa is a great way to go. You'll like to have a hub to really make things shine and have, in a sense, a base station for controlling everything but its not fully needed if you just want to be able to control a few plugs and lights, etc. Anyways, having Dots placed in every room is a nice thing to have (which I'm still aspiring to do! Lol) with a hub and some smart light bulbs and power plugs and you're good to go! Doorbell cam? Can set alarms and timing for stuff too. Will also control thermostat if you have a compatible one. Having a hub will really enable you to control pretty much anything and everything that's wifi compatible through simple apps/& or your computer. Wanna see what's going on when your on vacation? Wanna turn on the heat when you land at the airport and its wintertime? And things & texh will just get better. Really is a fun and cool thing.

I really, really wanted to love this product. There is a marked improvement in bass output and volume, such that I can hear Alexa speaking several rooms away if I crank the volume all the way up.

Unfortunately, if I leave the volume at a more reasonable level, the 3rd gen dot still sounds like it’s speaking to me from several rooms away. The bass is present, but the mid and treble tones suffer clarity. I can get great music quality from the device if I equalize it with software before the Dot gets it, so I’m sure this thing is capable of a better balance, but as is you’re limited to the undocumented features of asking Alexa to increase or decrease the bass or treble, each of which seem to have three levels (less/normal/more) and I’ve not yet found a happy balance that provides crisp voice quality.

Worse, the number of microphones has decreased from 7 to 4. In my use case (a mud room that frequently has running water or machinery) the accuracy of commands has plummeted, if the thing even hears the wake word at all. The only way to guarantee it hears me is to shout “ALEXA!” at the top of my lungs, wait until I visually see the blue ring, and then scream what I want it to do while maintaining a direct line of sight between my overloud gabber and the device

Speaking of the blue light, unlike previous generations which would do a spinny “thinking” effect while processing your query, the 3rd gen dot goes dark after it accepts your command, and only lights up again to indicate it has completed your request.

Unfortunately, the ring going dark is the same thing that happens if the device decides you weren’t talking to it at all, so if you’re sending a command that may have some lag before the result (for example, turning on a Zigbee light through an Alexa skill) you kind of have to hope and pray it’s trying to do what you asked, with no way of knowing if your command was ignored outright.

And finally, on the subject of ignored commands: follow-up mode has been turned into hot garbage of late. It will listen for your command, and as soon as you’re done uttering it, shut off like a defiant toddler.

My advice: pass on this model. The 2nd gen Dot is definitely too quiet, but if you already own one, there are plenty of third party drop-in speakers that fix that problem without losing 3 microphones. If you’re new to the ecosystem, plunk down the extra cash for a full-sized Echo.

This device is ok, I guess. I thought it was just a speaker to be honest and it was free on a special so no complaints really. I just don't get the point of it or Alexa really. I thought I was going to be able to use this as a speaker for my computer (I could not). It can be used as a speaker only to use Alexa as far as I can tell. Alexa is ok.
