I find it difficult to remember her name but not allowed to rename her. Also, really 3 syllable name necessary?? When I say "play" she interrupts my sentence and says "here's something I think you like"...geesh Alexa, wait your turn lol, I was trying to tell you what to play!! She does this repeatedly maybe every other time I say "play". Super confusing is the fact that you can't use it to play Amazon Video sound through...all other kinds of video apps there Netflix, etc. but no Amazon Video???? She can't search Google and give you info like Siri would, she can only search Wikipedia. She makes random dings and doesn't know why...when I ask her she says she doesn't know. Aside from setting a reminder, telling me the weather, and playing music apps I can't find much use for...and its not really loud enuf to play music on in my opinion unless you are sitting right near. Good sound though for sure and was not too difficult to set up with Alexa.

Update: After repeatedly asking Alexa if she could bluetooth pair with my laptop and getting a 3 beat tone in response (no words, no answer, just the same noise over and over), I searched the internet for a while and finally figured out how to do it. So I originally wrote this device could not be used as a bluetooth speaker but was wrong. You can pair to any bluetooth device (in theory) and use it as a speaker for that device which is nice because I wanted to play my own music and this allows me to do so.

Update 2: I'm so sick of this device making noises all day long and not being able to tell me what they're about! It goes on and on for hours with no end so I've given up on it and can no longer keep it plugged in due to the incessant noises it makes for no reason or at least no reason that it can tell me or I can figure out. Good thing it was free or I'd really be upset!!

Okay, I should say "Love my Dots", as in I now have 4! I started out with one, but then got frustrated when there was something I wanted to ask it, but the Dot was out of range. If there's always one within range, I always have access to it. I love the grocery list function, and haven't forgotten anything at the grocery store since I got one. I use the timers all the time when cooking. I use the "Sleep Sounds" to go to sleep to the sound of a box fan every night as I love to sleep with white noise in the background. Or the sound of falling rain... The Dot has replaced my alarm clock. The Dot syncs with my calendar. And I love being able to just ask it questions that I would normally have to run and google the answers to on my computer. I've even got one in my basement... The second gen definitely has better sound quality than the 1st gen. Not as good as my Echo Show, but good enough for my musical needs. Your mileage may vary. I love being able to turn things on and off just by asking. And smart plugs are way better than regular timers because when there's a power failure you don't have to reset them. Smart technology is the wave of the future for a reason.

reviews.reviewTitle: I Love Siri But This Is So Much Better
reviews.reviewText: We didn’t get why people liked Alexa products so much but when this went on sale we gave it a shot and LOVE IT! It does have a hard time hearing us when the TV is on sometimes but the room is large and open to several other spaces and we are upgrading to a full sized Echo, so this will be moving to our bedroom soon which likely won’t have the same problem. Caveats: I’d love better support for kids’ profiles and controls/restrictions - not being able to have a full profile for kids means we can’t create separate Apple Music accounts to pair for each person so we have to carefully monitor their use and won’t be buying kids versions yet (among other things like creating routines specifically for them). Love that we can share lists between our household (adding to grocery list while I look at what we have is much smoother than Siri!), but hate that since we share an Apple Calendar for family stuff we can’t link it to both profiles or it doubles all the events on Alexa. It’s also frustrating that only one profile gets notifications on our phones or Apple Watches even though we’ve both linked ourselves to the app, so we continue to use Siri for most of our timers and reminders. The voice recognition is incredibly smooth most of the time - way smoother than Siri - and much faster to process. Skills are still somewhat clunky sometimes (chore chart isn’t worth the time it takes to log things) but love that they can be customized. It would be nice to be able to pick people to share custom skills with so we don’t have to switch accounts every time we want to use them. Routines could use some more features like not counting an apostrophe or comma as a special character and accommodating longer text responses or other Alexa skills but that will likely come in time. It’s also frustrating not being able to see routines that others in the household have created to ensure that we haven’t used the same trigger words or already set something up (and I want to be able to switch in the app to my kids if we are going to invest in more dots). Overall, we are happy and ready to expand our usage. We look forward to advances in the future as well!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great device with still room to grow
reviews.reviewText: We bought the Alexa device so that we would have a music speaker at out house that is easy to use and will increase the amount of time we listen to music. After having it for a few weeks now, we have listened to much more music as a family than we did before purchasing the Alexa. It is also very easy to use, all we do is speak what song we want the device to play. One of the negative sides is that you need some music service subscriptions to be able to play music and sometimes it does not link well and you need to be tech savvy to figure it out. For example, music from Amazon music is played always super easy and without a problem. However, anytime we try to play music from Spotify, it wouldn’t link to the account unless the app is open on my iPad. This may be a quick fix in settings, but I wasn’t able to figure that out yet. Another issue I came across relates to music in foreign languages. I feel like I have to speak a song name or artist of a foreign language in an American accent for Alexa to understand what I am saying. Foreign language voice recognition can be a great area of growth.

reviews.reviewTitle: Kinda weak in the knowledge dept
reviews.reviewText:
"Skills" are like apps for this little bezos object. Either I am unclued as how to harness the echo's power or there is little there to harness. Weather reports, traffic update are ok. I LOATHE asking for a subtle seaside sound machine to play only to loudly pitched an 'up-sell' from the alexa inside. When trying to rest - I do not want to get into a lengthy ad description of a 'skill' for sale. At all. Yuck.
The unit itself sounds good enough when playing Spotify. It has difficulty hearing over some music and will require users to shout - I know - my neighbor routinely barks at her echo unit and sometimes it's laugh. Most times not. Echo is best placed out in an open area or it goes deaf altogether.
A simple answer I wish I could get: What network is carrying my NFL team's next game. Easily accessible info that echo can't report.
I wish I could have done a home test side-by-side with the google mini but I ain't got that kind of disposable dough.
For now the dot makes it easy to yell out my lights and check to see if it's raining even though I have a window.

reviews.reviewTitle: Newest member of the family!! Love Alexa!!
reviews.reviewText:
One of the BEST gifts I ever bought for my Mom and Dad! My sister has the Apple Homepod, and when they brought it on vacation with us, my parents fell in love with it. For $260 something, plus the cost of an iTunes subscription, it's totally out of my league. Amazon has never steered me wrong yet, so I figured I'd try the Echo. TOTALLY AMAZING!! I didn't get the subscription to the full catalog of Amazon music yet, because they're have only been a few songs that we couldn't access without it! I'll probably end up signing up for it, because, unlike Apple, you don't have to take out a loan to pay for it. It's only $3.99 monthly. Seriously. SERIOUSLY!!

Sometimes Alexa won't wake up to my dad's voice, but she does follow him the rest of the day. And whats hysterical, if you say her name, just in conversation, she stops what she's doing, and answers you. Doesn't matter if you're talking to her or not, she hears her name and tries to get involved. We're having a good time asking her questions and I like that sometimes she follows up with "Did I answer your question" and then sends the feedback. She seems able to answer a direct question, ("How many years was Friends on TV?") but not an open ended one, like ("What was the TV show that had Mary Tyler Moore's legs and voice?"). I wish I could have sent feedback on that.

reviews.reviewTitle: Alexa is free to download as an app on your device.
reviews.reviewText:
This is a fairly mediocre speaker / microphone. It, by itself, is not "smart," it just has the Alexa app on it ... which is free by itself. It also has a really obnoxious, un-intuitive, nonsensical, labyrinthine setup wracked with error messages and snags. For example: You have to plug in the Echo dot, wait for one color ring, then hold the button down for 7 seconds, then wait for another color ring, where it then tells you to download the Alexa app and follow the directions despite that the Alexa app doesn't seem to have instructions. You'd think they would put a big red "FINISH SETUP" button for you, but no. And you can't search because Alexa gives you a Wifi hotspot that disables your internet connection. The Alexa app on Microsoft demands that you log into an email and remember the password, for some reason, then runs through a whole other setup, so I hope you have everything memorized. I somehow stumbled through it the first time. A couple weeks later, a storm hit and knocked out the power and I had to do it all over again and could not figure it out the second time. Because this thing does not have any sort of battery pack. If the ring is the wrong color, you get to hold a specific button for a specific amount of time. You will be required to sign into one or more emails and one or more wifi hotspots. There's a lot of running back and forth between your various programs. Yes, setup is on a timer, too, so you'll feel rushed. And that's how you'll spend a portion of the hours that it takes to set up.

However, you can skip all that by simply not buying this device.

I was looking forward to this gadgeT, heard all types of great things about it, family members have one so I wanted it too. Well, it came a few days ago and that excitement turned to a nightmare. Man, it was the most stressful thing ever. What seems so simple watching videos about it did not go in my favor. Everytime I tried to get hooked up it would say, you're not registered. Followed all the checklist to remedy this situation but no success. Tried calling for help, no success. Literally did all the steps probably more than 10x and then tried it again with whatever changes to see if it would work. Failed. I'm returning this and bid this good riddance. This was not the outcome I was hoping for and after reading some negative issues about having echo dot I'm now glad it didn't work. I've read some really scary stuffs about it. Get unhooked now, you'll thank me later. BIG FAIL!

All in all, it is pretty much the same device. If you already own a Alexa device, there is no downgrade of Alexa's support. 3rd gen has slightly better voice recognition, but that has more to do with a better mic than it does software. The asthetics of the device are much more improved and look like a good and appropriate "desk" piece or wall mounted item. as ti no longer has the "ugly plastic" look and feel. Granted the drawback of that is no longer being able to use any of the 1st and 2nd gen dot perefials - but as 3rd gen is out for some time, companies will make new ones (but still have the draw back of needing to buy them).

The biggest advantage is sound quality. the speaker for 3rd gen dot is MUCH better and is a lot better "full room" sound in both terms of quality and volume.

There was a deal for a while to "turn in" and upgarde to the 3rd gen for a cheaper cost. I dont' recommend it. The 2nd gen is still good and has all the same alexa software. As the only noticible differences are "look" and "sound". Simply move the 2nd gen to a bedroom, kitchen, laundry room, garage and keep your new 3rd gen in your primary space such as bedroom or living room. "everywhere" sound is an amazing thing, as is the intercom system. So more echo devices the better, just pick and choose where you want the better sound.

UPDATE:

WOW, Alexa is great, the speakers are okay, not great. I mean the rest of this stuff right now is just plain silly.

I originally gave a 1 star because of this.

I thought the Amazon Music Individual plan worked like this,
* You can only play on one "Speaker" at a time, grouping does not work with the Individual plan, period.

BUT it works like this,
* You can only have one "Stream" at a time, but grouping will work for that one stream on all speakers in that group with the Individual plan.

Yeah, I wish Amazon would make this more clear in their drop-down menu (only place I could even find anything, sad). All they need to do is add a few words,

Individual Plan: ("add") "Single" Stream tens of millions of songs from any device "or a group of devices".

Pretty simple. Especially since the Family Plan says "Stream on up to 6 devices at once." makes it look like it is the only plan that lets you uses more than one device at the same time.

Still only 3 stars because of issues 2 through 10 which still apply (See below before you buy)...

ORIGINAL POST:

WOW, what a horrible overall experience. Alexa is great, the speakers are okay, but Amazon has just totally blown this for its main capability, playing music. I mean the rest of this stuff right now is just plain silly. I'm returning 2 Dots and an Echo plus because Amazon was so smart they put up roadblocks at every option to try and use these "Smart Speakers" as "Speakers"! Basically, the only way to use these speakers as speakers is using Amazon services. Please keep reading before buying!
.1 Multiroom is only available via Amazon Music, there is no other way to listen to all your speakers at once, period!
.2 Playing on multiple speakers is an upcharge via Amazon Music.
.3 Playlist through Amazon Music requires a minimum of 5 clicks per song (think about that).
.4 There is no way to use or upload ANY music you already own ( or even a way to compile playlists from that music)
.5 There is currently no way to import or create playlists externally.
.6 If you use Bluetooth or AUX for outputting sound from the Echo speaker's the speaker sound is turned off.
.7 The Dots have no input option, so you can't even just use them as a dump speaker.
.8 I tried multiple equalizer options and nothing I did made these speakers sound all that great. They basically have no range.
.9 They don't play in stereo either, they play in mono, one channel on all speakers playing to the same thing.
.10 This is basically a toy, get a Kid Dot if you want, and maybe in a few years this tech will have arrived, it's not here yet.

I could go on but I had the Plus for less than a week and the Dots for less than a day.

reviews.reviewTitle: Cheaper than the competitors and works better too!
reviews.reviewText:
Our first experience with a smart speaker was a Google Home. It had a nice app and it did some things, but we had to repeat “okay google!” 5 times before it even heard us. We repositioned it, we reset it, recalibrated the voice commands, etc and nothing really helped. It was too late to return/exchange it by the time we decided it might be a hardware issue, so into the bathroom it went to be used as a music player.

Then comes Alexa. Easier to use and set up, and the physical buttons are easier to use than Google’s (admittedly cool) fabric touch surface. She can hear us calling out her name in the nosiest situations, and I’ve gotten so comfortable with using her that I don’t even look for the lights to see if she’s picked up on my voice anymore. I just call out a command and she follows without fault every time!

We’ve got her hooked up to my Prime account to deliver us notifications and place orders, she’s connected to our thermostat, she can turn on my TV, and we’ve got her connected to Smart Outlets to control lights and appliances. I’ve almost even forgotten that Siri exists on my phone now!

I love out Dot so much that I’ve been using them as gifts for practically any occasion. They’re incredibly helpful and I’m excited to expand her abilities and even place a few more Dots around the house.

If you’re looking for a smart speaker, I seriously can’t imagine anything better than this. Just try out a Dot! You won’t be disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Echo has taught me to hate the name Alexa. Comparison of the Dot and Echo
reviews.reviewText:
If this is the best AI on the market, we've got a LOOOOONG way to go, America. These are probably the stupidest and most frustrating devices to use. Let me give you an overall assessment of the AI first, then the differences between the two.

I ask the devices to do something very simple, like to pay public radio, and it plays some obscure non-public radio station.
The devices dosn't learn use patterns. At all. When you ask a simple question, the only answers you seem to get have to do with purchasing items from Amazon or Wikipedia definitions. One morning I set up two alarms. I woke up before the first alarm, so I asked Alexa to turn off the first alarm only. Guess what happened. It turned off all alarms. Really stupid and unreliable. Plus, I find myself repeating my requests time and time again. The microphones downright suck. With both you will find yourself yelling at the machine and calling it a dumb b*tch. From this negative association I will never date a gal named Alexa for fear of becoming unfairly opinionated about lack of common sense.

Now, if I haven't dissuaded you from purchasing this junk, let me explain the substantial differences between the Dot and Echo. Surprisingly, the speaker sound difference between the two is minimal. Both are non-obtrusive in size. The larger Echo, however, offers little more than slightly better microphones. I am constantly repeating myself when talking to the Dot. Not so much with the larger Echo.

For most things, like listening to talk radio or for use as an alarm, the Dot is what you want. The sound from the Echo sounds no better, and if anything, it is a bit more muffled in an effort to make is sound have more bass, which it barely does.

reviews.reviewTitle: A very significant upgrade in sound vs the Echo dot 2.
reviews.reviewText: The echo dot V3 has a fuller (less tinny) sound than the Echo Dot 2. It also takes a larger power supply. I have purchased a second after using the first and would purchase AGAIN and recommend others to purchase. Still amazes me how many additional features are being added to Amazons Alexa software. I dont expect obsolescence any time soon.

You may be like me and done this several times. That lovely USB/Bluetooth speaker with good reviews. You pick it up and get hit with tinny sounding music or bad connections. I promise you that will not happen here.
I got 2 Echo Dots and put one in the bedroom and the other in the living room. Both powered up and said they were ready so the next thing was to install the app. I was a little confused by the directions at first. I thought that the software on my phone was going to create a network for the devices. Instead it meant that when the device is in discover mode you will see the network device by whatever name it says to look for.
So my first test was simple "Alexa, play David Gilmore" and voila the sound was very good. Then I found I could group everything...no only that but if 2 are in the same room they become stereo speakers. (future purchase coming) So I created my Everywhere network and told Alexa to play Meg Myers everywhere. My house was instantly filled with her music.
So then the last part was to tell Alexa to wake me for work tomorrow and do it to David Gilmore. The next morning; it is a bad idea to wake up to music you love listening to. You want to lay there and listen to the lovely tones.

I have not gotten into controlling lights or other things like that. But I have installed the "Thunder and Rain skill" which is confusing. Because all she does is play a 1 hour track from Amazon Music. But I have gone to sleep listening to thunderstorms every night since then. I guess my next venture is to try the more expensive ones with great speakers for the living room and move the living room one to the bedroom.

reviews.reviewTitle: Product was returned along with ALEXIS in the same box AMAZON shipped it to me in.
reviews.reviewText: After seeing 60 Minutes and t/w my work IT dept I decided not to keep this or Alexis. Sent it back and now I realize I should have printed 2 labels but they both came in the same box! I keep getting notices that I need to return it and I have. I can't email AMAZON and can find no where to let them know. Maybe they can respond to this. In all my years with AMAZON this is the first complaint I've had and the 4th time I have ever returned something. Maybe I'm missing it. There was nothing wrong with the product that I know of, I didn't even take it out of the box. Just opened and closed. I returned Alexis so one would gather I don't need this.

Purchased for verbal medication routine reminders due to poor memory. My reminder setup was double-checked to ensure the test's accuracy.
* echo doesn't understand me well, so I had to type in reminders
* Mispronounces words typed in
*Limits length of reminders so my noon medication instructions took five reminders spaced a minute apart.
* If your medication routine needs to be repeated multiple times a day it does not give you the option of doing so without having to retype everything all over again.
* Because the setup is cumbersome, I decided to just see how the noon cuing went; by the fourth day echo was only giving me 2 of the 5 midday reminders.
*A reminder I set to begin a change in my medication routine began 9 days earlier than scheduled

reviews.reviewTitle: Dead mode - Sorry I am having trouble understanding right now. Please try a little later.
reviews.reviewText:
"Sorry I am having trouble understanding right now. Please try a little later". I keep getting this message from my Alexa device almost every day. It won't recover automatically even after 2 days. The issue is fixed only if you hard reset the device i.e. you have to un-plug the power chord and re-plug it. I reached Amazon support several times, they tried their best nothing worked out. Even tried resetting the device and re-registered it. But issue still exists. Amazon is not ready to replace my device. They want me to buy the same device at discounted price. I really don't expect this from Amazon. I would not recommend this until Amazon fixed this issue.

I have both Google mini and Amazon echo dot. I have never faced this issue on my Google mini.

Google Mini
+ives
Understands my accent very easily and answers most of my questions. I primarily use this devices for playing nursery rhymes and lullaby. Those of built in. That is a big plus. They never market me to subscribe for YouTube red or anything of that sort.
-ives
It has very poor speakers. No option to add new skills. Looks bad.

Echo dot
+ives
Very good audio, looks good when compared to Google mini, Can add different skills, It looks new whenever you add a new skill
-ives
Highly unreliable, poor assistant, it won't understand my accent some times, No standard skills apps, poor support, No build it skills except weather and basic stuff.

Verdict:

I would prefer Echo dot because of its skills feature. But I cannot recommend Echo dot because it is highly un-reliable. It keeps going to dead mode every no and then.

reviews.reviewTitle: Alexa has become our very Dear Friend!
reviews.reviewText: My husband gave me The Echo Dot for our Anniversary gift. I've been intrigued by all of the advertisements for years. I never thought I would have a need for one, just thought it would be 'cool'. However setting it up was quick and easy. Plug it in and follow the instructions. Had to download the app to my phone, which is an awesome feature for control. We 'played' with all of the features, Question of the Day, What's the Weather today?, Who is ...?, Alexa, play Grateful Dead, for a couple of hours!! I personalized Alexa with my Good Morning = I get today's weather, Alexa, Welcome me home = Hello Darling song plays by Conway Twitty, Alexa, Good Night = Random sayings. Our son stopped by to visit and they were in LOVE with our Echo Dot. He searched Amazon to find it was 1/2 price! Upon leaving our house, within 1 mile from leaving, they ordered one for themselves. I took advantage of the lower price and purchased a second Dot for our bedroom at the opposite end of the house. I like the Babbling Brook or Ocean Sounds & Chirping Crickets to lull me to sleep. I'm thinking about getting a third Dot for the kitchen. Right now I transfer my original unit from Living room to Kitchen when I need it there. Alexa & Echo Dot has become one of those items that I didn't really believe "I needed" but don't you dare try to take it away!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Echo dot is almost as good as the Echo 2nd Generaton
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased the Echo Dot 3rd Generation on Amazon Prime Day Deals. I could not pass this deal up with the Amazon Smart Plug included. I was pleasantly surprised at the sound quality, volume of this Echo Dot. I do not remember the previous version of the Dot but this is very much improved over the previous versions. I wanted another Echo for my powder room but did want to pay the price for another Echo. Music sounds great on this little device. Perhaps I am using this in a small powder room but it sounds almost quite as good as my Echo Second Generation. It was easy to connect, easier than my second Echo, and it is small. I understand it is larger than the previous Echo Dots but I dot not
remember what the size of the previous version was. Even though it's larger than the original Echo Dot, it is still very small. If you would like a smart speaker and can not afford the Echo, buy this you will not be disappointed. I like the idea that you can buy a wall adapter to hang it up on the wall by just plugging the Dot into adapter. It will be out of the way. Check for deals,as this can be had for a very affordable price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Paired with good speakers, this is stellar for music.
reviews.reviewText:
This is my fifth Alexa device purchased in short order. I started with the 2nd generation Echo, which is a great device but the first thing I did was hook it up to the expensive audiophile 5.1 sound system in the living room. Once you do this, it's pretty much indiscernible from an Echo Dot. True, it has more mics built into it and in theory should be better at picking up voice commands in a room, but I've not noticed a difference. I now have Echo Dots scattered throughout the house.

Having Alexa devices throughout the house have the obvious "smart home" benefits. But as a music lover and musician with decidedly non-commercial tastes, the most amazing thing about these devices is what happens when you hook them up to decent external sound systems/speakers. I also have a smaller 5.1 system in the bedroom. A decent ancient stereo system in the basement. A Bose SoundDock and a cheaper but decent Bluetooth speaker. Put together into a Music Group, I have fantastic sound throughout the house with the Amazon Music Unlimited account. That's the BEST thing about having these devices: the built in speakers are beyond lacking but these things work with anything. I remember buying my first house decades ago and stringing speaker wires and speaker switches throughout the house. This is way way easier and cheaper!

About the AMU account: my first Echo Dot came with a 90 day free trial that I'm still using. Did I mention I'm a musical snob who loves obscure non-commercial music from mostly the 60s and 70s? While it doesn't have full catalogs of many of my favorite obscure artists, it has partial catalogs from a lot of them. Krautrock and Canterbury artists, Zappa, Velvet Underground/Reed/Cale, various progressive dinosaurs, Oldfield, even Jade Warrior and Slapp Happy are there. Henry Cow is sadly lacking, unfortunately, but I guess that's what CDs are for.

All in all, this is a no-brainer. The only downside is it seems they can't make them fast enough. As I type this, if you order one, you definitely won't be getting it in two days, because they're currently on backorder!

reviews.reviewTitle: I’m an Alexa Household!! A must have!!
reviews.reviewText: Amazing sound from this little device!!! Picks up my voice in the proper room (I have 3, one that came free with my Alexa Show 5 (which is amazing, btw) and got 2 more (for less than $50 while on sale because $23 each, why not?? I love the feature that brings up your Ring (and other brand) doorbell on your Show or a FireStick. The echo dot, a light switch that was compatible and a FireTV Stick is what I started out with, and now I can’t live without it in every room! It already comes with tons of capabilities, but if it’s not built in, there’s always an app/add-on for anything you can think of! The intercom feature is also very very handy!! I got that show 5 and had a Show Gen 2, and I can say drop in on living room from my cell or my other show and I have 2 way video/voice chat! Very cool. Also works with Skype and other people’s Shows/Alexa products to drop in on if they give you permission. Sorry for the novel, but this is definitely an Alexa household now. I added the Hue lights from Philips and my stereos and TVs are Alexa compatible.. so I can control almost everything in the house now.. I think it’s a must have because of the endless possibilities! I’m just glad I saved a fortune on setting up the whole house during Prime Days!

reviews.reviewTitle: My first Echo, and ended up getting 4 more since.
reviews.reviewText:
So I'll start off with a pretty quick disclaimer, I had been wanting to try these for a long time, and went in with my hopes very high for the ease of use and such. I was also very worried about certain things, like voice recognition and noise, and ease of connection.

I've been very pleased so far.

It picks up your voice incredibly easy, I've accidently had it pick me up on 2 of the devices at once, which we fixed by adjusting the location, not its fault. As well, it has trouble with some requests, but its fine once you figure out the commands it listens for.

For such a small speaker, it projects very well and sounds great, Especially once you have them all play at once and the house is filled with music. I was impressed. And as well, the volume controls are easy to adjust as well.

Currently on my setup I have 4 Echo Dots, a Echo Show 5, 2 LED Lightbulbs, and 5 smart plugs, and one air conditioner, and it recognizes and controls them all very well. Its been a great addition to make light and electronic control easy and smooth.

Overall, I may update if there is any significant issues that come up, but nothing that I have noticed yet, and I'm very happy with my investment.

I finally had enough time to play with this to give a quality review.

I am new to the world of Alexa. Most of my house is filled with google IOT merchandise.

Voice recognition
The voice recognition is good but not great. It’s reliable for most everyday tasks.

Call capability
Is an incredible feature. I have been out of the country since my purchase and haven’t been able to use it on my own device.

Sound
The quality is amazing for the size of the speaker. I don’t love that the volume settings are only 1-10. I like to set my volumes by percentage... idk I’m weird but I prefer that to the numbers of Alexa. However at a 6, I’m able to hear the music well over my shower or in an adjoining room.

Setup
The setup was much easier than most other IOT products. I would almost give it a 5/5 just for that. I was surprised at how easy setup was after trying to setup my fire stick (night and day difference)

While I’m not sure the quality is different enough for me to switch over.. I’m glad I splurged the $25 when it was on sale to try it out.

I want to see IOT get a lot bigger.... so I definitely support what amazon is doing.

Let me know if this was helpful.

reviews.reviewTitle: 2 Years Later Using Both: Echo is Much Better than Google Home Mini!
reviews.reviewText:
I started my smarthome with Google mini because they were, ...well Google (an AI company that will probably do a better job). Almost 2 Years later, I came to find out I was very wrong! While Google’s platform is slowly getting better, I found that Amazon’s Alexa platform is actually a lot more mature with a wider variety of sensors and smarthome products. Software-wise, Alexa supports way more skills, like way way more. It’s not even close!

Using both platforms side by side over the last year or so, I found Google assistant (despite being more accurate with factual answers overall) to be lackluster with “skills” and extension/apps.

Alexa also does a few things way better. For example the “drop in” feature alone on Alexa turning the echo into an effective in-house intercom system is so much better than Google’s one way intercom “broadcast” feature. Google’s system is just frustrating in comparison. In fact I ditched it all together so I can easily have 2-way conversations without having to repeat “hey google broadcast...” and then waiting for a reply from the receiver. Alexa intercom system is especially effective with guests and the elderly (who won’t know how to reply or formulate a broadcast message on Google’s system and just wind up flustered and frustrated with the communication method), etc.

Despite running a mostly google smart home system these new echos definitely raise the bar. They work well with my new Ring Alarm System (much more reasonable pricing both hardware and monthly service fees for 24/7 monitoring. By reasonable I mean over a 50% price difference for arguably a worse product -google being the worse product and charging double!).

Hardware: Amazon raised the bar with these. Sound clarity on echo as well as mic sensitivity is unbelievable when compared to Google’s Home Mini. It can hear you even from across the room with its speaker playing.

I love the Echo Dot (3rd Gen). I have an Echo Show, three Echo Dot (2nd Gen), and I recently bought two Echo Dot (3rd Gen).

Echo Dot (3rd Gen)'s sound quality is amazing. It is much louder and clearer than the Echo Dot (2nd Gen). I still love the 2nd gen; I just put them in rooms where the sound quality was not as big of an issue.

Amazon Echo has changed my life for the better. It has so many great features. I especially love the timer function for the kitchen. I can't tell you how many times I would be cooking and accidentally delete a timer because I put on a second timer for a different food item, That is not an issue with Echo. You can have multiple timers and name. Plus, it's hands-free.

I also love being able to add items to a list from any room. The list sinks to my phone, and I'm always ready to go. No more forgotten paper list left at home.

The music feature is wonderful. It quickly finds things on the television.

I use Echo with the Life 360 app. My son has a 30-minute train ride to his high school in downtown Chicago. The life 360 app beeps when he arrives/leaves school, hockey practice, and arrives home. It is an extra layer of safety. It's also cute because when the app beeps my dog waits for my son by the door when he comes home. She realized its only the afternoon beep.

Echo works great with my smart home devices. It is easy to pair with various devices.

I have had parties where I demonstrate all the things Echo can do. I have had multiple friends go home and buy themselves an Amazon Echo. They all asked me if I could help set it up, but it's so easy no one has needed my help.

I love Amazon Echo! It's changed my life for the better.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great litttle device for entertainment and education
reviews.reviewText: We bought 3 of these. I read that many reviewers complain about the sound quality. I cannot support those complaints. A friend of mine has the second generation, and I can clearly hear a HUGE difference in sound quality from the second to the third generation. The third gen has a nice base and fuller sounding quality. I understand that larger speakers might sound even better, louder, basier, and what have you, but let’s face it: this is a small device that is supposed to tell me the weather, remind me of things, set alarms for me, play oceans sounds when I want to fall asleep, and maybe play me an occasional Celine Dion song while I get ready in the morning. My daughter gets a kick out of having Alexa telling her jokes, playing 20 questions, or making farting sounds (I didn’t even know there was such a “skill”). This is light entertainment, and additionally the dots function as our dictionary or Wiki. We love those little Echo dots. To prevent clutter and taking up counter or night stand space, I recommend looking into the Genie that fits those dots perfectly, tugs away the power cord and stays plugged into the outlet. Nice space saver. I highly recommend this little inexpensive Echo Dot, and for the record: I’m not being incentivized for my review.

I bought two of these: one for me and one for my parents. Mine won’t go through all the prompts to learn my voice (I was sent a replacement and experienced the same issue with the second), but there is a ticket out to the developers to research the issue. The customer service representative has gone above and beyond to try to help me; he even called my internet provider on my behalf. My mom’s Echo Dot learns voices easily but she can’t drop in using her phone (iPhone SE). I’m able to do it on my phone (iPhone XR) so maybe her phone is just too old.

My father has health issues and the Echo Dot makes me feel better when he is left alone for short periods of time. My mother has security cameras, so if he is to fall and can’t get to a phone, she can send an announcement to him through the Echo Dot. Also, he is losing his eyesight so he can ask Alexa what time it is and what the weather is like outside.

When you receive your Echo Dot, one of the first things you should do is have Alexa check for software updates. Also, be sure you keep the Alexa app up to date.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is our 5th Echo device, and our 3rd Dot - awesome how they integrate with each other!
reviews.reviewText: We now have an Echo Show in the kitchen, a Show 5 in the bedroom, and Dots in the office, downstairs, and in the garage. It's awesome how they all work together - we have them playing on a speaker group, but also I don't have to yell across the house to run a routine. With the latest two Dots - one is in the garage, and I can be working on a project and ask Alexa to turn on the light (I also bought a smart 3-way light switch). That's really helpful because I might not need the light on if the garage door is open, but then go over to my shop area and all I have to do is ask to turn the lights on. The sound isn't as good as the Echo Show, but it's pretty darn nice given how small it is. The only thing I wish it did was be able to use the internal speaker AND the speaker jack at the same time - I have a stereo in the garage and would love to have the Dot output to it, but most of the time the stereo isn't on, and I just want to hear the Dot's replies on the internal speaker. Right now I have to plug the cable in and out of the Dot to do this, and it would be nice if I could just leave the speaker output plugged in whether the stereo is on or not, and still hear an output.

reviews.reviewTitle: WOW - I don't give out 5 stars often ...
reviews.reviewText:
First heard one of these little Dot's at my step-daughters house - was really impressed that such a small device could fill a decent sized room with "reasonable" quality sound - if your a audiophile - your going to lower your expectations - but for the rest of us humans - with aging ears - this little Dot is amazing - I'm streaming using XM Radio & the sound is amazing - I'm sitting in our living room - the Dot is in our kitchen on top of our fridge - set at a reasonable sound level & it sounds really good - perfect for just back round sound - the second Dot - we having sitting in our bedroom - that one also streams from XM Radio - it sounds great as well - we use it at night to give us ambience for sleeping - the Thunder Storm is wonderful - set for loop & it'll play all night.
I can honestly say - the setup was painless - downloading the App for iOS was painless - wifi connectivity was again - painless - the entire experience was great ...
The "only" glitch I ran into which did require some back & worth between XMRadio & Amazon was the setup of accounts to use with XMRadio - I have two Dot's & three XMRadio accounts - the issue I ran into was - during the initial setup of both Dot's - they both grabbed the same XMRadio streaming account - thus - if you started XMRadio on one & the started XMRadio on the other - they would both crash the XMRadio app as your only allowed to stream one account on one device - fair enough - the catch was - neither XMRadio support - or Amazon support could give me clear steps on how to re-configure one of the Dot's to use a alternate XMRadio account ...
Turns out - you need to delete the XMRadio Skill on one of the Dot's & then add it back - when you add it back - it takes you to the XMRadio site - were you can put in your alternate account information - then the XMRadio account will be associated with the 2nd Dot ... thus I have two Dot's - streaming two separate XMRadio channels ...
The final "tweak" I applied via the Alexa App - was - took up the Bass two notches - lowered the Mid one notch & took the treble up two notches - on both & they both now sound really good - again - not "audiophile" good - but good enough for us aging folks ...

I made this my first purchase in an attempt to introduce myself into the world of smart technology. It was definitely a great buy. Alexa is very responsive, sometimes it may take an extra couple of seconds for her to recognize a command but we live in a small apartment. That being the case some of the appliance noises hinder it's ability to fully hear what was said. The routines are my favorite part, especially early mornings when I want my weather, traffic and news all together while I make my coffee. The built in speaker sounds pretty good as well, I'm one of those people with turntables multiple sets of speakers and to be honest it isn't bad for what it is. Good for asking for a song or playlist to get you going for the morning or cleaning up the house. All in all I give it 5 stars because it is everything they claimed it would be and It's fun to have in the house. To the kids she's become a family member, and in just the 3 weeks that we've had it she's seen two bdays and has sung happy birthday more times than I can count.

reviews.reviewTitle: Alexa is Great for kids and busy moms
reviews.reviewText: I don't know too many people who have Alexa but I recommend it. I got one just to try it Fall 2018. I easily forget things on the stove or to leave for an appointment unless I set alarms. My phone is good but Alexa is so easy. You just tell her: set an alarm (or timer...they are different in sound) for 25 minutes. If you set 2 alarms or 6, you can just say: Alexa how many alarms have I set? Or how many minutes are left? Alexa knows lots of radio stations (not many of us have radios anymore), music (she plays your favorites without asking), lots of games (great for parents & kids to do together - listening is important!). If the music is too loud you can say: Alexa, turn it down 3 notches. The only thing that is slightly annoying is when Alexa interupts our conversation. She thinks she hears her name so we say: Alexa, adults are talking! My teen son and I laugh because, of course, we aren't abusive with other people or even our pets...but Alexa can take it! She doesn't do it often so there's no need to turn her off! I ended up getting one for my son's room (Feb 2019) I hear him playing games before bedtime. We also ask her world facts and math questions whilst doing homework. Eventually I'm going to wifi the whole house but for now our two Alexas are a great addition to our home. highly recommend for busy people and families!

Digital Assistants are getting better and better but still have distinct limits. The Echo Dot 3rd generation is no exception. There is information you might think would be easily accessible but is still met with "Sorry, I don't know that yet ." Part of it is a learning curve for the user in how to frame a question for the best chance of success so don't give up on one try.

I won't bore you with all of the features because they are quite easy to find on the item page, help, and in the Alexa app, but one recently really helped me out. Being a Baby Boomer, I have the occasional senior moment and managed to leave my purse with my cell phone and Fire tablet in a cab. I stopped hacking landline or VOIP a couple years back. The spare key got me inside, but how to call lost and found?

Enter the little Echo Dot. I used the calling feature to reach customer service, but had the flash that I I should call my mobile to alert the driver. He turned out to be a jewel and was walking up to my door as my phone rang. It would have been fine but knowing I can make calls without my phone de-stressed me right away.

It does a fine job for the price. I got it on sale before Christmas but like other Amazon devices, you can also divide the cost into several interest free payments. I recommend this digital assistant. It worked well even before I used the voice traing.

And as for disturbing? One perk of digital assistants is playing with their Easter eggs and asking loopy questions. I did this with first Siri and later other devices. One wild question early on with the Apple program was asking where to hide a body. They.later made less helpful and supposedly less creepy. Naturally I had to give it a try with Alexa. She responded by offering a recipe for slow cooker carnitas.

Of course, the setup was easy. Just plugged it in and it used my account information and set up with no added effort from me. It feels nice - the fabric outer shell. The response is fast, given the increased number of listening microphones. But the biggest difference for me between the 2nd generation and this 3rd is the sound. Huge improvement! And get this: IMHO the sound from the 3rd gen rivals the sound from the 1st gen Echo! I personally think it's better. I bought two for my workout room and paired them to play stereo. Very nice sound! I ended up grabbing a 3rd one for the bathroom!

We already have a few 3rd Gen Dots in our house and they have always worked perfectly (not the greatest sound quality but they work perfectly). This makes it easy to stream music to all of the Alexa devices at the same time. Incidentally, we also have a Show and a Spot which both work just fine too. I recently purchased two new Dots on sale from Amazon... I spent a week trying to get them to work to no avail. They just drop out when playing music after only 1-3 songs.

I went nuts checking my internet and wifi signals everywhere... our wifi coverage is all great. Next, I moved on to just testing an old Dot in its usual place for an hour... worked perfectly streaming music. Then replaced it with a new Dot in the same exact location... it would drop out to silence within 1-3 songs. Put the old Dot back in place... worked perfectly for an hour. I did this with both Dots in multiple locations and the two new Dots consistently failed. It was clearly the new Dots that had some defective component in them.

I've returned the two Dots. The return process was a nightmare as well. I wanted to exchange these for new ones but I had to wait on a call from Customer Service... I couldn't just check off an exchange on their returns page. They insisted upon talking to Customer Service... the page indicated they would call within 10 mins or so... I waited two hours... no call. In the end, I have opted to return for a full refund instead.

When I purchase the last 2-3 Dots that I need to complete the home, if I get one more defective unit, I am done with the Echo line. I'll toss them all in the garbage and purchase another brand. This problem has wasted far too much of my time. Amazon's exchange procedures were impossible to use too.

Sound quality for this little Dot is pretty awesome. We've played all kinds of music through SiriusXM and had no problems at all with the sound quality. Alexa's voice is very clear and there's no problems understanding what she's saying. So far, I've used it to set alarms, play music, read us stories, ask general questions, turn on lights. I really wanted to use the "Drop-In," feature connected to another Dot on a second floor (which is on another account) but found out that I have to have a "mobile phone number" which I don't have, so that was very disappointing for me since that was a big reason why I bought it. The other thing I can't get it to do is remember the "sound" I chose for the Alarm. It always manages to jump back to the Default sound, which isn't terrible, but isn't my choice, either. I've yet to figure that simple thing out and the help files aren't much of a help. Next to these two annoyances, I really like my Echo Dot 3rd Gen and plan on getting some more Smart Plugs to use.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broken after 6 months - Warranty only 90 days
reviews.reviewText:
I overlooked the fact that this only comes with a 90 day warranty which should really speak volumes as to the quality of product you are getting. It is quite standard to have a 1 year warranty included for pretty much anything technology and google home has that on their product.
I am frustrated because I bought 3 of these units for $50 each about 6 months ago and one of them has failed already. Furthermore, when I spent $50 on each of these they went down to $29.99 just weeks later and I was not given an option for a price match. When the product was working, The sound quality was good and overall I enjoyed it but I am very disappointed in the quality of it and how it isn't backed by a real warranty. I also want to share few things in terms of the device itself which I find to be major problems. The first is Alexa's Spotify integration. The controls are very limited in terms of choosing your playlists and alexa easily gets confused when asking her to play one. Furthermore if you are like me and have a spottily family account it is very annoying to switch between accounts. I thought that alexa would be able to detect my voice and use my profile but that is not that case. You need to tell Alexa to switch to xyz account. Then you need to tell her to play music, then if you are lucky the speaker will show up as an available device from your spotify. At least now that my echo is broken and won't be eligible for warranty repair I have a great opportunity to get OUT of this amazon ecosystem and buy google home. I know google home has the features I want like better spotify family support & a warranty that isn't a joke.

reviews.reviewTitle: Magic in a little Dot! Great for the family!
reviews.reviewText: I love this Echo Dot! My husband, myself and my son find it very useful it. Let me start off by saying that this is good for a small room, kitchen or small living room. When asked a question Alexa pretty much understands unless there is something playing in the background or when she’s playing a song you might have to speak up a little louder for her to understand, As for sound quality I would say that it has no bass, but it is pretty decent in sound, Not that I would use for playing music all the time unless I was using it in the kitchen. The Dot is awesome! It’s good for weather updates, to set alarms, reminders and for shopping lists. I try to leave this device in the kitchen to let her know what I need, I could even send my grocery list to my husband manually through a text from Alexa Or ask for recipes. My four year old son has a speech problem so this Dot has been very useful it makes him have to say the words correctly or she will not understand him, my son has a hard time pronouncing words, he wants to get it correct so he tries very hard to pronounce the words better without throwing a fit, so that’s another plus, my son’s words have improved to the point where she’s able to understand him now, my son likes to speak to Alexa so that she will play music for him or speak pikachu he loves pikachu and all Pokémon characters. You could say we like it so much that I purchased the echo plus 2gen so we could leave echo plus in the living room and I could actually keep the ech dot to myself cause my husband and my son keep taking it from me!

I love this thing when it works. Unfortunately it only works about 50% of the time. When I initially wake it with a command it works great for about 15-20 minutes. If I'm listening to music, after about 15 minutes it seems to stop responding to commands. It will light up like it's listening but doesn't respond. For instance, if I tell it to pause, ask it to add to shopping list or set a timer it lights up to listen but doesn't follow through or comply with demands. I've tested wifi strength and connection while it's malfunctioning and wifi is not the issue. Neither is location, as I've tried multiple placements in respect to the router with no improvements. Often it just lights up red and says it's having difficulties understanding me, to try back later. This is with zero background noises. I'm not sure If I recieved a faulty unit. I will contact customer support and revise my review once it is addressed. The sound quality is pretty impressive. It's not going to blow you away but it fills the room.

Same as previous Generation-Speaker is a LOT more Bass(ie) still trying to get that sorted - no matter how I play it still sounds muffled and bass -
Bigger not sure needed to be ....

Same flaws the ‘listening’ mic either answers to anything regardless of wake word - or you have to scream for it to hear you
On scale of 1-10 on understanding, maybe a 4 i articulate my words I do not us slang rarely contractions still gets it all wrong
Find lately I have to repeat my command up to three time before it is actually executed even though Alexa signals it did it ...

They are so concerned with either staying ahead of a curve or being the first the the simple single commands are left to rot an ruin - as a rule for what they charge for the ‘higher’ toy - not worth it stick to the least expensive of the group - maybe when they pull themselves together and make the simple commands flawless then and only then should they be considered worth of the prices the command for the upper toy - till then this is nothing but a kids toy that functions Maybe 40% of the time with out glitching on the simple commands - forget the more complex ones

I bought the dot to control a smart light in a bedroom. I also bought the new echo plus as a hub. I installed the echo, got the light up and running, and waited for the dot to arrive (I didn't order it soon enough to get it opening day).

The dot arrived, I plugged it in, and it was good to go - I didn't have to do anything. I just asked alexa to turn the light off and off it went. In the middle of the night I asked alexa to play a prime music "sleep" playlist I like, and it started right up. I know it can do much more, but those are the two most important things to me and they work great so far.

We decided to upgrade the Echo Dot in our bathroom because I could not hear it well enough, even at full volume, to listen to books or news while showering.

The new dot delivers much fuller sound and higher volumes from its little built-in speakers. Mission Accomplished! I can now listen to Kindle and Audible books or News Briefings (with variable volumes from one news source to another), even when in the shower.

The reason for four instead of five stars is because of two things that could be better:

1) The bass is too high, and I do not know how to adjust it. The lower frequencies overpower the upper and mid-tones. The dominant bass makes listening to books and news a little less pleasant, more difficult.

2) When using it to control lighting in the adjacent room, it does not understand us very well in spite of the wide opening between the rooms and no background noise. To be fair, it could be a quirky acoustic issue with these rooms. It's usable, but we have to work at getting it to understand us a bit more than we do with our other echo devices.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great speaker, not really useful outside of that for us
reviews.reviewText:
It seems to be the way of the world that we are going towards more home integration with technology. However some habits are just hard to break and I think that’s why we don’t use this so much. I got it in a deal when I bought my Blink cameras so it wasn’t something I specifically wanted.

We haven’t explored much of its features but again, we don’t really feel the desire to do so. Yea you can ask about weather, and news, and for it to tell you a joke, but that’s really it for us. We use it more to play our Amazon Music list than anything which it does quite well. Great sound.

It also has a habit of ruining surprises (Amazon gifts that arrive at the door) by telling my wife or son that the such and such item arrived. Definitely have to get to it before they do as far as that is concerned.

I’m sure people use these much more than we do but like I said, we’d much rather just use our phone to figure out things ourself. Anything that’s connected to this (lights, thermostats, etc) also have their own apps which don’t mishear my “commands”.

I’d only get one if they’re on sale and you’re interested in having an argument with it, lol.

Just got our 2nd & 3rd Echo Dots and so glad we caught them on sale for Prime Day! From alarms in the morning to sleep sounds at night, calling my teen to make sure he's doing his work cause he never answers his phone, to new features like house break-in detection. Everyone's sleeping better, my teen is setting reminders for his work, and I'm casting Baby Shark to whatever room my SO is in because I'm a horrible person.

The sound quality is great, much better than previous gens. You can actually turn off the microphone if you have privacy concerns. Apparently the break-in detection can hear stuff like breaking glass? Not sure I didn't look too much into it and I hope it never goes off if I break a plate or something but I thought it was a neat feature in a time where crime seems to happen more frequently.

Honestly though it was the drop-in feature that really sold me. I work a lot and even if a family member's phone is off or they're in the middle of something and can't reach their phone they can always easily answer the echo with their voice. I thought about going to Google Home mini but that's just not a feature they offer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent buy. Can't stop at just one!
reviews.reviewText: Absolutely love this. I bought several for my home including a sub, I use it every day. I know some people have a problem with the Amazon echo because they believe that Amazon is listening in and recording what they say, and I don't think this is exactly denied by Amazon either. The seems to make a lot of people nervous, however when you think about it it's not that much different from having your smartphone on you. Your smart phone can listen, and track you with GPS, what difference is it by having an echo in your house? If you want to get away from anyone that can listen, leave all electronics and take a walk in the woods. As far as this Echo goes, it works very very well. Sometimes, I have noticed that I need to word things a little bit differently in order to get the result I want, which seems a little silly, however I have acclimated quite well in order to get it to do what I want. For such a small little thing, it has an amazing speaker in it. It plays really really well, and with the echo subwoofer it is amazing. The only thing I've really noticed about the echo Dot, is that on max volume the speaker doesn't have as great of sound. But considering that max volume is absurdly loud anyways, I usually don't put it that high at all and I never have any issues with sound. I have also noticed that sometimes the echo doesn't want to give commands to other third-party apps such as robot vacuums, there's been a lot of problems with it. But nonetheless this has been an amazing device and I have been very pleased with it so far.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Speaker. With More Than 1 Dot I Have an Intercom System.
reviews.reviewText:
I ordered this 3rd gen Echo Dot and I already had an older Echo Dot.
They both synced up easy with the Alexa app. I can now use the Dots like intercoms with my kids, using the "drop-in" feature. I think that's neat, my kids... not so much, haha.
This 3rd gen Dot does have a better quality speaker.
I don't like that the plug is attached to the power cord on the 3rd gen Dots. My older Dot had a USB cord that plugged into the plug. That way you could plug the dot into any USB power supply.
Overall I'm happy with my newest Dot. I plan on eventually buying a couple more to place throughout the house.

reviews.reviewTitle: Echo is a combination of the unit, the app, and Alexa - so just regarding the unit:
reviews.reviewText:
We wanted to add another dot to the arsenal so I saw they had a 3rd gen for a good price. I replaced a 2nd edition that was in constant use in our bedroom with this one and relocated the old one. This “swap” matters because we’ve been using the bedroom one for a year and would immediately notice any differences.

Is it better than a 2nd edition? I think so, but the improvements are subtle. The speaker sounds different. The 2nd edition one sounded very “bare” and “hard” in comparison. The new one seems to have a speaker that sounds “softer” or maybe even a slight bit “muffled”, but we don’t have any problem hearing or understanding. I still wish that the audio was not transmitted in 360 degrees because most people probably aren’t placing these in the center of the room. I think the sound directed towards corners of the room is potentially wasted, but this speaker seems more powerful than the 2nd edition one so it doesn’t seem to be as much of a problem.

As I said before, the improvements are subtle, so I think the microphone is also improved. I think Alexa can hear and understand us a tiny bit better.

At the price I paid, it is definitely better to get a 3rd edition instead of a 2nd. I think 2nd edition works just fine and if you had no 3rd edition to compare it to you wouldn’t be upset at all.

So why the 4 stars and not 5? Because the app is garbage and Alexa is a huge pain in the butt. Case in point, I set up this Echo using my phone. We had some trouble because it would only play samples of songs. We figured it was tied to my account and not my wife’s (who had the Music Unlimited plan tied to hers). We both checked in the app and the device said it was associated with my account on my phone, and HER account on her phone! We both share the same prime membership, so I’m not even sure why this matters, but it does. After two attempts to set it up with her phone it finally seems to play music unlimited.

The worst part of it is how dumb Alexa is. She can’t even tell you which account the device you’re talking to is registered to: “I’m sorry, I don’t know that one.” She doesn’t know, and the app wants it to be registered to everyone - which is a nice gesture, but just not true.

I’ve explained in some depth the problems with Alexa, but to paraphrase: NOT SMART. If Alexa was capable of more than one command at a time and had a longer memory than Dory, it would be a drastic improvement. You can read my other Echo review for more details: https://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-reviews/R1N696ZHMO7CL0/ref=cm_cr_getr_d_rvw_ttl?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B0749WVS7J

This unit, compared to 2nd generation Dot is 4 stars.
Amazon App: 1 star
Alexa: 2 stars

Received the Gen 3 Dot today, set it up, and tried it out. My experience up to this point has been with a Gen 1 Dot have had on my nightstand for years and recently a Gen 2 Dot. The Gen 3 is the worst of the three, but first a little base-lining.

You primarily buy an Echo Dot if you plan on attaching speakers whether wired or wireless. If you plan to use the device standalone with even an inkling of playing music, then you should go with one of the larger Echos and not the Dots as regardless of the Dot, the sound isn't going to be good. Dots = external speakers or news, full-size Echos = everything.

The worst thing I've found with the Gen 3 that the other two generations didn't have is a buzzing when turned off (not playing anything). There's a buzzing through the speakers. Thing is, I also bought a Gen 2 Echo and it does the same thing. There's a buzzing, even when the volume is low, coming through the speakers regardless of whether the speakers are external or internal. it's something inherent to the latest devices/hardware. it's terribly annoying and I can only assume something is wrong with the devices. As mentioned, neither the Gen 1 or Gen 2 devices have this problem.

The buzzing is annoying as heck and the only way to "stop" it is to either play something or turn the volume down low on the external speaker, but then everything is lower. To stop the buzzing, I turned down my speakers so that what now must play at a Volume 5 on the Gen 3 Dot is equal to what the Gen 1/2 did at Volume 2. When it comes to the full-size Echo, there's nothing you can do. It just buzzes even when at a low volume.

The other thing I've noticed is that the Gen 1 and Gen 2 were far more sensitive and responsive than the Gen 3 Dot. I could speak at what I consider a normal volume regardless of what was playing and the Gen 1/2 heard me. Not so for the Gen 3. i also have to slow down to let the Gen 3 Alexa catch up to what I'm saying which wasn't a problem with the Gen1/2.

I can only assume that there's just something wrong with the device. I may give it another day or two in the event a patch was released, but at this time, the device seems defective because of the buzzing.

reviews.reviewTitle: ALEXA...change the toilet paper roll? A GIRLS WISH
reviews.reviewText: This came on time and had a .99 price tag, so... I took a chance. NOW I SEE why everyone loves this. Haha, I have used ALEXA to settle arguments with my fiancé, asked her how to spell something, find fantastic music. I hook her up to my portable UE speaker and head-bang to METALICA! Spa music for yoga....Yeah I know....odd combo....it takes all kinds🤪 I’m not ready to ask her to order things because I’m still learning...lol. THANKS AMAZON as I would have never tried this w/out the promo! If your reading this, don’t even hesitate....JUST BUY IT!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Good improvement in audio, but it comes at a price
reviews.reviewText:
I have three Echo Dots in use in my house, two of them on small "outlet shelves" that are built to hold small smart speakers.

The Echo Dot v2 speakers work great with those shelves, as they can use a small USB power port to cut down on cable mess and not block one of the outlet plugs.

The Echo Dot v3 is a little bit bigger, and while it just barely fits on the shelf, it does NOT use a USB power supply, and the included power supply is big enough to block one of the outlet ports and you can only do so much to compact a 6 foot power cable to fit in the 8 inch distance from the plug to the back of the speaker.

Function-wise, the v3 is a great improvement. The sound is louder and has more range.

Design-wise, you sacrifice the "fits anywhere" and USB-powerability of the v2.

reviews.reviewTitle: Really great, but still has some problems
reviews.reviewText:
We have 3 in my house. They work well with my SmartThings, they play Pandora, they do quick math, conversions, answer simple questions, etc.

When they lose their internet connection for whatever reason, (or Amazon is having server trouble) any time you say "Alexa", they ding and say "I'm having trouble understanding you right now" which is super frustrating, and I wish they would say whether it's a local connection problem or a server problem, but I guess it's not an all-the-time thing.

They are usually great about identifying where I am, but on occasion I'll be standing right next to one when I ask for something and one in a different room will answer me instead.

Adding things to lists with my voice is very easy. Sometimes they don't get the words quite right, but it's usually close enough that I know what it was supposed to be when she repeats it back or I look at it on the app. Removing things from lists with my voice, however, is a real challenge. If it's a one-word thing, usually no problem. Two words is difficult but possible. 3 or more words and you're better off checking it off in the app.

Wish we could rename her to something custom, instead of their default set of options, but I get that programming wake words isn't trivial.

Can't talk about her without her trying to answer. In my house we call her by a different name when we're talking about her than when we're talking to her. Early on we figured out if you talk about her casually she can have some pretty big misunderstandings and almost sent messages to some old contacts and ordered things on Amazon.

reviews.reviewTitle: FAULTY broke after 60 days. DO NOT BUY! 2
reviews.reviewText: Bought this one In May of this year. Yesterday it just kept spinning the blue light NO LONGER WORKS. Not even 2 months since purchase. I have bought a total of 5 echo dots. The ones from 2017 still going strong. I bought 3 new generation this year. Two still working. Because this one died after only 2 months I will NOT ever buy another ECHO dot. TIME to move to google! Oh I can't return the faulty one due to 30 day return policy. Less than 24 hours after the 1st 3rd generation echo dot died another one bit the dust. I now have only ONE 3rd generation left. DO NOT BUY these they quit after only two months! No return policy rotten to the core

Where to even begin.... i bought two dots with a smart plug bundle deal going on for Cyber Monday and it’s been the best purchase I’ve had since god knows when. I have one dot in my living room connected with a smart plug controlling my lamp and another dot in my bedroom, connected with a smart power strip controlling my heater, electric blanket, lamp, and pretty string lights. I’m able to tell Alexa to turn on/off all of these devices. I can even set routines like turn my heater on, electric blanket on, and lights off with one phrase. Like how cool is that??? Other than that I don’t use too many functions with Alexa other than some voice commands and having her tell the weather/set reminders/play relaxing music for me. There’s still so much more you can do with the dot but even with these few functions I use, I am more than happy with the price I paid. Also the speaker is great for the size of it and it can hear your commands from pretty far away

reviews.reviewTitle: It's all fun and games until the power cord comes loose
reviews.reviewText: Okay I'm really hoping that Amazon customer service will read this review because I actually sent back my first Echo 3rd gen that I bought because when I played music occasionally it would just get very distorted and start sounding like one of the speakers was blown basically. If anybody's ever had a blown speaker you know what that sounds like and it sounds horrible. Well we sent back the device and received a replacement only to have the replacement a few days later start doing the exact same thing. Now my logical brain deduced quickly that the two devices could not both be damaged because that was too much of a coincidence. So after tinkering with it for a while my wife and I figured out that if the power cord on the 3rd gen Echo becomes a little loose it starts distorting the speaker sound very badly. So hopefully that's an issue you guys are already aware of if not maybe I can bring it to your attention right now, but that is definitely an issue that happens. so ever since we have mounted are device on the ceiling and the cord is securely connected to the mounts and will not become loose anymore we have not had this issue, but this could be a serious problem for all the customers who are buying these devices and then just thinking that they're crap and sending them back now I love you guys Amazon so I knew that was not the case so I had to figure that out but I just wanted to let anyone else know that this is an amazing product I love it very much but if you start having that distortion of the sound problem like I was check your power cord and make sure it is securely plugged in.

reviews.reviewTitle: The entire Echo system has changed for the worst...
reviews.reviewText:
I changed my review from 5 stars to 1 star because of a software update that now forces me to specify which light, power strip, and/or other devices I want to turn on/off. All of my rooms, lights, power strips, etc... are in various groups for a reason. Each light, outlet, and other devices have a unique name (IE: The upstairs hallway lights are named UH-Light, UH-Light2, and UH-Light 3, my smart power strip has unique ports like TV, Monitors, etc..).

YESTERDAY (9/18/2019) I was able to walk into a room and say "Alexa, turn the light on" (in my home office for example) and it turns the light on, Today (9/19/2019) I'm sitting in my home office and I say "Alexa turn the light off" and I get the response "There are multiple devices that share that name, which one do you want".

The master bedroom - Setup with only lights (MBR-light, or something like that so I can identify it later when adding other stuff), the wife used to say "Alexa, turn the light off" because that's what she has always said before going to sleep. Today she can't do that because of Amazon's development team.

So I say "Alexa turn the office light off" and it turns the ENTIRE OFFICE GROUP OFF. So now I have to go to the app to turn the light off.

I reached out to Amazon customer support who tells me I have to be specific when asking the echo to turn the light off as in "Alexa, turn the office light off/on" and that it has always been this way. When I tried to tell them that yesterday I was able to say "Turn the light off" they said it wasn't possible and I have always had to be specific.

I set up groups for a reason, that being I can go into a room, say "Alexa, turn the light on" without having to remember each light bulb name or what I named the room/group. Yes, I know what the group names are, I don't expect everyone in my house to remember the group names.

There was a software/firmware update overnight that broke all of my Echo's and Amazon's customer support will not acknowledge it.

I will not recommend this device to anyone else until they put it back to the way it was.

My wife refuses to let me use this in the main part of our home so the three I purchased have been quarantined to my personal spaces. I spend most of my working day in my shop with my hands dirty and hence the reason for my original purchase. I was constantly having to take my gloves of to change what I was listen to on Sirius XM but not anymore.

All of my laptops and phones are Apple and I stopped using Siri long ago because it's basically junk. Anytime you ask her a question she says she doesn't know or just directs you to a webpage. Alexa on the other hand will actually answer you questions which is amazing! We also recently purchased an Emerson smart thermostat which I was easily able to connect and can now control the temp with ease. Alexa is also such better at understanding me when compared with Siri.

For me the biggest down side of Alexa is that I don't believe it has the ability to send text messages from my iPhone which is a big bummer.

The audio is about a 6/10 so that could be a bit better as well. I still use my Bose portable speaker to listen to music.

reviews.reviewTitle: I thought this was a Waste of money until I got a call
reviews.reviewText:
I have decided to edit my review for a few reasons, 1 the day after I posted my review I had a very nice and helpful person that works at Amazon call me, after asking a few questions they helped me figure out alot of the things that I was told wasnt available. I couldnt believe it, it made me happy again to be able to do some of the things I purchased the dots for in the first place. But then I got upset again. What if I would have never posted a review? I would still be thinking that they didnt work. How come we dont have someone call or email or atleast text us to see if the dot or other Amazon product is living up to expectations. Shouldn't this be required. But this is a review not a blog. I would suggest that if you have or are going to purchase an Alexa device contact the alexa department with any questions because they are the only ones really trained and can give the correct answer! Like I stated earlier I am happy with my dots now, I still feel a little work has to be done but that is true to any device that is still developing! This starts my original review, You really need to look at all the things that this can do, you really don't even need to waste the money to purchase, just download Alexa on your phone. It doesnt really do much more than that. We purchased them because we seen where it can control your fire TV with the echo dot, well let's just say that isnt 100 percent accurate. Yes it can control SOME things on your fire TV, however these aren't really the main things. You CANNOT control the volume, power, you CANNOT search your prime videos, let me just give a list of what it can do that would be alot less time consuming.
So the only things that you can control with the echo dot are Bravo now CBS NBC Hulu and the playstation network that is it! Now granted I'm sure I'm going to get alot of heat for dissing this device. And I am sorry, I know it has taken people alot of time and energy to get where it is today, I just feel that selling it at the price it is, it should really be able to do atleast what the remote Alexa can do. And yes it is my fault for just assuming that one Amazon device can control just like another device I should have read deeper into it. My fault, one that i wont be making again! Please take my advice and look into what it can do before you buy. Go the cheaper way and just download Alexa on your phone or tablet! The only good thing is I can command whatever music that I would like to listen to because we pay for a subscription to Amazon music. Is anyone else seeing a theme here, it will control paid apps easily, just not the free ones!
