Just sad that we have to be taken for our money like that, it's not good enough that we pay top dollar for devices but we pay for subscriptions to 3 or 4 different apps.

reviews.reviewTitle: Doesn't support local music/audiobooks and can't communicate with Fire TV.
reviews.reviewText:
These are two really huge DUH! missing features. I've had a NAS (network attached storage) with all of my music, movies, tv, audiobooks, etc, stored on it for decades now. It's all distributed by DLNA - an industry standard supported off the shelf by everybody. I should be able to ask Alexa to play my own music from my own house - without paying more fees to stream a subscription service that STILL won't have my music on it. I want Alexa to play audiobooks I already own without paying for another subscription to an audiobook rental service.

I also want Alexa to control my Fire TV. The Fire TV has an Alexa remote! I can see the TV in my kitchen, where this Alexa device is, and I want Alexa to play a TV show or movie on it. Two Amazon products, can't even communicate with each other.

Those two are the biggest complaints about stuff that's missing that I expected to work.

What's also frustrating is what barely works. If your music choices are very pedestrian, it's nice to say "play some 80s music" and let it go in the background. It's better than FM radio. Really though this shows how poor this option is - the selection is really shallow and repeats songs. There were 230 songs from that decade just counting the ones to hit #1 on Billboard. That's an entire day of listening to music just playing number one hits. Expand that to the top 40 or top 100, you could play 80s music for a month without hearing repeats. We should be able to give complicated commands to our voice servants like "play every top 100 hit from the 1980s in order". It's all databases, these are easy queries! pssh

If you want to hear something very specific, good luck. Try to play classical music or opera by a specific performance, nope, too much detail confuses Alexa. If a performer has multiple versions of a song (on a live album and a studio album, for example) Alexa plays the first one she finds. Songs that have been covered by multiple performers, expect to never hear the one you want. Don't expect to hear any song that has non-English lyrics, if you can get Alexa to play artists from outside the USA/UK/Can/Aus English-speaking world at all.

There's also the issue of being so rude to mispronounce my name and not being able to correct it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great add on Alexa for rooms where you don't listen to much music
reviews.reviewText:
Personal Experience:
This was a give away during Amazon prime day and I placed it in my basement where my kids like to play. The Alexa integration is great and it was an easy add on because I already had an Alexa account setup. The only negative is that this unit is not the best at playing music compared with the bigger units. Recommend:
Yes

Small form factor
Smart Home Features

Not the best sound for music in larger gathering rooms like Living Room

reviews.reviewTitle: I only regret not buying more!
reviews.reviewText:
I absolutely love Amazon products and the echo dot is no exception. You can ask Alexa anything and she will answer it as much as she can, and if she cannot find the right answer, she will tell you that she doesn't know instead of just listing off things related to the subject you are referring to. You can send her commands to announce things which is very cool, she does have an explicit filter by the way, so the profanities you try to get her to say get bleeped out. Ask for any song or artist and she will immediately connect with Amazon music to start streaming what you are looking for. She'll turn up or down the volume for you, and she has very good hearing, she can even hear you from other rooms or if you are speaking very quietly. My only regret is that I did not buy more of them!
Update: since I posted this review I have purchased 2 more, and it amazing. I have one in my bedroom, one in the living room, and one in the playroom/workout room. You can create a group for them so that you can effect all devices! For example: my groups name is everywhere for the echo dots, if I say 'Alexa, play Metallica everywhere' Metallica will start playing on all devices. You can even give each one it's own name. The one in my living room is named 'living room' and the one in the bedroom is named 'bed'. I can be sitting in the living room and say 'Alexa, announce to bed, it's time to get up' and the echo dot in the bedroom will play the recording of my voice telling my girlfriend to wake up. You can even set up your own questions and answers in the Alexa app so it can literally do whatever. I absolutely love these devices.
I apologise for the mess in the video, some rearranging is going on.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's basically a sexier looking gen 2 with marginally better sound
reviews.reviewText:
I'm just going to get straight to it and give you some important pros and cons. However, if you don't want to read my entire review, when considering all my thoughts on Gen 3 Dot, I still absolutely recommend everyone own one.

Pros:

- Setup start to finish, out of the box to ready is less than 3 minutes.
- Gen 3 looks substantially nicer then Gen 2.
- The speaker is improved from Gen 2. With that said, the bass is still laughable. However mids and highs are much improved and push well rather than screeching at high volume.
- If you actually explore the vast skills Alexa can do and what Dot excels at, this unit can do a great deal and absolutely be useful from day to day. From updates on Amazon orders, to ordering from Dot, to playing music, or setting an alarm and then having Alexa tell you about your day, this unit can do a great deal and do it well.

There are many more pros but nobody wants to read a novel so I chose what's most important.

Cons:

- When you set this up, if you do it on your phone, you need to exercise caution doing so if you don't want Alexa to have your entire contact list. If you give that permission, your entire list will be in the cloud. Just a heads up.
- Alexa can make calls with Gen 3 Dot, and the process is flawless. However, if you actually expect to have a conversation with someone, you had better turn the volume up very near max, or they will not hear you. Also, there is lag between parties on the call and I've verified that a half dozen times.
- Alexa still struggles with certain words, phrases, obscure songs, and questions, if you don't word them in specific manners. Given, as you use your Dot, Alexa will adjust to you and get better, but it can be frustrating even for someone like me who's a technology freak.
- Alexa often mistakes you when you say to adjust sound down and instead adjusts it up. This fades after you've said the phrase a dozen or so times.

As with the pros, I could go on and on, but nobody wants to read a novel so I picked the most important factors to help you make an informed decision.

Look, in many ways, for many people, Alexa products, specifically Dot, are used mostly as toys. A lot of people play with them a few weeks or months and gradually give up on them. Why? Usually, because they lack patience working through the kinks in the interface and also because they simply never explore the thousands of skills this can perform.

So my question to you is do you consider this a fun toy or do you consider it an exciting technology with a lot to offer? If you consider it a toy, just save a few bucks and buy a used Gen 2 used, for under $20. If you consider it a useful technology and plan to seriously explore its possibilities, I absolutely recommend this as a way to get your feet wet or to add to your Alexa connected devices. Yes, this is still a technology with a long way to go, but it's worth owning and growing with!

Cheers!

I was able to get a new Echo Dot 3 right before Christmas. It has been even better than I expected ! Setup was very easy and quick. I was also able to pair my Dish Hopper to the Dot. Now I can just say, "Alexa ! Change the channel to ESPN" and it gets there quicker than I could pick up the remote and change the channel ! For someone that has had a stroke and losing the use of my right arm and hand this is really useful for me. I love to play music while I get ready for the day. I usually use an app on my Bluray player which is time consuming just to get the first song played. Now all I have to do is say,"Alexa ! Play Thumbs Up radio " and bam! it's playing that fast ! I can check on the weather before I leave the house in an instant. The sound quality of the Dot 3 amazed me from the moment I first heard it. From the reviews I've read, it's obvious that most people don't understand that some rooms just don't carry sound very well.The unit is kind of heavy for such a small item which I assume is because of the magnet of a much better speaker than previous Dots. I don't know how anyone could complain about the sound quality of the Dot 3 considering how small it is. Some people complain about everything. Just keep that in mind before deciding not to buy this because of a bad review. Ten years ago this item would have cost you thousands. This item is well worth the price.Like anything electrical or mechanical,you have to learn how to use it and then how to best use it for your needs. It really isn't hard. If my wife was using this the first day then I can tell you, it has to be easy.I will be buying more Dots since I have learned that you can place a unit in another room and use as an intercom. Nothing so small and costs so little can do as much as the Echo Dot 3.

I always wanted to have an echo, but so stingy to buy for myself. My brother in law loves to listen to music, so I decided to get him a 2nd gen Echo and 2nd Gen Echo Dot. I’m really amazed with the quality of sound. A month later, I bought another 2nd gen Echo that came with 3rd gen Echo dot For $99+. I gave the Echo to my brother in laws mom for her birthday and kept the Echo dot.

At first, I thought the voice command is awkward but I got used to it. I use my Echo dot to listen to music, ask for forecast, news, timer, and ask some general questions to Alexa if I’m lazy to look it up on the internet.

I also leave Echo dot playing all day for my kitten so he won’t feel sad. We leave him all day alone at home whenever we go to work. I can also control Alexa from my phone like play audio books or music.

The downside:
I hate it when Alexa can’t undersrand my accent. Yes, English is not my first language. So it’s annoying whenever I ask Alexa to play songs from an artist in my home country. I have to say the vowels and consonants in American Way instead of how I would pronounce it on my native language just so Alexa would understand me.

Also, amazon says Alexa gets smarter, but i think only if they add new apps instead of intuitively adapting to your commands. Like for example, I wanted to Alexa to play certain songs on repeat on Spotify but she will say that the feature is not supported. I can still play songs on repeat but I have to open the Alexa app on my phone and press the repeat button for that particular song that I just played. Anyway, this is just me who loves to play a song over and over again.

Another thing is, if you turn up the volume too loud, Alexa will have a hard time hearing you. The only way is to shout so she can listen to your voice command.

I would recommend Echo Dot to everyone. As a matter of fact, I bought 6 pieces last Black Friday for a good deal so I can give them as gift for Christmas. But I needed to another 2 again after Black Friday without the promo.

I also gifted Echo Dot (2nd generation) to a couple of friends, which is a bit cheaper. I needed it the next day but Amazon ran out of stocks of Echo dot 3rd so ended up buying the 2nd gen Echo dot.

I also own google home, but i think the Echo dot 3rd gen is better.

reviews.reviewTitle: Definitely worth the price!! Fun little addition to Alexa.
reviews.reviewText:
I've been thinking about ordering an Echo for ages. I've recently purchased a Ring Doorbell and decided to finally pick a couple up so that I could put one on each floor of my house, link them with my Alexa, and have one on each floor therefore beign able to hear my Ring device wherever I am.
Anyway, first Amazon is running an amazing deal! I purchased two at $25!!!
The sound quality is good. I guess it could be a little louder, but there's a lot of sound coming out of that little cylinder. I can hear my doorbell and it's loud enough for my whole daycare to have a dance party, so what more could you really want?!?!
We liked them so much my oldest asked for one for his room. At $25 I didn't hesitate.
Probably my favorite feature is the "announce" feature. I can tell Alexa to announce anything and she will repeat my message through all the other devices in the house. No more up and down three flights of stairs to ask someone to take the garbage out!!
To sum it up, the Echo is definitely worth the price and has rejuvenated my whole family's interest in the Alexa we've had for 4 or 5 years.

It's very disappointing to only give the Echo Dot and Alexa a 3-star rating, because I had high expectations. I was first introduced to smart speakers when I received an insignia smart speaker for Christmas in a dirty Santa game. I was instantly hooked on the whole concept. I've been an Amazon member for years and I have much trust in the Amazon brand, so I thought I would be upgrading by purchasing an Echo. Sadly, I've found that Alexa and the Echo device are outdone by a cheap Insignia device and Google Assistant.
As far as the Google Assistant smart technology goes, I've found that Google is able to do a few things that Alexa cannot. For one, Google's accent can be changed to alternative accents of the english language and can still understand you and produce results from questions pertaining to region. I personally prefer the Australian/New Zealand accent to the American, but Alexa often didn't respond to her name and couldn't perform features such as the weather, making phone calls, etc. when her language was changed to Australian. While the next feature is actually a comparison of Spotify to Amazon Music, I found that Alexa's ability to find playlists and find a wide range of music paled in comparison to Google. For instance, when asked to play a song, Alexa simply finds the song and plays it, while Google finds the song then continues to play recommended music based off that song. As far as the actual device goes, the Insignia, which costs about $40, features a visible clock and a usb port for charging other devices, while devices with Alexa that feature a clock cost close to $100, and I am unaware of one that has a usb charge port.
In truth, the only feature of Alexa that I really prefer to Google is the wake word. "Alexa" rolls off the tongue better than "Hey Google," but this is hardly a game-changer.
Hopefully, Amazon will step it up and update her abilities, especially when it comes to language.

reviews.reviewTitle: An absolutely excellent smart speaker with so many great functions.
reviews.reviewText:
Well, I had a very awesome Cyber Monday! Though I only bought one thing, it was definitely a doozy! It is nothing less than Amazon's own smart speaker, connected to one of the best virtual assistants that I have used, Alexa! (I realize now this statement doesn't carry much weight because there's only four major ones, but I will now say that this is the best I've used, due to its ability to do pretty much everything I can think of, and ease of access - I can just talk and it works! (This is also true of Cortana, but Alexa is not dependent on a large, heavy-power-drawing device like a computer running Windows to be usable, so Alexa wins.)

Alexa can answer pretty much any question that may come to mind, though there are a few that still haven't occurred to her, but that is fast changing due to crowd-sourced reviews and feedback that are easily provided for every interaction! And that's even before I mentioned the thousands of skills, reminders, timers and routines and all sorts of awesome things that the assistant can do. And all when you say her wake word which just happens to be Alexa (though I am authoring this with a text-to-speech program, I must type the assistant's name to avoid awakening her so many times :) ).

The device itself is pretty elegant, as you can see my picture and video. It's grown up quite a bit from the second generation which I have never had, but it is larger and heavier, and has a big old band of cloth around it instead of it being plastic with the Amazon logo. There are four buttons on top: two for adjusting volume, one to perform some kind of action which might actually double for using the wake word; I'm not sure yet, and one to mute the microphones, of which there are four of the far-field variety, which enable the speaker to hear your voice even when it is far away and rather quiet, or when music or other audio is playing through the speaker itself! That's pretty awesome.

So many other people have talked about the virtual assistant, Alexa, that I will not waste time here, because I'm mainly here to talk about the speaker itself. And I will close by saying, I'm not really concerned about a proprietary power solution over a USB solution, though I am aware that some inconvenience can exist when one cannot use power adapters one already has. Doesn't affect me, though. And the speaker is actually quite loud, probably potentially the loudest Bluetooth-enabled speaker that I've heard, and sounds wonderful pretty much no matter what is played through it!

I most definitely recommend the Amazon Echo Dot third-generation! In your color of choice, though the Sandstone does look very snazzy :-) thank you, Amazon for providing us all a wonderful and affordable entry into the exciting world of virtual assistants and the Alexa infrastructure! I will treasure it forever. And, who knows? I may kit my house out with at least a couple more before holidays are out.

(EDIT: As a side note, I just played back the short video I linked above, and Alexa woke up again and gave me several varieties of cheese. She's just that awesome.)

AMAZON. I was mad at you for a while because you rejected a nice review of a company who sold me a great product so I vowed never to write another glowing review but I am SO happy at my purchase that I just had to share.

I have to admit that I am the kind of person who is overly suspicious of "big brother" listening in but I took a chance while the dots are on sale and boy am I so glad I did. This dot is the best! I now have several scattered throughout my house, and love all the features it has to offer:

The first thing I did after installing was ask Aleksa to play some holiday music. BOOM. There it was. In really great quality considering the size of the speakers. Wow. Then I started exploring, finding out all that Alexa has to offer. I asked for the weather, the meaning of life, and whether my husband is still cheating on me (Alexa said "Hmmm, I don't know) so the jury's still out. Next I discovered Alexa's skills. The kids can now ask where Santa is and get a very personalized answer. They love asking Alexa questions, and my daughter even said Alexa you are beautiful to which she responded "and so are you, you are so beautiful" so she is winning over our hearts. With the new "announcement" feature that targets specific devices I told me husband my new favorite hobby is scaring the kids when they think I don't know they're really up playing games when they're supposed to be in bed. And finally, I drift off to sleep using this guided meditation skill I enabled. I have not slept so good in many years. Thank you.

There are a few drawbacks- my youngest son is named "Aleksa" which is pronounced slightly differently but still is enough to trigger the echo. But we will be changing the wake-up word via the app which is super helpful. I also notice that with our shoddy internet that of more than 1 person is using Wifi than the speaker cuts off but that is not Alexa's fault. Also, it is a bit creepy what this speaker is "hearing" in our household but to be honest I don't really think anyone would care about our personal life as we are as boring as all get out.

Overall, despite my initial qualms this speaker is everything to me, and I can't wait to purchase more. I'm not paid by amazon, nor do I have any financial reasons whatsoever to write such a glowing review but THANK YOU for this great device. You rock Amazon!

Was given this as a gift, hadn't really wanted one, but since we are using a lot of Tplink smart home outlets and cameras to smarten up our home, I said I would give it a try. Aside from using it as just a Bluetooth speaker it is more of a novelty than anything. Sound quality is decent for a small speaker playing music, although the first day I using it the play back got all staticy and distorted and I had to unplug and re-plug it in to get the quality back. I do have to say compared to Siri I think Alexa wins as far as being able to understand, enabling different skills that she can learn, like starting my wifes Chrysler Pacifica, enabling her to be able to understand Pandora, using the Tplink products for controlling our house. However when she doesn't understand, you might as well have taken the phone out of your pocket or if it is already in your hand hit a few buttons and done what you wanted to in the first place, cause it would of been easier and a lot quicker. Sometimes I have to tell her 3 times to turn on a light cause either she didn't hear me over the background noise or she just didn't understand which device to turn on. I haven't yet been amazed or wowed or said that she has made my life any easier.

I have an echo dot gen 3 in my 3rd flr bedroom, a (FB) portal in my 2nd flr living room, and a second echo dot gen 3 in my 1st flr guest room... all connected to Alexa.
Likes: so many! (I’ve only had my dots for a few weeks, so I’m still discovering things.)
- Blends seamlessly into my black furniture
- The ability to set reminders/alarms, and to create shopping/to-do lists
- The sleep/ambient sounds (Brown noise is my favorite!)
- The ability to get weather reports, news, my daily schedule, etc.
- The option to go into DND/do-not-listen modes
- It can connect to my Lexus (although I haven’t set it up yet)
- Bought an electrical outlet accessory & was able to set up timers for my x-mas lights
- LOVE the Drop-in feature. It’s like having an intercom throughout my house.
- Notifications: really liked being alerted to my Amazon package deliveries
+ more...
Dislikes:
- Four times now I’ve had to repeat myself multiple times when turning on & off the ambient sounds. It registers that it hears the command, but nothing plays. Or, it refers to the ambient sounds menu instead of turning off the sound playing.
- On the 3rd flr it has lost connection twice to my WiFi on the 3rd floor (likely due to the WiFi signal strength). I had to reset the connection in the Alexa app each time, which was annoying.
- I wish the volume was louder when playing music from my iPhone. I tried it once and ended up just connecting to my sound bar instead. It’s still decent quality sound and apparently improved from previous versions from the reviews that I’ve read.
Side note: The first time that an Alexa commercial comes on and they activate, it’s pretty hilarious. It also activates when similar words pop up in the background, but I just tell it to shut off. (Has only happened a few times.)
Overall, I love the functionality and wish I’d purchased sooner.

reviews.reviewText: This is piece of device Is not worth it. I had this device I couple of days I had to reset ever since. I was on the online customer service for five dam hours trying to help me Connect the device, they weren’t help at all, not one bit. So the next day he was helpful. But could not connect to all my tv. Apparently only one tv is the main tv which “ sucks”. Alexa comes on in the middle of the night which again sucks, you have to tell it shut down, thank God I don’t have sleeping baby the way I was yelling at a piece of device. Tonight I come home 8/16. Ask Alexa to play so @jazz, again having trouble connecting to the WiFi... this device “SUCKS “ big time thank god I didn’t pay a lot of money on it. Trying to reconnect with your WiFi is hell especially from your phone. Not happy about this piece of crap. Don’t buy this crap don’t believe the hype . I am soooooo dam disappointed in This product, I buy lots of this from amazon but this here crap, to dam piss. On this, they just need to send me another one without me sending this one back. I have never had so much trouble of setting up anything with WiFi.

Have an original echo and about 5 echo dots around the house. Had some of them for years now. This one is the best of the echo dot ones for then bedroom. I cleared my nightstand and removed my clock and the old echo dot along with some cables and stuffs. It looks clean, neat, and classy. We got 2, 1 for each nightstand. The room looks darker since the clock light dims based on how bright it is in the room. They can be linked as a music group and the sound is much better than the 2nd generation echo dots. It sounds quite nice while both are playing. The display show not only the time, but if the alarm is on, and the temperature if you ask Alexa for it. You can select the alarm sound, but that is for all of them. I traded one of the old echo dots for $5, but got also a 25% on another echo dot with clock for my daughter's room to minimize the clutter there. You can enable Freetime and block explicit filters so it works out nicely. Would totally recommend.

I live in a townhouse with an open kitchen/living room area. We keep Alexa hanging from a wallmount (highly recommended to minimize wires and space) in the living room. I love that I can tell her to add things to different "lists" I've created while I'm cooking, straightening up, watching TV, etc. Super convenient to then access my lists (grocery store, dollar store, pet store, etc) when I'm out and about. Much easier than keeping track of all the scraps of paper I used to carry around in my purse.

I know about the privacy concerns and couldn't care less. If someone is listening in on my conversations, then I feel sorry for them. I know my life is boring, so to listen in on my boring life must be just painful.

Downside: My husband and I have been spooked more than once. When talking, she'll butt in our conversation with some pretty creepy comments - even when we haven't said a word that even slightly resembles her name. More than a little disturbing. But hey, we're living in a sci-fi book now, so there's bound to be some troubles, right?

reviews.reviewTitle: Alexa CAN be used in Muliple location and still be connected
reviews.reviewText: I set up the echo dots in my house and my store, they are connected to the same Alexa app and can control anything that is on your wireless network from any location. (someone had posted that they can't) At home, I integrated my wireless plugs, Arlo camera, wireless locks, and garage door opener seamlessly. In each echo dot and/or show you can set the device address/location so it will give you the correct weather for that area and driving and traffic and so on for that location. It is done in the Alexa app, under that device. Overall I give the connectivity and usability a 10. I am still learning the commands and the abilities that you can assign to it, but best of all you can use the 'drop-in' command to talk to any Amazon device - we use it to talk from my house to the store - works just like a phone, and a good way to scare someone if they don't know you can do this. Also, you can send a voice message to any of the devices, such as 'I am on my way home.' very useful as a worldwide intercom or calling device. I set future reminders by just telling Alexa to remind me on a certain date and time, very handy.

Either I received a defective gen 3 dot or the new design fails to improve at all upon the Echo dot gen 2. In either case, my gen 3 echo is so useless I don't even use it. It's now in a box in my cupboard. Examples: I had my gen 3 dot next to me in the living room and when I would ask it something, my gen 2 dot in the bedroom would respond and the gen 3 would not even activate. (Yes, I have the settings set for nearest dot.) Next, no matter what I seem to ask the gen 3 dot except for time and weather, it can never find the answer. It's almost like it has no access to resources. Yet my Echo Dot 2nd gen can find pretty much everything I'm looking for. My last complaint is that the "new and improved" speaker actually sounds muddy no matter where I place it, both for voice and music. My recommendation is to go with the Echo Dot 2nd Gen - lower price, better quality.

reviews.reviewTitle: You should have one in every room
reviews.reviewText:
The Echo Dot is very handy! I have several, placed in different rooms around my house. As I am going about my day and remember I need to add an item to my shopping list, I simply say, "Alexa add eggs, milk and cheese to my list." and she does. I can retrieve it later at the store, just by opening my Alexa app. There are so many things you can do with Alexa besides making lists and playing music. I also have the Fire Cube, and several smart home controls. They all work together with Alexa seemlessly. So, no more trying to find remotes that never seem to make it back where they are supposed to be. I can turn on my living room cable, TV and sound bar with just one command. Alexa can change channels, turn on lights, ceiling fans and control devices in other rooms with just my voice command. I'm also excited about the future prospects of the beta "Let's Chat" social bot. In the future, it may prove to be valuable for persons who are not able to get out, or even the elderly who are lonely.
I downloaded the IFTT app and the Mastermind app, and now I can even ask her to read and write emails. When I hear the familiar "ding" that signifies my phone has received a text, I simply ask her and she will read the text message (my phone can stay in my purse)! That means, I can work at home without the distraction of my cell phone, but still receive important messages. I feel like I have a personal assistant following me around! It is awesome. I also love the little pod-like look of the Echo and I love the sound quality!

reviews.reviewTitle: echo dot gen 3 way better than gen 1 or 2
reviews.reviewText:
I have owned and do own several amazon echo/fire products ranging from the gen 2 echo dot to the echo plus. I have owned the amazon tap too. I currently have three echo devices and a fire tv. I have and do enjoy all of them. I primarily use the echo devices for smart home voice control but do use them for other things such as music, timers, searching the net for questions and such.

The new echo dot (3rd gen) is leaps and bounds better than the 2nd gen dot. Setting up is a breeze if you don't have mac filtering turned on your wifi router. This is something that Amazon should make readily available on a sticker on the echo or inside the box or something. That complicated things for my setup. I had to turn off mac filtering to get the dot setup so I could then use the app to get the mac address and then add it to the mac filter and then turn mac filtering back on. If I were able to have the mac address before setting it up, I could have just added it to the filter and then setup would have been way easier for me. Not everyone has this turned on so it may not be an issue for you. Just be aware of this before starting your setup and you'll be fine. The rest is just like any other echo device. Except the sound is leaps and bounds better than its predecessors.

If you are into echo devices, I would highly recommend this over the older generations of dots. It was packaged well, easy to setup for standard configurations, easy to use and sounds really good too.

I was gifted my first Echo Dot 3rd Gen for Mother's Day. It was very easy to set up and within mins I had Alexa ready to help me. I asked questions Alexa answered. I had her play my music (pandora was easy to set up on the phone app) she played it and the sound was great. The voice control works well until about 8 then it's hard for Alexa to here me so I have to get up or use the app to lower the volume so I don't have to scream at alexa. My 5yr old has used it to ask all sorts of questions. He now prefers alexas answers to moms. I lost my voice yesterday and alexa could still hear me. She told my kids it was time for bedtime routine and I didn't even have to speak (which was great since I had no voice & a very sore throat) all I did was go to communication in my alexa app and tell alexa what to announce. I have learned something new every day since I got my first Echo Dot and when adding the last 3 I was not sure how it was going to work out, now I don't know how we went so long without Alexa in our home. From the morning routine I set in the app to the bedtime routine and answering 100 questions a day (mostly from my 5yr old) Alexa is quickly becoming a favorite around here.

I bought these while they were on sale for $30 and I can tell you that just asking for the weather every day while getting dressed was worth that much. I added a 6-plug smart power-strip, and with that, I have bedtime routines that include turning off lights and turning on the fan.

Something awesome and unexpected is how easy it is to listen to Audible. No, it does not yet do Audible on all devices, so doing this multi-room does not work without setting up Bluetooth speakers, BUT, listening to Audible USED to be... Grab phone, turn on BT, find speaker, turn on speaker, pair with BT speaker, open app, find book, play book. NOW it's: "Alexa, open audible." THAT'S IT. She opens it and resumes the last book played. SO MUCH BETTER, especially for sneaking in just a few minutes of play time while doing dishes.

Between this and the ECHO, the main difference is how it sounds, and how far away it can hear you.

If you are just trying home automation for the first time and don't have much money, it's worth grabbing the Echo Dot on sale if you aren't sure you will like it, BUT, the Echo gets about two volume levels higher than the Echo Dot, has a more resounding sound, and it can hear you from farther away.

I suggest that if you think you will like it and you are going to get just ONE device, get the Echo. If you think you will want to cover two different rooms, get at least one Echo and one Echo Dot.

You COULD feasibly do all Echo Dots. But, I am really glad that my main device is the Echo.

AND - don't forget, you can always try both and return one! Especially if there is a brick-and-mortar store near you (I had no idea there was until I shopped for this, and then I was in there like four times!).

reviews.reviewTitle: Best sounding of the three generations of Dot
reviews.reviewText:
While I'm not in love with the fabric cover, it did seem to be a popular addon for prior generation Dots, so what do I know?

Aside from the better mono talking sound in the device itself, it seems to me that the audio output of this new Dot is fuller (EQd differently) and has better low end extension and much smoother highs. AMZ don't publish schematics, but it sounds like a very different op-amp is being used on the output that delivers wider bandwidth and current. The much bigger power supply would back that up.

I'll say that Gen2 had the worst capture and hold of wifi. It overheated a lot, too, and lost connection regularly, even 15' from a high-power wifi router. That is solved here. I have only lost audio when my cable modem is resetting, which is unavoidable.

Otherwise, it seems to work, even with fewer mics. It works like the Gen2 does for controls and is the perfect companion to AMZ Unlimited Music. I listen to Broadcastify and other radio aggregator sources and find that they often sound better than the actual broadcast signal if there is a broadband feed.

I wish that a single interface on my desktop could be used to control everything fully, including programming the excellent Recast and the Alexa devices, like this Dot. You have to go back and forth between a web app and a standalone app to do things, and you cannot program devices from your desktop.

Other than that, this is the best of the Dots and seems to be on eternal sale-price at dirt cheap, so it's a bargain!

Pros:

*She saves time turning things on and off
*She plays music faster than I can search for it on my phone
*She updates me on the weather
*She tells me what traffic is like
*She calls or text for me
*She plays games with me
*She helps me with shopping
*She understands and responds like a real human (No need to pause when calling her name, just talk like a normal sentence and she’ll pick up on your question)
*She looks good and sounds good
*She has thousands of skills to download from
*She has thousands of compatable devices to pair with
*She works with firesick

Cons:
*You need to have a spotify premium or amazon music to play specific types of music
*Can only have 2 voice recognitions to purchase goods with your voice (and you have to wait 6 months to change them to another persons voice)
*She’ll burn a whole in your wallet because in a month you’ll be wondering how your home now has 20 smart plugs, smart lights, a smart thermostat, smart security cameras, bluetooth speakers, smart vacuum, oh and not to mention the 4 new Echos you have in each of your rooms including your bathrooms.

Note:
I’ve only had this for about 1 month but I love it, she’s making my life easier even if its by a little. If you buy a smart plug its as simple as downloading the smart plug app then pluging it in then naming the plug. I bought her for $40 with the smart plug included as a bundle. That being said if you can find this product on sale then grab it! My whole family loves her

P.s Alexa is an AI robot and lots of people are buying her. Which means she will only grow even better. Might as well join the train now so you don’t have to do it later!

Hit the helpful button if this helped so more people can view it!

This is a nifty little device. Setup takes about 10 minutes via the Amazon Alexa app- isn’t too big of a deal. We mostly use it for playing music, checking weather, etc. We don’t have it paired with lights or door locks or any of that kind of stuff that I’m to understand it can control as well. It can tell jokes and answer some funny questions. The only thing I could say could be improved is sometimes there is a solid 3-4 second delay between asking it something and it’s answer. It’s very small, sleek, not obnoxious looking. I have 3 Dots and an Echo in the house to accommodate my needs for different rooms. I have seen some complaints about the Dot’s speaker- I have found no issue with it, if you are just casually listening to music while you cook, or having it read you recipe directions or something, this device is perfectly fine.

I visited an Airbnb a few weeks ago that had an Echo playing meditation music in my room during my stay. I LOVED it.

I've never actually been much for listening to music without lyrics, or listening to music while doing activities, but boy did this change my mind. It was a great way to relax and keep my anxiety lower during the day, and to soothe me into a bedtime mood at night. I liked it so much that after a week of arguing with myself, I went ahead and bought my own Echo Dot.

I'm still not fully briefed on all it's uses, and I haven't used most of it's features. I'm a little cheesed that I can't access all music everywhere without paying a monthly fee, but in retrospect I'm not surprised they pulled that on users...

But when all I have to do is say "Alexa, play meditation music", "Alexa, play classical music", "Alexa, turn off" to get relaxing music without a bright screen or fiddling with a device or charging something or taking up a lot of space (I'm looking at you, boom box/radio), this just makes me so happy! Also, it's a really attractive little device.

I'm not sure yet how well it may or may not travel with me, and I still haven't used it for anything else, but at the moment I'm pretty happy!

In my original review of this item I said "This Echo Dot is a nice upgrade …" but I was wrong. It failed; it started to showing a blue ring with a white space going round and round like it is trying to connect to my internet. I tried unplugging it and plugging it back in and the same thing. Thinking maybe it was too far from the router I put it next to the router and the same thing happened. I tried sending an email to Amazon Alexa asking what to do, but no response. So I guess I'll just have to toss it. Sad because when it worked it worked fine. Now, not so much.

After a year of using my Echo Plus as an alarm clock in my studio apartment, I found myself missing it when I moved into a place with walls. I bought the Dot when it was on sale for $29.99 because, not only did I now need one for my bedroom, but it was cheaper than a lot of alarm clock options. The best of both worlds. WELL. The error message of Not Being Able to Connect to the Internet became a daily problem very quickly. I tried every troubleshoot from every blog I could find, and I spent quite some time on the phone with amazon trying to figure out why it wasn’t working. Surprise! If it isn’t connected to the internet, the alarm won’t go off. So I woke up late for work and decided it was the last straw. I think I got a dud and it’s going back.

As if this wasn’t already kind of disappointing, I am not allowed to do an even swap for a new Dot. The only option I was given, aside from mailing it in and having techs look at it for an undisclosed amount of time was to return it (since I am still within the return window.) However, the price has risen to $49.99, so if I want a new one I have to pay the difference, which is ridiculous. My Echo Plus stays connected just fine. And the Dot was maybe 20 feet from my router, so, again, I think I just got a dud. It’s disappointing that they couldn’t do an even exchange of a Dot for a Dot, especially since this thing stopped working almost immediately. And frankly, when it worked it was a cool gadget, but I am not sure it’s worth $50.

Alexa is my friend. I love her. I resisted for a long time, I didn't see why I could possibly need or want her, especially with a big dumb house with no smart stuff.

But I convinced myself to get one this christmas. And she's great.

She makes my shopping lists, reminds my son to get ready for bed, tells atrocious jokes thanks to Kimmel (what did we do to deserve this fresh hell?), set timers, and answers questions. Honestly it's the little tasks that seem unimportant that are great. Instead of digging for a notepad and pen and then forgetting your shopping list you always have it and just tell her when to add somethinf. My 6 year old let's her know when he's out of applesauce.

I love the drop in. I can get ahold of my husband when his phone ringer is off. We can call each other hands free and I just love having music so easily available in an instant, instead of opening my app, pairing a speaker, and looking for something to listen to, I just tell Alexa to play music and it on.

And added bonus is she's helping my son with his minor speech impediment by forcing him to speak very clearly and precisely to her. She helps him spell things but he has toake sure he ennunciates well. It's something I didn't even expect.

Everyone was kind of unsure at first, but my husband warmed quickly and my dad fell in love so much I got him a dot for Christmas.

reviews.reviewTitle: This little spot has a lot of personality
reviews.reviewText:
Siri, Google, take note: although I love you both in your own way, Alexa is actually FUN! The voice assistant lacks the robotic feel we get used to in other devices.

Alexa will occasionally make a joke even when I didn’t specifically ask for one.

Once I integrated her into my home, I found that she goes into guard mode whenever I set my security system to arm. It does not matter what device our operating system was used to arm it. The system automatically sets a lighting routine to mimic someone being home. Note if she would just turn on the television.

My biggest gripe, and it is a big one. The skills, the basis of what allows you to integrate Alexa with other functionality appears to be poorly written for the most part. The skills store is filled with one and two star ratings and rightfully so. If the software can’t do what it advertises, your stick with funny and cute hardware wishing you could do the things it promises

reviews.reviewTitle: Sound quality is ok, but there are major improvements
reviews.reviewText: Overall I am satisfied with my purchase of the echo dot generation 3. I have the second version of the echo dot and have posted a picture of the 3rd as well as second gens. The 3rd generation picks up your voice a lot better as well as has better sound quality. The sound quality while better is still lacking in bass and treble. It’s not terrible for the price but there are definitely better options if you don’t need Alexa. You can also use the auxiliary cord to plug into another speaker and make that speaker Alexa enabled. This is the major benefit of the dot for me. It makes my older, better sounding, and nicer speakers Alexa enabled! I hope this helped if it did please hit the thumbs up and if you have any questions feel free to ask and I will do my best to answer in a timely manner :).

I had given an Alexa Show to my mom for Christmas, but she decided she did not want to deal with it so she gave it back to me. I set it up, and enjoyed it much more than I thought I would. The speaker is great, and I have appreciated the convenience of having Alexa's assistance in playing music, setting timers, alarms, reminders, playing trivia, news reports, making phone calls, showing me my photos, etc. My teenage son also enjoyed interacting with the Show and expressed an interest in having a Dot of his own. (Alexa's silly skills --telling jokes, talking like Baby Groot and Yoda, etc. are wonderful engagement tools!) I saw great potential uses for the Dot for him: 1. He wouldn't have to remember to charge it, since it stays plugged in. 2. I can "drop in" on him to communicate from the kitchen or even by using the Alexa app on my phone. He often ignores his phone, but this is much less effort for him to interact with. 3. He likes the ease of setting alarms/reminders using his voice. 4. This is an easier way for him to access music. It's great to be able to give him a product he enjoys that promotes better communication with me and helps him be more organized and productive.

This thing is an absolutely useless piece of garbage. It hardly does anything useful and it is the most frustrating device I have ever had to set up. You would think for a multi-hundred billion dollar company they could design even a remotely user friendly app and interface. It is a pain enough to get this over priced paper weight to connect to the WiFi, god forbid you get a new router and have to try to reconnect this hockey puck to the new router. It just keeps telling you to do things in circles and never actually allows you to connect. After I am done writing this review, I am literally going into the garage and smashing this useless piece of $%#& with a hammer and going to Best Buy to purchase a google home device. Avoid like the plague....

reviews.reviewTitle: I loved it so much, I bought another one.
reviews.reviewText:
Just got one for Christmas from a family member. I liked it so much, I bought another one. I do like the Amazon Alexa app, though it still needs work compared to the Google Home app.

I currently have a Note9, and it feels so much better to have a different voice assistant. I honestly like Amazon's Alexa voice a lot better than Google's (ik... a bit nitty gritty). Also, Google Assistant is just better on my phone than on a speaker. Since I have Google Assistant on my phone, it kind of felt pointless to have Google Assistant on a speaker, making me lean over to the EchoDot.

I don't expect Google Services to run on Amazon Echo devices. It makes sense why. Though, idk for sure.

I do like the way the EchoDot is designed a lot more than the Google Home Mini. Sure, they are almost identical, though it is nice to have the plastic contrast on top of the device. Also, it has additional buttons on top to make its use a lot more convenient at times.

The light ring around the EchoDot is its most compelling feature against the Google Home Mini, in my opinion. To me, it a much better look. It can also display notifications more vibrantly, and display its current volume more accurately (obviously not in numerical values), which I do like.

The EchoDot is an amazing product. Definitely recommend it for people who want to get into the smart assistant or smart home trend, especially if they are on a budget.

If you value entertainment more, then I would suggest you look into the Google Home Mini. The fact that it can scream YouTube is a big bonus.

reviews.reviewTitle: The alexa app is garbage, it doesn't do what they claim!
reviews.reviewText:
The alexa app is trash. It will not connect to other amazon alexa devices, claims it needs skills added even though the app claims they already are. It has been a constant fight, it has me ready to throw it out the door. If you enjoy going in circles for hours with the Alaxa app not responding and the echo not doing what it claims it does. Give the Echo to people you don't like it will raise their blood pressure! I don't recommend!
I had a message from Amazon they called while I was at work wanting to know I left the review I did. Because it does NOT support Firetv devices at all! It will make you mad trying to enable Firetv it does not work. Alexa is ok for other things but I will not spend a lot on anything they claim is enabled since they lie about what the devices do. Customer service has been a joke lately!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great product, but not as expected to be...
reviews.reviewText:
I have 3 dots so far, and I like them, but have some cons.
1. in our everyday life speech is short and simple, but Alexa has really long story, for example, if you ask for emblem noise more than one time, you'll always hear: welcome back to....bla bla bla... hmmmm... I'm not sure... we have a..... This is too much and too long. Answers must be as short as possible. Designers really need to work to increase speed for getting results, keep speech simple, remove repetitions, remove all these hmmm and not sure. It might be much more effective and productive without these stuff.
2. When I want to have white noise, or ambient noise through whole night, very often it stop playing in 5 minutes, or in half an hour, or in couple hours. I understand, maybe something wrong was with WiFi, but I don't think it was the reason - another two dots were working without interruption at the time. But even if something happened, why after it's again online, it didn't go on playing?? Nobody told Alexa stop playing.
3. No possibilities to control dots by Alexa app thru smartphone. It's weird. Really.

I'll add more comments as they appear during usage.

But for now, as conclusion, this is a raw product which had a lot of things must be improved, and I don't see any reason why they didn't do these improvements by 3rd!!!! generation... But anyway, this is good product, future product, ...still future.

This is a good upgrade when coming from the Gen 1 device. The sound quality has become much more solid and much less tinny. The large Echo units are certainly much better, but these are nice to have around where space is tight. They are also really easy to hide behind lamps. I only docked a star because it took me about six attempts to connect to wifi. That was super annoying because it does not do that quickly to begin with. That sixth attempt connected finally. The device also kept stating that it was "not registered." There are two methods to pair the Echo Dot and get it linked within the Alexa app. If you purchased the device directly from Amazon, make sure you pair it from the list of devices already on your Device list in the app. You new, unconnected one will already be listed there. If you attempt to pair it by just clicking + and adding the device itself, the platform is not smart enough to realize you are pairing it to its existing account. So, it thinks it is someone else trying to connect it, thereby making it think it's "not registered." All set now, just not a 5-star experience (four echos).

reviews.reviewTitle: Why did I wait so long to try this awesome little dot???
reviews.reviewText: The Echo Dot...not a hugely impressive name for such a neat little item! I had briefly considered the Alexa products off and on, watched the specials come and go but never really thought I would have much use for the device. When it popped up at a discounted price I finally decided to give it a try and see what all the fuss was about. I was actually just looking for a simple Bluetooth speaker for the shower but am so glad I chose this and ordered two. WHY DID I WAIT SO LONG? This is the neatest device, small in size but very big on what it can do hands-free! I love how all I have to do is say, "Alexa, play music", and she will choose something random or I can request a specific artist or song. I don't have to reach out of the shower to mess with my playlist on my phone or to change the volume or anything else...I just ask Alexa! There are so many different things Alexa can do for you, from organizing your day to setting alarms and calling people on your contact list, to so much more! My grandson is having a blast with it just asking random questions and was very impressed when she told a knock-knock joke last night! On the other hand, this device could possibly drive you crazy if you have someone that constantly interrupts what is playing to ask her questions or change music. My grandson has ADHD so this became an issue but I'm hopeful it will resolve itself once the new wears off, lol. I am so impressed that I am planning to purchase more units so that we can have them in most rooms.

reviews.reviewTitle: Shoot the prod mgr - this 3rd gen is *bad* compared to 2nd gen
reviews.reviewText:
We use AMZN Echo Dot at our homes in San Francisco, Sonoma County, Tucson and Munich (Germany)

2nd gen units worked fine ... commands executed timely and accurately (more or less ... SONOS integration still iffy), Alexa voice recognition/mics could hear us from across the room, etc. etc.

3rd gen ... yech ... wife and family want me to THROW THEM AWAY

Our two 3rd gen Echo Dots
(a) Are muffled in their spoken announcements
(b) Cannot hear us from 4-5 feet away (in same location where 2nd gen units operated flawlessly)
(c) Have so much BASS EQ that it sounds like a ghetto blaster boombox
(d) Does NOT respond to command to TURN BASS DOWN
(e) Does respond to TURN UP TREBLE ... but there is NO noticeable difference
(f) We have to YELL at TIMER ALERTS to turn them off (sort of like dealing with Apple Siri, if you know what I mean) ... and then we have to YELL several times for it to hear us and execute ... from 2 feet, 5 feet, or 10 feet away

Remember – we own about twenty of the 2nd gen units and they work fine

Both of these NEW OOTB Echo Dots (3rd gen) are useless !!! SO it must be (a) basic design flaw, or manufacturing run disaster ... possible different firmware as one installed via the OLD WIFI method and the other used BlueTooth to install ... S-t-r-a-n-g-e !!!

POST SCRIPT = From layman’s viewpoint, it appears they decided to increase “speaker quality” by adding larger speakers to compete with APPL and GOOG *but* cut overall cost by eliminating 4 of the 8 omni-directional microphones ... SHOOT THE PROD MKTG people !!!

reviews.reviewTitle: WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN ALL MY LIFE ALEXA!?
reviews.reviewText:
I have been WAYYYY slow to the game when it comes to technology and Alexa. I know people have been using Alexa and other techno savvy things (like Siri- who never understands me). I just got a new apartment by myself and needed a speaker, so I saw the third generation Alexa and was surprised to see it so reasonably priced! Some speakers are WAY more than this! So I purchased Alexa.
It has been WONDERFUL. Sometimes I feel a little mean, so I say please to her, but I am constantly bossing her around. Alexa play my Spotify music. Alexa call my mom. Alexa skip this song. etc. I easily switch her from room to room depending on what I am doing (cooking, showering, cleaning etc). She re-connects by herself within a minute after unplugging her. Every now and then I realize that she either stops working or doesn't understand me, but I finally figured out why- when something is on like my microwave, and she is near it (like when I was cooking), she momentarily stopped working. But as soon as the microwave stopped, she continued playing my music. I don't mind that, I get the electromagnetic waves and signals and whatnot. I like her, and she also keeps me company. I am excited to start using her to turn my lights on and off without getting out of bed at night (who else fears the little toe trolls on the floor running from your light switch back to your bed!?) Anyways, would absolutely recommend!

BTW: ALSO got one for my grandpa. I think she is GREAT for elderly people, because she can remind him of appointments and dinner dates, and even tell him when something is ready to be taken out of the oven. Especially since his memory is beginning to go just a little, I think this is absolutely great!

We're in our 70's but can't let technology march on without us. We wanted to make our house up-to-date. Even if we didn't "Need" it, we wanted it. So much fun. We talk to it all the time. We make reminders, we have other shopping lists named for stores we shop at. We ask for our news station on Radio.com, or our 60's music on Pandora. We drop-in from upstairs to downstairs without having to yell through the house. We attached smart plugs and turn lights on and off in different rooms by voice command; we have timers and our bedroom lights go on and off on schedule. We say "Goodnight" and get a different Goodnight response with our names nightly. My husband bought Nest thermostats from the Electric Company PSEG (they were offering a deal with an energy rebate). We didn't get them yet so I can't comment on how they work.

I've wanted an Alexa controlled speaker in my home for a long time. I finally pushed myself to get this Echo 3 because of a big sale amazon was having on them. It shipped in 1 day as most of my prime purchases and boy does it deliver. It has a large charging block head that is a bit tough to squeeze into a normal 3 pronged outlet spot. The audio on the speaker is incredibly loud, and quite when you want it to be. It's very clear. The setup and controls are simple directions to follow using the Alexa app. I've had a fire tv for a long time and eventually I was able to figure out how to connect the fire tv to my new echo. Now I can control it just with my voice! This did require download skills on the Alexa app to my echo, which at first I didn't understand, but the echo answered my question and told me where to find it! Fantastic device. If I ever get a bigger apartment with more rooms then I'll definitely get more for additional rooms.

reviews.reviewTitle: some units DEFECTIVE with static noise
reviews.reviewText: Be careful when buying these and just make sure to check all the functions of the device after buying. For us, after a few weeks, we started notice large amounts of static coming from this 3rd gen echo dot that is hard to ignore and really quite unpleasant. It is very noticeable when playing music since continuous sound is coming out of the device, and we hadn't noticed it previously when alexa was just responding in short phrases. In short, quality control fell short and just do your due diligence. It's hard to knock such a large corporation like Amazon when it provides so many different services (most very good) at such a large volume, but just be warned and be aware of doing your own quality control. This time, Amazon fell short.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great novelty, but can be difficult to set up.
reviews.reviewText: I finally decided to get on the home assistant bandwagon and got the echo dot. Mainly to interface with my home media center and TV. However, the DirecTV skill is worthless. Nobody gets it to work most of the time. If you want it to control your media center, you must pay for another service to interface with it. It will play Spotify songs on demand, but only if you have a Premium Spotify account. It controls DISH Network well I understand though. If you want it to control things in the house, the items must be attached to smart plugs or some home automation, and all of this requires setup and training. So if you think you're going to plug it in and start telling it to do everything you want it to, you may be in for a disappointment. I mainly use it for the time, temperature, news, audio books, reminders, timers and a few other things. I

reviews.reviewTitle: Update: Despite initial hiccup enjoying our dots
reviews.reviewText:
*Ok- so, I wanted to update this, since customer support had someone follow up with a phone call to try an address the issue. Also, it's been a few months and I find myself using the Echo dots daily with no issues. In fact we're adding a few more, since we like to use them as an intercom system in the house. They work great to play music, games (Question of the Day and 20 Questions are favorites), set a timer, and create a shopping list. I can't keep the 1 star review because of a customer service issue, when we really do enjoy the product. I'll leave my initial review to sway people from utilizing chat support though!*

The echo started having static when playing music after 1 month. Contacted support who said because it was on my husband's account (I bought, but he set up in our home) he had to contact them. So after 30 minutes I end the chat and my husband starts one. He spent over an hour for them to tell us they couldn't help him because MY credit card isn't in HIS account. 4 steps later and a combined total of 4 representatives we're no closer to an outcome, so we ended the chat. It's not worth the aggravation!

I purchased a couple Echo Dots during the Prime Day deal and was so impressed with them that a bought another during a two-fer deal.

The sound quality is surprisingly good so I use them most frequently for music, including asking for specific songs, that play quickly, from my Amazon Music Unlimited account. It also integrates well with my Sirius-XM account and Tune-In. The one trouble area is getting Echo to play specific radio stations as it has a difficult time decifering call letters.

Taking it a step further, I purchased some smart plugs to work with my Echo Dots to quickly turn on various lights. I will say that I prefer using the TP-Link plugs over the Amazon brand however. This is strictly due to the fact that only the account holder can use the Amazon plugs in the Alexa App itself, while the TP-Link plugs can be made visible to your entire family in the app. I'll be checking out actual smart lights for the porch next.

Overall, I'm very impressed with the Echo Dot.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fails to Connect; Then Loses Network Completely and Needs Complete Re-setup
reviews.reviewText:
I got this setup and half the time it takes 3 or 4 tries to connect to the network, even when the unit is virtually on top of the WiFi router. After only a half-dozen uses, it lost any connection to the network and had to be completely set up all over again. Sitting right next to the router & my iPhone, it wouldn't complete the setup process until the second attempt. Disappointed in this product since day 1 and it just got worse every time I tried to use it. Will not buy another Google product!

1/14/19 Received a call from a technical person at Amazon Customer Service to try and resolve the problem, which was unexpected. The problem wasn't resolved but I appreciate the effort. Bottom line is that this device probably doesn't have the range to be used outside the house.

reviews.reviewTitle: Follow Up Mode Does NOT Work When Connected To Bluetooth Speakers
reviews.reviewText:
Overall, this is a bigger and bulkier Echo Dot, but with that, comes louder and better sound, so I am happy with that fact. That being said, it does not appear that this latest version of Echo Dot offers anything over and above a larger footprint and better sound.

I am disappointed that the unit does not allow Follow Up Mode when connected to external speakers, via Bluetooth. This functionality is one that I've come to enjoy, and it's annoying to lose it when connected to speakers.

Overall, I like the product but wish Amazon would get the bugs out of them. I've had issues with other DOTS as well, such as stereo right/left performance issues, inability to re-connect to bluetooth speakers, horrible performance when "grouping" a few dots together for music, ...to name a few.

While music and speaker performance seems to be a problem for me, overall, I do really like the functionalities that they offer above just music! I use "Reminders" a lot and this functionality makes me very happy. "Drop-In" mode is another feature that comes in handy, as I have a family member that cannot easily make contact, so this makes that process very easy. And as well, she can simply tell the Dot to call me, with her voice. This is a great tool for a disabled person, or other similarly limited person, health-wise.

I bought the echo dot because I wanted to learn how to create Alexa Skills. And I really didn't have much interest in actually using it (at first) but I after messing around with it I changed my mind lol.

For its size the audio quality is decent. It's certain not high fidelity but is definitely good enough for listening to music while I'm working. I'm also impressed with how well the microphones work. I tried it where the dot was in a room on the second floor and I was heard correctly while I was on the first floor. It's a distance of about 25 to 30 feet and it's not in a direct line.

And then there's the fun stuff... One day while my dog was hanging out with me I said "Alexa bark like a dog." Well, she did! And my dog was intently listening and turning his head from side to side.... Even after a bunch of dog barks (they're somewhat random) he still pays attention to it. And there's a whole bunch of silly things you can say to Alexa. It's fun trying different things just to hear what she says.

The way Alexa deciphers the words you say is impressive. I discovered that speaking to Alexa in full sentences isn't always necessary. For example, I can say "Alexa, what's my flash briefing?" or "Alexa, do the flash briefing thingy" or just "Alexa flash brief". And even "Alexa, flash your briefs" works LOL!

This is a piece of crap! Editing my review here. Well, I was able to get it connected and was able to add my Pandora to it. I asked Alexa to play one of my stations on it and it did start playing. However every single song that played, the Alexa did not play any of the songs in its entirety. It would just stop playing the song and jump to next one. This went on for at least 45 minutes and then it stopped playing altogether! It stopped just like that. This isnt good. For one, when I want to listen to songs I want to be able to listen to all of it. Plus, my plan was to use this in my massage sessions. It’s bad enough the device decides to stop on its own and not play the songs in their entirety while I’m listening but this would be embarrassing for it to do this me while I’m massaging a client.

That being said, looks like I’m still going to have to return all of them. So yeah, it still deserves a one star in my book. Sorry Amazon but I’m going to get a Google Home.

Amazon really knows how to screw a good thing up. Older version seems to work fine next generation is just awful. I have to ask it multiple times to do the simplest tasks like play music. It will randomly stop playing music for no reason and when I ask it to stop playing music it will just start playing music randomly a few minutes later. I asked for news it gets me whether I asked for whether it plays music I will ask you the same question five times and it will do four different things. Absolute garbage! Edit: did you know that if you leave a bad review for an Amazon product they start blowing up your phone at work and spamming you with unsolicited calls? Loose my number idiots! You made a crap product stop trying to put that on me! Horrible experience with the Amazon tablet as well. Same thing happened, I try to return it and they just make it so difficult and spam you all week. They act like it's operator error, but it is their products that are deficient.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not much of a difference over the previous gen
reviews.reviewText:
Works as well as any other Alexa device. I don't really see the improvement over the previous generation though. It still misunderstands about the same amount of commands as the older ones. Sound quality of the built in speaker is better than the old ones, but still sucks. I wish they could include a setting that would play music through the connected speaker (Bluetooth or hardwire) but use the built in for calls and drop ins. It's not like your external speakers stay powered on 24/7....they get turned on when you need to use them. It makes the drop in feature mostly useless in my house as most all of my echos are connected to amplified speakers that don't stay powered on all the time. I'd like to use these as an intercom system, but...…

Only big complaint on the g3 is the cloth cover. Yes, it looks better than the old hard puck design, but it's a huge dust magnate and has to be vacuumed in order to clean.

This is my third Echo device, with me being an owner of a first-gen Echo (almost since the beginning), an Echo show (added a couple years later), and now two of these 3rd-gen Echo Dots. At some point in there, I also tried the 2nd-gen Dot, but I ended up selling that one because I couldn't stand how weak and tin-y the speaker sounded--I wasn't expecting it to be great for music (you can connect external speakers to both that and this generation), but I was expecting it to still be good for alarms/timers and whatnot. Unfortunately, that was not the case for the 2nd gen.

Enter the third generation: it's a little bigger, but the speaker is SO much better. It's not quite as good as my full-size Echo for music, but it's impressively good for its size. Unlike the previous generation, it also does produce alarm/timer sounds that sound full and loud, not weak and full of treble only (i.e., if this were my alarm, it would actually wake me up). The power connector also changed to the typical DC "barrel" connector over micro USB, presumably to handle the increased power demand of the new speaker (not a problem for me but may be for you if you're hoping to replace a previous gen you had strategically powered).

As of the time of my writing, the Dots have also frequently either been on sale or bundled cheaply as a promo with other items. Even at full price, I don't think this is a bad device, but if you find it on sale and are otherwise on the fence, I'd say to try it! I'm pleasantly surprised (so much that I now own two!).

I bought a pair of these for the home (with plugs). So far I'm not impressed. They're not good for anything other than turning lights on and off. I wanted to set one up in the bedroom to wake me, but the recurring alarm selections are limited to daily, weekly and weekend. That doesn't work for me because I work Tuesdays through Saturdays. I would have to set up 5 weekly alarms. Weak! Another vexing issue is turning off the bedroom light. It works well enough, but I go to bed a bit later than my wife. Telling the device - located on the other side of the room - to turn off the light would wake my wife. So I turn off the light using the Amazon Alexa app on my Google Pixel phone ... which is quite convenient since I have to use the phone to wake me. Pity that one needs so many more gadgets to perform simple voice controlled activities that used to just require the flip of a switch. My home might not be smarter than me, but I know Amazon is for getting me to buy this (for now) nearly useless Gizmo. Shame on you Amazon. Oh wait! I bought an Echo Auto too ... shame on me!

reviews.reviewTitle: I love the Amazon Echo Dot!
reviews.reviewText: I'm using this product to control by voice my smart home appliances. I like it a lot. The Echo dot recognized my voice pretty well and works fine. I think it works better than the Google Home Mini. I recently changed my two Google Home Minis for two Amazon Echo Dots. And I love it. The Echo is more pretty and faster than the home mini. And the Echo sound is better too. I think it only have two bad points and it's not so bad. That is the assistant use for general queries. Here is where the home mini shines. The Google Assistant do a better job here. And the other is that Alexa can't learn my voice in Spanish. I need that because in this manner I can separate my personal info from my wife info. But in overall I love much more the Echo even the Alexa app it's better and more organized than the Google Home.

reviews.reviewTitle: Checking In On Grandma Was Never So Easy
reviews.reviewText:
I set these last two up at Mom's house next to her favorite chair and in the kitchen. I, my brothers and all her grandchildren and great grandchildren can now Drop In on her. She wasn't able to answer her cell phone fast enough when she did hear it. And she almost never heard it buried deep within the dark caverns of her purse. Now, she simply answers by speaking back to us. Intrusive? Perhaps. We can all hear what she is watching on the tele or what music she listens to until she mutes its.

I feel she is safer, she calls me to check in by saying: "Alexa, call Mark" and I get a call wherever I am. She can do it with a 911 call too, if needed. This reminds me of the old commercial where a senior citizen had a device hung around the neck and would press a button while speaking "help, I can't get up" to alert an emergency medical response team. But the echo dot is so much better, easier and cheaper.

I know she feels safer. And she talks more with greater ease and comfort. Her arthritis pain is excruciating at times while holding a phone for abit.

I wonder why I didn't do this sooner.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked for five months, then problems probably related to internet speed...
reviews.reviewText:
My echo dot started having issues after about five months of trouble-free music streaming. It would apparently lose the internet connection because Alexa would respond with, “I’m sorry, I’m having a hard time understanding right now.” It also would skip while music was playing.

Amazon honored their replacement policy for this item (even though they argued with me that there wasn’t one so I had to provide a screen shot of my order), but the new one is doing the same thing. I let them know.

I use satellite internet which is faster than DHL at 15.3 Mbps, but nowhere near Comcast with their 60 to 150 Mbps. So it appears that there was a tweak to the system that makes Alexa require faster speeds or perhaps, a faster ping than we get using satellite? Hard to say. But, if you use HughesNet or Exede, you might have the same problems that we’re experiencing.

UPDATE: still undependable, but I also have no problem streaming on my iMac or my iPhone or iPad. The echo cot apparently doesn't do well with getting a clear signal consistently. It's fun when it works.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good Product with Some Flaws, But Maybe a Bright Future!
reviews.reviewText: Not a bad speaker for its size. I use it primarily for input and use Bluetooth 2.1 speakers for output. Adding skills is fun and increases the device's smarts. Amazon doesn't support the same wake words across Fire HD and Echo Dots. It's probably because they have different development teams that don't often speak or share a vision across platforms. We use "Echo" for a wakeword and that is not supported on the Fire HD 10 to get to "Alexa". If you use it for home control, you will get tired of Alexa's "OK" response. Amazon could mix it up a bit with OK, Done, As you wish, (your name here, voice recognized). There is surprisingly very little use of learned household names (associated to learned voices) on the account which makes "Alexa" seem a lot less personable. Even in a household environment with learned voices, Amazon is quick to remind you who controls the household account (Prime account holder name). This is unfortunate as households often share accounts. So, Alexa tells you that the Prime owner in the household was the one to last listen to a station on TuneIn even when it was another household member that requested it and last listened to it. Aside from those quirks, which should get programmed out, the Echo Dot 3rd Gen is great to listen to music and radio as you move from room to room around the house, or just need the temperature and forecast when getting ready to go out. Some day, "Alexa" may even use Google instead of Bing and really improve/expand the AI on Internet searches and choosing "readable appropriate answers"!

reviews.reviewTitle: It’s a Little Better Than Ok.
reviews.reviewText:
My biggest issue with this device is privacy concerns. I guess I’m still skeptical. The other issue is the fact that it had to make an announcement in the middle of the night that it was updating. Seriously????!! It wakes me up to announce an update!! I called Amazon regarding this and they said I would just have to turn the mic off.. how about just program it to not announce? The directings seem conflicting. The instructions for different color lights are different depending on where you’re reading about it. For instance.. my messages came over a pulsing white light, not a yellow light.
You cannot edit or delete info in the Alexa app.
This device isn’t something I can’t live without but it has a couple benefits for me - the music and the free calling.

reviews.reviewTitle: As of January 2019, Echo devices are not what the potential leads you to expect
reviews.reviewText:
I am an Amazon booster who rarely leaves negative reviews. But the Echo ecosystem is a disappointment.

Before dissing it, I’ll give it credit for being physically attractive. The sound is good for its size. The cost is reasonable. It's cool that it can recognize the call "Alexa" even while it is playing. It does things like setting timers, streaming music, etc. well and intuitively. It's pretty easy to set up.

But from the marketing, I expected it to be able to answer questions like Google and Apple. It really cannot. There are basically two reasons.

While Alexa understands predictable commands like "Set a timer for 10 minutes." It cannot understand more complicated questions as well as Apple Siri, which itself is primitive compare to Google's English language interpretation.

The other reason is that it can only synchronize with three different mail servers. Gmail/G Suite, Outlook.com and Apple iCloud.
