In other words, it cannot access a standard POP3, IMAP or MAPI mailbox from any other service. This was hard for me to believe since all smartphones can access all of these. But not Alexa.

This review is written in January 2019. I hope it becomes outdated soon. I'm sure Amazon is working on natural language understanding. And it seems inconceivable to me that a year from now, Alexa will still be unable to access most mailboxes in the world.

reviews.reviewTitle: AMAZING, GREAT SOUND, LOUD, 3rd Gen Dot, I LOVE EM!!!
reviews.reviewText: I’ve seen several reviews saying the sound isn’t much better on the 3rd generation from the 2nd generation, this is one I have to disagree with the other reviewers! My 3rd Gen Dot’s sound is significantly better then my other 2nd gen Dots! My new 3rd Gen fills my large frontroom with music/sound. In fact it can be heard from other adjacencent rooms too! The new Dot is pretty close in the level of sound that my 2nd gen show puts out, which is really quite loud! Honestly from the reviews I read about the 3rd Gen dot I almost didn’t buy them thinking the volume of sound wouldn’t be near loud enough comparing them to the 2nd Gen Dots I already own that are not all that loud. But I’m glad I took the chance and bought 2 of these 3rd Gen Dots, cause they do sound amazing and are more then plenty loud. BTW, that’s coming from a old cabinet maker that’s had his hearing lost significantly from using loud equipment for decades! If I can more then easily hear these, then anyone with normal hearing certain can too! If their not loud, try turning up your volume on your Dot! Personally I can’t say one bad thing about these new 3rd Gen Dots, I’m very impressed! My old 2nd gen Dots are now in our bathroom paired to our new ceiling vents that have Bluetooth speakers. Perfect use of my 2nd gen Dots! No need for extra Bluetooth speakers on my 3rd Gen Dots, plenty of bass for me and you can adjust your bass, etc. on your Alexa app too! Unless you’re wanting ear bleeding sound, you won’t be disappointed with the 3rd Gen Dots!

reviews.reviewTitle: It's like having a personal assistant!
reviews.reviewText:
I love my Echo Dot! I can go about my day and don't have to stop what I'm doing to look stuff up or write things down. I just wake Alexa and ask her to: calculate a measurement for a recipe; set a timer for my wash or dryer cycle; add something to my grocery list; or just a remind me to do something at a later time.

There's a small learning curve to know the correct terms, like instead of "turn off" use "stop" when I'm done hearing music. Or sometimes I'll say "dining" in my command and she'll ask "did you mean dining." And I also have to remember to say Alexa for each different command.

It's actually been fun learning how to use my Echo Dot and how to set up routines that make life easier: for instance, when I say Alexa good night, it triggers the smart plug of the lamp next to me off and turns the smart plug of my lamp on my night table on. I've also set my porch lights and back yard lights on a daily schedule using smart bulbs. No more turning the porch lights on when we're leaving before dusk if we're returning after dark.

reviews.reviewTitle: How did I live without this just three months ago?
reviews.reviewText:
I love my Echo. I’m having surgery next month and I set two of these up to control smart outlets in the living room and bedroom so I can control lights without having to get up. I really like the ability to set alarms and timers. I use one when I’m baking and another one for getting up in the morning. I have a routine set where the alarm goes off and then it turns on a light. A bonus from the smart plugs that has nothing to do with the Echo is that I can turn on lights in the house from my phone while I’m driving home (although Echo can be used to set up a routine for those as well).

One thing I didn’t realize is that you have to be connected to the internet for any of them to work. The speech recognition engine is not hosted on the local machine. I live in a remote area where the internet goes down from time to time. It would be nice if Amazon would enable some basic features like alarms to run internally.

I was impressed with the sound; my Echo pushes noticeably more base than my Oontz Angle. I do have some problems with Alexa selecting songs with similar names to what’s in my library from the cloud instead of from my library. I’ve gotten a couple of jarring surprises.

We've several 2nd generation Echo devices in our house and I decided to order one of the newer models during Black Friday sale. I am amazed at the difference in sound - it's excellent for such a small device at the sale price or the typical price. I hate reading some reviews were people are critical of the sound. It's as if they think they can spend $25-$50 on a device and get the equivalent sound quality of a multi hundred dollar speaker system - be real. It's much fuller than 2nd gen and the bass is actually noticeable, but it's not a multi hundred dollar speaker. Also, I don't see many speakers of better quality out there capable of controlling smart plugs, set thermostats, play games and give out the news and weather, as well as read out appointments on a calendar, etc.

reviews.reviewTitle: There’s a reason why they lowered the price - Alexa is being smothered
reviews.reviewText:
In my house, I have an original Echo Show, a generation 1 Echo Dot, an original Echo, an Echo Spot, an Echo Input, and my most recent acquisition - a third generation Echo Dot. You might say that I collect these things. I bought the new Dot because I really liked how it looked. It was my intention to it replace the first generation Dot, but I changed my mind on that very quickly. When Alexa speaks, she sounds super muffled. It sounds like she’s wrapped in a blanket. I’ve only played a few songs and they don’t sound terrible, but I find that I have to turn the volume way up to hear her, and if I forget to turn it down again, whatever I play is way too loud. My conversations with her have gone like this:

Me: Alexa - Set volume to six. Alexa, what is the weather?
Alexa: The weather in blah blah is blah blah blah blah. (Loud, but muffled).
Me: Alexa, set volume to three. Alexa, play blah blah by the blah blah blahs

Without the first and third step, it’s completely unusable.

It is also one of the most deaf of my Echo devices. It’s not as bad as my Show (really hate that thing), but it’s close.

I wonder if the muffled sound can be worked out with an update. Music doesn’t sound bad, you’d think that they could make Alexa clear.

I am going to put my Dot first generation back and buy a little owl holder for it. This thing is going back.

reviews.reviewTitle: Won't reconnect automatically to wi-fi network after loss of power - fixed!
reviews.reviewText:
"Of all my wi-fi devices this is the only one that would not reconnect automatically to the home wireless network after any type of disconnect. Every time you re-plug it at new home location, lose power or the like, the thing is at loss and wants you to go through a setup routine anew, smart?"
Above was my original reaction. After weeks and multiple trials, frustrated, I posted a one star review, got call from Amazon on my voicemail next day with an offer to help, came home and plugged the thing in again (just to make sure it still did not work before I called back) - and it worked! Miracle, don't know what to think. In disbelief I tried few times more.
Went back into the setting, found a suggestion to allow Amazon to store a wi-fi password so new devices could be connected automatically. Was it a privacy issue then and my Echo did not save the key first time(s)? Then how had it been fixed w/o my intervention - a mystery. Don't understand what's wrong with saving wi-fi passwords in the device's some sort of non-volatile memory on a first setup, as apparently all my other devices like cameras/speakers/tv do. Unless the device is not secure maybe? Never thought of that, what about cameras? Anyway, problem solved, not an issue anymore.
Thanks!

reviews.reviewTitle: Major issues connecting with smart home devices
reviews.reviewText: The echo dot itself seems like a great little gadget, however when you attempt to integrate it with smart home devices there are major problems. I ran into so many problems pairing Alexa to my Bluetooth Phillips hue bulbs- customer service agents have no idea what they’re talking about and kept insisting I needed a hub, despite the product set up stating everywhere that a hub is not required. After being insulted and purposely disconnected from chat support, I was able to figure it out on my own- proving that I in fact did not need a hub. Moving to the next issue- the 4K firestick. Alexa recognizes the device and will boot up the tv and play shows when you ask- however once you attempt to power on or off the tv, she suddenly has no idea what device you’re talking about and claims it does not exist. Clearly some issues with echo Alexa connecting to other devices properly. No point in talking to tech support about it either because they obviously don’t know their own products and will just insist you need to buy something else to connect them.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good improvements over Gen 2! Got rid of the verbal replies!!!
reviews.reviewText:
I’d certainly say this was worth it. I took advantage of the sales this year and was able to on 2 occasions buy one on the monthly pricing and discounted to 29.99 I did that last year for the gen 2.

The design looks better although I’m not sure how well it will hold up in the kitchen because of the cloth. But that may be on purpose in a way.

Bottom line it works better and doesn’t respond with voice to commands that went through correctly. Only if something is wrong.

Might be a feature available on the gen 2 but at the time this arrived and replaced my gen 2 the gen 2 was still responding to everything with its loud voice! Thinking of loud if you whisper to it even if it doesn’t understand it speaker quieter!

The headline says it all, but to elaborate...I love her functionality...immediate gratification when I want to know the temperature outside, or the weather for the rest of the day. If I want to hear the news, a few words and I'm all filled-in. Corny jokes? No end to them! Ahhhhhhh, but the music! That's the best. I love a wide variety of music...everything from show tunes, to oldies, to classical...and thensome. All I have to do is tell Alexa what genre to play and the music goes on and on until I tell her to stop. When the speculation started that Alexa is spying on us, I asked her if she was. Her response was, "Elizabeth, I value your privacy. I would not spy on you." I laughed my head off. I can't imagine anything more boring than spying on me, anyway. I'm 72, I live alone, I watch boring TV shows, and have even more boring phone conversations. Yes, I do love Alexa...and I have two of her...one in my living area and one in my bedroom...and, actually, a third on my Fire Stick. Life is good!

Bought this because I needed a new Bluetooth speaker for listening to Spotify, and figured I'd give Alexa a shot because it was on sale for about the same price as a regular Bluetooth speaker, but with extra features. Read that the Dot didn't have the same sound quality as the full-size Echo, but my previous Bluetooth speaker was an itty bitty, cheap, inch-high pocket-size thing, so I figured surely the sound quality would be at least as good as that one was (it had surprisingly crisp, clear sound for such a tiny thing). I was wrong. The music sounds weird and muffled on the Dot, like someone tossed a heavy blanket over the speaker; not even close to decent quality, and trying to adjust the bass/treble didn't improve things. Furthermore, it won't link to my Spotify account, as it apparently requires you to have Spotify *Premium*, which I have no interest in paying for, and this bit of fine print was not mentioned anywhere in the item description when I bought it. So basically, it is completely useless for the entire purpose I bought it for. I initially figured that if I didn't like the Dot, I'd return it and save for the full-size Echo, but as that one presumably won't let me listen to my free Spotify account either, I think I am just going to return it and go with a regular old, non-smart Bluetooth speaker instead -- one that will let me listen to what I want, with decent sound quality and no stipulations. Very disappointing... I was really looking forward to using this. The only reason this doesn't get one star is because I'm sure it does everything else it's supposed to do just fine; I didn't bother to test those features out though, once I realized it wasn't going to perform the primary task that I wanted it to.

reviews.reviewTitle: Much better than the 2nd gen Echo Dot
reviews.reviewText:
I used to have a 2nd gen echo dot, which I use it as the computer's speaker, it was doing it's work just fine, but always think the volume was too low. Saw the 3rd gen on sale, and decided to give it a try. Oh my, this is one of the best purchase I've ever done to my life.

The 3rd Gen is slightly bigger than the 2nd gen, and it does required a different power plug, so you will have to replace everything if you are currently using the 2nd gen echo dot. However, this echo dot's audio is much better than the 2nd gen. the 2nd gen was more of a mono tone audio, whiile the 3rd gen offer crystal clear with bass and everything, it is also much louder than the 2nd gen as well. I would say the volume lv 3 is equal to the lv 10 on 2nd gen, that's how much the difference is.

Right now I am using my 3rd gen echo dot for the following
1) Alarm Clock: I have given command to Alexa to play classical music every morning to wake me up
2) Weather: Just say "Alexa, how's the weather" and she will tell me all the details
3) Traffic: I have set my commute address via the alexa app, so I just need to say "Alexa, how's my commute, and she will tell me the traffic condition, I am never late to work ever again
4) desktop speaker: you just need to hook it up with bluetooth and it is ready to go, plain and simple
5) music station: sometimes when I don't feel like using my computer, I just ask alexa to play music(via amazon music), or play the radio station when I am laying on bed relaxing.

I would highly recommand you to give this dot a try, it certainly improve your living standard!

reviews.reviewTitle: Affordable way to try home automation, works as a personal assistant
reviews.reviewText: This is my first foray into this type of technology, I got it as a Black Friday special bundle with a sengled smart light kit, so I have no comparison. It has a sleeker domed edge and rounded top which makes it look higher quality out the box than the previous hockey puck style version. It was a straightforward setup along with connecting it to the smart lighting, coming from someone who didn't grow up with technology. It's nice when I come home at night to turn the lights on by voice instead of fumbling across the room to the light switch, as well as remotely control my lights for security reasons, and get my flash briefing while I'm having my morning coffee, and do other simple tasks by voice via skills you can add, you can link various apps to it like Pandora and list.me, make phone calls, schedule, set alarms, use multiple units as a home intercom system, as well as skills templates where you can make your own skill if you're feeling industrious. The speaker is plenty loud for my small space (900sq ft total), but there is some distortion to music at higher volumes, which, for me, is to be expected for something so little (about 4 1/2 to 5 inch across). I keep it In my kitchen, it can hear me from my bedroom down a 15 foot hallway if I have the door open, and not if the door is closed (I'm fine with that as I dont really want a potentially open mic in my bedroom or bathroom). For the cost it was an affordable foray into home automation for me.

This Dot came as a free device from a purchase during Amazon Prime Days and, based on my daughter's Dot, I did not have high hopes for good quality sound. I was happily wrong. The sound is deep and rich and quite loud enough. The device itself, of course, is compact enough to fit pretty much anywhere - I have mine in my bathroom, a space not quite large enough for a full-size Echo - and is unobtrusive.

There are two problems, though I think the first one is more related to the smart plug I have more than the Dot itself. It does not like to be paired. Even though my Alexa app shows it is properly connected, over the past couple of weeks, the Dot has disconnected without my doing anything. The second problem is that if I have a Bluetooth device activated anywhere nearby - and that has proven to be a pretty large area - the Dot does not connect to my Alexa Everywhere group.

As a result of those two issues, I have docked my Echo Dot (third generation) one star.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love love love my new echo dot!
reviews.reviewText:
I have not bought any Amazon made products in a while. The last time I did, I bought the Amazon echo (first gen) and I still use it to this day. It still works amazingly well. So Amazon prime day comes up and I had already been looking at the Amazon echo dot because I figured, "why not?". The price was out of my budget before prime day, but BOOM! Prime day comes around and it only cost me like 20 something bucks and I couldn't say no. The style is sleek and the color is cute. Alexa responds very quickly and recognizes my commands easily. It's also fairly compact so I can put her right next to my bed. I honestly havent really found a con but when I do, I'll definitely update the review.

I mean if AI's are going to be taking over the world like a scene out of terminator then I might as well get to know our future AI overlords. Who knows, maybe they'll cut me some slack after watching me struggle with life. If no update is found then either I have been killed by Alexa or the echo dot is just that amazing.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'd say 2x better than Echo Gen2, and 5x better than Show at understanding us
reviews.reviewText: This little puck does a great job at understanding the whole family, even with pronunciation variances. I own Dot Gen2, Dot Gen3, and Show. Comparing them, I found the Gen3 to be so much better than the Gen2 - a lot fewer "I'm not sure" and "I don't understand". It's also greatly better than the Show (which I now consider to be garbage). I actually bought the Gen3, so I could move the Gen2 from center stage (our Rec Room) to our bedroom, move the Show to center stage, and use the Gen3 in our Living Room. Well, when I made the Show center stage, I soon discovered it's useless, unless you interact with it from 2 feet away (something I didn't realize because it was always on my office desk right in front of me). Long story short, the Gen3 is now my center stage device, and I am now much much happier.

So since I got my Dot I have pretty much kept it on mic disabled since Alexa responds and acts on conversations that did not include the "Alexa" prompt. When it did responded, even to the "Alexa" prompt it responded in ways that made zero sense in terms of the context of the commands or conversations it over heard.

It's too late to return this so it's mine. The key feature I have been using this with is Amazon Music but ask it to play a certain genre and it won't play anything but the same six songs over and over and over again.

The key integration I was expecting with this was home automation since the Ring Hub of my Ring Alarm (Ring is owned by Amazon) can now work as a Z-Wave hub. However, the software still can't schedule anything yet so there is no point in moving my Z-Wave devices over to the Amazon infrastructure. Who knows when Ring will deploy this feature? It's been over two years as far as I can tell when the Ring community asked Ring to update the software to rotate a video feed from a Ring Doorbell 90 degrees. This was needed in my case if I wanted to install a Ring Doorbell. Thankfully, I was able to return the doorbell in time for a refund.

I'm getting to the point of just putting the Echo Dot up on Let Go and see if anyone wants it. It's already a sunk cost; maybe I can get some reimbursement.

Sometimes I have to call Alexa twice to get her attention. But when I have it she works flawlessly. I also have a second generation. Now, I live in a rest home and I have a room to myself approximately 15 x 12. And having two dots in such a small area could be confusing. It's like sometimes the third generation will wait patiently to see if the second generation will pipe in. Other times the third generation uses Brute Force to over come the older second generation. One thing you instantly notice is that the third generation is about 3 times louder then the second generation with much more Bass. Almost too much. But it is all good! I cannot cook the 3rd generation and 2nd generation together in the stereo configuration. I don't know if it's them are just the neophyte like me trying it. I can't see any reason to buy more of them in the small room and since it's a rest home I'll probably spend the rest of my life here anyway. Just the same it is so cool to have Alexa right there when I need her.

I love the speaker! I have both google and amazon. The differences I notice is that Alexa will ask more specific questions and when you ask or Moreno medical questions it provides very reliable information and sources. Google does not go into as much detail but does seem to be a bit more user friendly. For instance I’ll tell Alexa/google to turn off the lights. Alexa will tell me there is more then one light and wants confirmation to which exact bulb I want to turn off. Google will just turn the lights off. I figured out later that I need to name all my bulbs the same name if I want Alexa to turn them all off. There are other instances where google seems to understand more of what I want and in my opinion seems to be a bit more user friendly however Alexa does have strengths over google such as giving better and more detailed information. The speaker in the google mini seems to sound a bit better but not by too much. Alexa can send messages and can call people through my iPhone. I also like that I have a better selection of music through prime. It’s like a one stop shop. Overall each has its strengths and weaknesses. I have not messed around too much with each device side by side but once I do, I will add some more information. I am just glad that each gets updated and the more they are used the better technology will hopefully progress!

reviews.reviewTitle: I am having trouble understanding, try again later
reviews.reviewText:
All of a sudden with same environment (same WiFi network, same Echo Dot location, same quiet room, etc.)Echo Dot keeps saying "I am having trouble understanding, try again later." for three days.
I have a lengthy conversation with customer service team letting me know that my Echo Dot is out of warranty so they can't be replaced. A suggestion he offered was move Echo Dot close to WiFi router...

What a simple waste of my time talking to someone with a lack of technical knowledge....

I did hard reset, reboot, and moved it close to WiFi router. Nothing works...

Toss it to the garbage reminding myself never buy any Alexa products again.

I wasn't sure exactly what to expect, this being my first smart home device. However, I have to say, I am pleasantly surprised.

The setup was very simple. I downloaded & opened the app, plugged in the Echo Dot, and followed the simple instructions on my phone. It connected to my Amazon account and told me about a few things that I could do with Alexa.

I originally purchased this because I wanted a speaker that would connect to my music without using my phone as the intermediary. As advertised, it did this very well. However, it can do a lot more as well.

I was getting tired of screaming "Hey Siri!" at the top of my lungs hoping that my phone would hear me. Now, I barely say "Alexa" in the room and she is ready for a command.

When you have more than one in the house, they connect to each other and you can decide which one plays music, if not all.

It looks great. The 2nd generation wasn't very inspiring to me in its design, but this one looks like a fancy speaker.

The audio is fantastic. I want sure how it was going to sound since it's so small, but I never go above 5 out of 10 in volume because it gets so loud. The sound quality is also on par with some really good speakers that I've previously used.

All in all, I highly recommend. If you are looking to buy a Bluetooth speaker, just buy this! It'll work better than other speakers at its price point.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do not download the AP fro the App store.
reviews.reviewText:
Followed directions to install. Tried to download the Alexa AP. It failed to download. A phone number is given on the web page to get help, when diAled "THAT NUMBER IS NO LONGER IN SERVICE". NOW THAT IS SPECIAL! I tried to send a message for on line help and no one is available. Not a very good start.
he next day I tried again, the program still failed to download, so I again called the suggested number. This started my nightmare. I spoke to what appeared to be a very helpful "Amazon tech" she stated that I had a problem with my wifi and that Alexa had detected a problem with my computer. She assurred me that she could fix it After 30 minutes of back and forth and taking over my computer she cheerfully declared that she could fix this by removing all the illegal websites that had invaded my computer. The cost $295. I spelled a problem and hung up, then deleated what I could from my computer files. Later on I called Amazon directly and the very nice young lady who assisted my and Alexa was working in 15 minutes. I am still in the process of learning but so far I am pleased. So, it is vey important to not down load this app from the app store!

The 3rd Generation Echo Dot was a great aesthetic improvement over the 2nd generation. This one is slightly bigger but sounds better than the previous generation. My only complaint with this one is the power plug. The 3rd generation no longer comes with a USB adapter and USB to USB-C cord. It now comes with a molded A/C adapter to USB-C power cord. This is annoying because it limits the installation options IMO. A/C power adapters typically take up more room than the average USB power adapter and this one is no exception. Fortunately I bought this unit to replace a 2nd Generation inside my house to then move the 2nd Generation to my pool area. If I had the 3rd generation as my only option it would be a problematic install because outdoor outlets are limited. There is one outlet available to power my TV and any devices I need to connect to the TV. In this particular location I installed a high wattage 4 port USB charger (plugged into the second outlet) which had one open port. The 4 port USB charger is much smaller than any 4 outlet power strip that I would need to power the 4 devices currently plugged into the USB charger. I'm not sure why Amazon felt the need to change to the power cord. The previous gen power configuration worked fine. Just like screen mirroring was a great function on the previous Gen Fire TV but Amazon felt the need to remove it with the new 4K Fire TV. Sometimes I wonder who Amazon consults before making changes like this.

reviews.reviewTitle: Don’t understand why I didn’t buy one a long time ago.
reviews.reviewText: I love my echo so much that I’ve bought 4 more since. One for each of my three teens and one for my sister in law. We all absolutely love it. I use it when I’m home alone and want to listen to my audio book while cleaning or just listening to music. There is so much more you can do with it. I now want one in every room of my house. My only complaint is because I have three teens and you can only add one adult to your amazon household, we can’t use ours as an intercom system. They each had to make their own amazon account to be able to connect theirs to their individual Spotify accounts. It was very frustrating but I guess we will have to live with them not being connected to each other even though I was really looking forward to that aspect of use.

reviews.reviewTitle: These are great little devices with many uses!
reviews.reviewText: This is the tenth echo Dot, Spot and Show I have purchased for the home, friends and family. It has a long way to go to provide a useful tool for quick research, but Amazon is making it better, and it has so many other uses, it is a great device for the home and office. I would like to have more control on selection of my own wake word, which is currently limited to Amazon, Echo, Computer or Alexa which presents an issue. Computer is the worst of the wake words. I never realized how many times the word computer comes up in normal conversation or is said on TV which causes it to wake up and respond to whatever follows the word computer. Its annoying and funny when it provides random responses to questions that were not asked, or weirdly interrupts the conversation. Also requires careful phrasing as it often says it does not know the answer or gives a weird random response repeatedly until the Question is perfectly phrased.

Alexa has made my life SO much easier. I’m a techie so I love smart home devices like this. My whole house is automated with smart lights, fans, heater and a bunch of other stuff. Alexa turns on my landscape lights automatically at sunset and I have routines set to where when I say “Goodnight” it turns off my bedroom lights and turns on my humidifier (since it’s cold and the heater dries my skin.) Alexa then turns off my humidifier and turns on my lights gradually every morning at a set time. I have a total of 4 echo dots in the house so I can control my home almost anywhere in the house. It also reminds me of stuff I have to do with the reminders feature. And the speakers on this updated version is a HUGE improvement over the last version. My music sounds great from this tiny speaker (obviously not as good as a nicer one but still) in conclusion I would highly recommend and will definitely buy more in the future.

reviews.reviewTitle: Echo Dot is a Game Changer
reviews.reviewText: The Amazon Echo Dot is great, right out of the box. It connected effortlessly to my home wifi and now it practically runs the show! My 1940's home is slowly becoming a "smart" home as I add gadgets that work with my Amazon Echo Dot - who says you can't teach an old dog new tricks! Like turning on lamps by asking Alexa to do it and finding the perfect music for just about every occasion - instantly. Sometimes Alexa gets a little annoyed when my family barks commands at "her" - she knows just the right phrase to put everyone in their place. Very quick come-backs - you almost forget you are talking to a computer. Alexa has become part of the family. Don't know how we got along with out her! We even took her along on a recent vacation. My radio isn't very happy and neither is the stereo system. Maybe I'll get a smart plug so that the Echo Dot can bring them up to speed. If you're thinking about dipping your toes into the smart pool, start with the Echo Dot. You will wonder how you have gotten along without it...I know I do.

I had this product before and had to rebuy it. My wife and I were staying with some people and we used our Alexa everyday we were there. We use it to play music while we are getting ready, rain sounds while we are sleeping, or classical music for our dog Olivia when we are away. Anyway, this family we were staying with never used Alexa before. My wife decided to show them the device and their son really fell in love with it, he's one years old, and he is the reason I need another one. These people were so happy to see their son trying to say Alexa and watching him dance to different songs. My wife offered MY ALEXA to those people, and they accepted! I was so sad to leave her behind. Once we left, I would shout Alexa randomly in my own home and no one answered! I finally demanded that we get another one, so here we are. I will miss Alexa 1 dearly, moral of the story don't let babies near your prized possessions.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good stand-alone BT speakers! HUGE SOUND IMPROVEMENTS OVER 2ND GEN. But Alexa's not for everyone.
reviews.reviewText: While this is a great Bluetooth speaker and overall I love using this device to play Amazon music unlimited and for the occasional Wikipedia reference, I'll be the first to admit that ALEXA STILL HAS A LONG WAY TO GO TO CATCH UP TO GOOGLE ASSISTANT IN TERMS OF EASE OF USE AND CONVERSATIONAL SKILLS, PLUS ACCESSIBILITY OF INFORMATION. When it comes to what is the better speaker this or the Google home mini, this wins hands down. I can say that confidently because I have both. What is the better device? Well that depends on you. And which company's services do you have, if either of theirs? Personally I have both Google play music and Amazon Prime account and additionally I have an Amazon music unlimited account - BUT I only have the Amazon music unlimited account because I have the devices that use it, but the side benefit now is that I get to use it on my phone through the Alexa app and through the Amazon music app. Before I was strictly using Google play music, which was sufficient but sucked on the voice control side comparatively, at least by phone. Anyways with both companies' services being paid for, it makes a straight-up comparison of the Google Home vs Amazon Echo easy and for the Google Home Mini vs the Amazon Echo THIRD GEN, the comparison is REALLY EASY. THIS IS A BETTER DEVICE THAN THE GOOGLE HOME MINI IF YOU KNOW HOW TO USE IT, ESPECIALLY IF YOU ARE ALREADY A PRIME MEMBER, AND REALLY THE CASE IF YOU PAY FOR AMAZON MUSIC UNLIMITED WHICH YOU CAN PAY FOR EVEN IF YOU AREN'T A PRIME MEMBER. My aunt still I think summed it up best when she told me one day, "Alexa or Amazon devices are the best for Entertainment [AND SOUND QUALITY, AS IS, COMPARATIVELY] but Google devices are better at getting information [i.e. question-answering using natural language]". But the sound difference between the 3rd generation dot and the 2nd generation dot is TREMENDOUSLY NOTICABLE to me. Every second generation Echo dot in my house has a additional speaker attached to it, but neither of the two 3rd generation dots, I feel, require an additional speaker - for adequate sound volume w/o loss of clarity. Remember if you want a search engine, choose Google. If you want Alexa's features, then these are currently my recommendation for the best value device for that. Plz see attached videos for more of what I mean and for demonstrated points.

I got my Echo as a "gift with purchase" when I got a new Insignia TV at Best Buy (August 2019), which is the only reason I even have an Echo Dot. I had no desire/need for it, but it's been a fun addition. I don't use it to its potential, partially because I'm not used to it and forget about it even being on my nightstand, but the few tricks I resort to are nice (morning routine/alarm, light and TV switch on-off, weather forecasts).
The biggest thing was having to figure out what each color ring means - yes, there's several colors and speed associated with different notifications/status of the device. That's kind of a pain, as you have to memorize them all or pull up the help section on your phone every time the device lights up without being prompt to. I have had a few issues when I had to log out of my amazon account on my tv and log back in - Alexa didn't automatically reconnect to the account, and it took a good 20 minutes for me to figure out what was going on. Voice recognition can be obnoxious too, as sometimes I have to really raise my voice even if I'm in the same room as the device - and people in other rooms can definitely hear me "yell" at it "ALEXA!"
Overall, it's a fun little gadget to have around the house. I'm obsessed with its design and have been told you can actually even buy cases/masks for it if you want it a different color/pattern. Wouldn't have spent my money on it, but that's just me!

I like that it's fairly fast but hate that it requires way too much personal info in order to do much of anything other then play music or give you the weather conditions. And talking about music. I #$%^& HATE iHEART radio (or any traditional over the air radio station for that matter). I will not pay for music streaming from any source when I have thousands of songs already that I normally listen to at home and in the car, Thankfully I can find stuff I like on 'TuneIn' but it's a pain to have to specify the exact channel each and every time I want it to play. And even then, some channels you can only get to by going through the POS mobile phone app. If I ask Echo (the device) to play a certain channel that I was listening to the day before, it says it can't for various reasons. Yet I can turn on wifi on my phone, fire up the app, go though TuneIn and select the channel and it plays fine. If I was playing a certain channel hours before, the day before or days ago when I last listened to music, I should be able to just say "Echo, play" and it should play the last station I selected. But it doesn't. It defaults to some crappy country station on IHeart and I hate Country music worse then I hate iHeart radio/over-the-air-radio-stations in general. I hate that it can't go over the net and play internet based stations (like DI.FM) that aren't listed in 'TuneIn".
It's ok for asking about the weather while you're busy running around in what ever room you are in. Other then that. I haven't used it for much else and refuse to let it do things that require it to have personal info about me and store it on the $%^& cloud.

I gave this to my 8-year-old daughter for Xmas, mainly so she'd stop moving my Amazon Echo around, making me worry she'd break it. She didn't get much use out of because she also got a tablet from her grandma, so it has kind of just been in her room for my convenience when I'm cleaning in there or putting away laundry. Last weekend I was listening to it, and not loud, mind you, because we live in an apartment and unless I'm singing to something, I'm past the point where loud music is my thing. Anyway, about a half hour after the first song, it started sounding like a stereo does when the speaker is blown. I couldn't believe it! My Echo has never given me a problem and my daughter and her friend have played that thing so loud it couldn't hear them to turn the volume back down. I was irritated that this had broken so quickly, but I got distracted and forgot to do anything about it for about a week. Just in case, I turned it on again and it sounded completely normal. I thought it was just a fluke and maybe I'd been tired and hearing things. However, about a half-hour in, it did the same thing again. Just to test something, I turned it off and turned it back on a minute later. It was fine again, but didn't last that way for a half-hour that time.

Basically, in order to use this, I'm going to have to continually turn it off and turn it back on and when it gets to the point where the normalcy is only lasting a minute or two, I'll have to turn it off completely and let it "recharge" itself. I'm not sure if this is a common problem or not, but I'm extremely disappointed it didn't even last a month, especially when it was barely used and was definitely not mishandled, as it never left my daughter's dresser.

I've never had an Amazon product break like this before, so I'm not sure what the process is here. I would like a replacement, though, still having some hope that I just received the dud in the batch of ones that worked as they should.

I wouldn't not recommend this to someone else, but I might revise this later if the second one doesn't at least make it through the end of the warranty.

reviews.reviewTitle: Much improved sound over the 2nd gen Dot
reviews.reviewText:
I have several of the 2nd gen Echo Dots. Because they are inexpensive, I've used them in places where they might become damaged, such as in the barn or garage, and because they're small, I've also used them in the bathroom. But the sound was very lacking, requiring the volume to be turned all the way up in even a small bathroom to hear adequately, and the sound was tinny and dull. I had to buy a cheap set of computer speakers for the barn and garage because the volume was utterly inadequate for such a large, open space.

The 3rd gen Dot fixes a lot of the sound issues. I bought one to replace the unit in the bathroom. Now music sounds much better, and I only have to set the volume to about 4 or 5 (out of 10) to hear clearly. I haven't tried it out in the barn or garage, but I suspect it might have enough volume to use without external speakers.

The only down sides I've seen so far is that the new version is slightly bigger around, so it won't fit into any 2nd gen wall brackets, and currently there are very few 3rd gen brackets and they tend to be fairly expensive ($17 for a plastic 3rd gen mount vs $5 for a metal 2nd gen mount). It also now takes a proprietary power plug instead of a standard micro-USB like the 2nd gen, so don't lose the cord!

reviews.reviewTitle: "Alexa set the bass to 5; Alexa, reduce the bass by 2.".
reviews.reviewText:
"Alexa set the Bass to 5; Alexa, reduce the Bass by 2.". "Alexa set the Bass to Maximum (+6)" - min. = (-6)
WOW! But it gets even better: Alexa, increase/decrease the Trebble by 2, 3... - (-6) to (+6).

3rd Gen Amazon Alexa enabled Echo Dots are Dual-Band and default to 5G ** if your Internet Modem/Router is dual-band. Therefore, complete compatibility with 1st. and 2nd. Gen. Echos should not be assumed. The third generation line up of Alexa enabled Amazon devices are a remarkable make-over and rethink of an already amazing concept. This product will satisfy anyone's expectations for a Digital Assistant and the Audiophile's single aim--music in its most balanced form; amidst style and flair to be sure, with a totally rethought-out design concept. Gone is the useless and touchy Mini-USB power plug - replace with a standard unified DC 2.1mm. power adaptor and plug. Dust collecting dust-Pit openings on the tops of previous generations have been eliminated in this fresh, new Form Factor, just 4 pin-hole mic. openings remain. One more very important concept designed into this Echo Dot's rollout is the 'Surround Sound' effect design that's accomplished by radiating sound out of the sides of the device and around it in 360° Surround.
** It can switch to 2.4 (4G) Wireless later.

It took me about 30 min to figure out and set up, of course with having to reset a password. things you need to use the echo. Wifi , android 5.1 or higher Fire os 3.0 or higher ios 10.0 or higher. I have an iPhone 7 I think I've updated to 12. 7. so youll need to download the Amazon Alexa app. and then everything should be good. I had no trouble with setup. For me I love it its great, some basic task you can ask and get quick results, like weather,movies imdb,sports,current news, for instance Alexa when is The Bachelorette on?. Music is awesome of course you have to have a subscription, its cheap but I have so many, I hated to add another but the convivence of it all is so worth it if you listen to music a lot you can of course create your own playlist all by voice command . I'm defiantly going to get about 2 more if anything for me the music is awesome. I used to spend too much time searching for something to listen to, its so easy to do it by voice command and still do the dishes or what not, right before I sat down to write this review I asked alexa to set a reminder for me to feed my dogs and she just reminded me thank goodness. lol I totally forgot I set a reminder and to feed the dogs, see its pretty cool. I have the generation 3 my first of this type of device so nothing to compare it to, but I love technology and this is cool. if you do play music loud Alexa may not hear you across the room you have to get closer like 6 ft. an if you use siri a lot good luck not getting annoyed at why Alexa wont answer when you've forgotten her name isn't Siri .

Alexa works great! Definitely makes my life easier...due to health issues it's difficult for me to do some activities. We bought the ECHO Plus, 4 DOTs and the ECHO SHOW. We even have a DOT in the garage so I can contact my husband when he's working outside. Gave DOTs and a SHOW to our children and grandchildren so we can video chat easily.

My recent physical therapist bought 10 DOTs for his family. A brother with severe disabilities shares a 2 level home with his parents. They usually communicate with cell phones, but with the Alexa system they can communicate hands free! If someone has fallen or is injured and cannot get to a phone, they can use voice to call for help.

My mother fell in her home a few weeks ago and did not have her Call Alert button around her neck. She had to crawl across two rooms to reach the phone. She was taken to the hospital and died a week later. If she had the Alexa system, she might have lived longer.

We highly recommend any of the devices for Alexa.

I am really impressed with the 3rd-generation Echo Dot. It sounds MUCH better than the previous models; in fact, it sounds almost as good as a full-size generation 2 Echo, just with less bass. For audio where the bass isn't as important (e.g. classical orchestra, audiobooks, or voice calls), I don't even notice the difference in bass unless I'm thinking about it.

Put another way, the 3rd-gen Dot sounds good enough that your average user probably won't feel the need to connect it to an external speaker.

The third generation is also much better looking than the second generation, due to the fabric cover. It looks classy just about anywhere you put it.

My only major complaint is that the Echo Dot's microphones aren't as good as the full-size Echo. The 2nd-gen Echo has 7 microphone holes and can understand me no matter where I am, how much background noise there is, or how loudly I'm talking. The 3rd-gen Echo Dot, on the other hand, only has more microphone holes, and seems to have trouble hearing me if I'm too far away, not facing it directly, or there is too much background noise (including noise coming from its own speakers).

I do think the standard retail price of $50 is a bit of a ripoff, but the sale price of $30 is a good value.

reviews.reviewTitle: Compared to echo gen 1, it's MILES better!
reviews.reviewText:
I use my Echo Dot primarily while I'm in the shower to check the time, weather, and play trivia games like Jeopardy. Echo gen 1, I felt the volume wasn't quite loud enough or clear enough to understand all the words in the trivia questions. I usually had to have it repeated once or twice. This Echo, it's not a problem! Maybe one repeat per 12 questions. Also, this Echo's understanding of my answer is WAY BETTER! Over 30 days of usage, I think she misunderstood me once or twice, playing every day. I know there are bigger problems in the world, but it was still frustrating to know the right answer, only to get it wrong because she thought I said something else. I would recommend this gen Echo 100% :)

Also, my 9 year old son listens to Prime music while he is in the shower. I asked him if he thinks this generation is better, and I got a resounding YAASSSSS!

I hope this helps anyone thinking of upgrading!

reviews.reviewTitle: Alexa - You Make a Great Product!
reviews.reviewText: What can I say? These are just awesome. Throughout my house I have a combination of 8 of these in different styles. Yes, apparently I am addicted to them! Great product and never fails me!

reviews.reviewTitle: ALL OF US WERE DISAPPOINTED IN ALEXA'S NEW VOICE BUT AMAZON CAME THRU
reviews.reviewText:
After posting the ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW I actually received a call from Amazon support. That AMAZED me. They pointed out some settings I missed that had been added to the control app on my cell for the device. In particular, I could now adjust the treble & bass. This essentially cured my issue.

YAY AMAZON! RENEWED FAITH!

=== ORIGINAL REVIEW ===
We still have our Echo Dot 2nd Generation tucked in a draw & it looks like she's going to be put back to work. We gave this 3rd generation a fair chance, almost 3 weeks, BUT WE ARE STILL HAVEING A DIFFICULT TIME ADJUSTING TO THE MORE MUFFLED SOUND OF ALEXA. _EVERYONE_ who hears "her" says the very same thing. I am so frustrated at this point I want to kick myself. I usually never buy a new version when released, and I know if it ain't broke, don't try to fix it, but I made an exception in this case because I trusted Amazon not to screw up something so basic as Alexa's voice. I was prepared to live with some initial bugs, BUT TO FIND THIS STRANGER IN THE HOUSE MASQUERADING AS ALEXA WAS SOMETHING I NEVER EXPECTED.

Perhaps you will feel differently or your hearing is different. However, it was not just me that felt this way. Literally everyone is saying the say thing. WHY DID THEY DO THAT???

I was looking forward to having an Echo again in my apartment. I had the 1st Echo, that big black one. And I was mad excited about this one. First, maybe I should have placed it next to my Google Mini and not the Home. It was weak in turns of playing music, its like it's missing something. So I'm looking to upgrade to the New Echo that is $109, maybe. I'm only looking to have this control my microwave and ac united, maybe I will keep it due to the low price. Not too sure but I know I'm not to happy with the sound.

O.k. I had NO IDEA that the Echo Dot could work all on its own! I thought that you had to have a base Alexa unit, and the dots were just add-ons. Nope! I was recently at a BBQ and they were entertaining the birthday guests with the Echo Dot! Alexa even sang Happy Birthday to the birthday girl! How crazy is that? The host had the Echo Dot connected to this really cool Bluetooth speaker and it sounded great in the backyard, in fact, they had to keep turning it down because people were yelling over the music!

After the party I was sold and had to go home and order my own Echo Dot! It is insane how much this little device can do! You can ask Alexa anything and she will come up with an answer from google. Very rarely does she not have an answer for your question. She will tell you jokes, weather, news, etc. You can set timers, alarms, add items to your grocery/to do list, or control your smart T.V. without even picking up the remote!

The Echo Dot sounds phenomenal. For the small size (about the size of your palm) this thing can put out a lot of sound! and if you are trying to be quiet , you can whisper to Alexa and she will whisper back to you! You can tell Alexa to play a specific song, or a genre of music and rock out for hours. You can make hands free calls to your loved ones!

I am in love with my new Echo Dot and will be purchasing more for other rooms in the house (you can even sync music and notifications to all of the dots throughout your house!)

My one complaint about the Echo Dot is the length of the cord. I wish it were a bit longer, but hey, minor detail. I would recommend this to anyone who likes a little hands free technology and entertainment in their home!

reviews.reviewTitle: Echo makes life easier and gives a peace of mind.
reviews.reviewText: The 3rd generation Echo is the best so far. I own a 2nd generation Echo and it serves its purpose. This 3rd generation has a higher quality speaker, looks better and has more functionality as I often use it as a speaker phone when I’m not in the mood to hold an actual phone. Thanks to the Locate (Or find) My Phone skill, Alexa is a lifesaver. I have two of these 3rd gerations, one being in my bedroom and thanks to the available skills, I can set an alarm, mediate, and drift off to a restful sleep with soft words and peaceful sounds. The only thing I can recommend is a better data base for information as Alexa is often stumped and responds with an “I don’t know that.” Please know: I purchased an Echo 3rd generation for my elderly mother as a backup plan in case of emergency. She can simply say: call or Drop-in on my daughter, and my echo and/or phone rings. Although she has a medical alert system, this is an additional tool that ads some peace of mind. This Echo works fantastically with my robot vacuume and smart light bulbs. Amazon Echo definitely makes my life easier. *Please know: I’m positive that Amazon would never suggest or encourage this device as a substitute form of a medical alert but in my opinion, it never hurts to add anything that might help.

The most irritating piece of junk I have ever come across. every 30 seconds, it announces, "now connected to {my laptop name}" but it's not connected - then 30 seconds later, the same thing. You can't shut her up!
Then when I explicitly 'removed' it from my laptop - it pops up with that request to connect (see attached image)

It is like a defective big-brother - just constantly harassing you with its malfunction!
I'd return it, but I threw away the boxes - Another one of Bezos' scams. I was gonna get a Beatspill - I should've got the BeatsPill! (At least the ModelT worked!)

I bought it with the hopes that it would do the same some tasks that Google home mini can do. I was wrong. The echo dot is a nice idea and good things could come from it but I am not seeing it. Alexa wouldn't tell me about my orders, couldn't give instructions on carving a turkey, couldn't tell me where the nearest Chinese restaurant is, and can't answer simple questions. The only thing I found decent is that it pulls up the exact song I want to hear. With my purchase Amazon sent me a free 90 days of Amazon music. After looking at it they want .99 cents. That's not free. Side by side with the Google home mini the echo fails to do what Google has nearly perfected. If you are really trying to choose between the 2. I fully recommend the Google home mini over Amazon. For every test I did the echo dot failed to out perform its biggest rival. This product may be great for some but I wasn't impressed by it. Perhaps one day Amazon will beat Google but that's not likely to happen. The echo dot has severe compatibility issues and the app constantly crashes where as I've never had an issue with Google. So I say again go with the Google home mini as this product is a fail out of the box

reviews.reviewTitle: Big Improvement in sound quality over older Dot gen 2
reviews.reviewText:
I didn't mind the small size and low sound quality of the older Dot gen 2 for the bedroom to set a wakeup alarm or ask what time it is in the middle of the night without needing to turn on a light or even listen to the news with the flash briefing either before bed or upon waking up. I even enjoyed the ambient sleep sounds to help me block out noisy neighbors when falling asleep.
So I didn't expect much more from the 3rd generation of the Dot, and I liked the fact it had a 3.5mm audio output so I could connect it to a set of powered speakers if I needed to, however I was pleasantly surprised to hear the increased volume and especially bass in this 3rd gen Dot.
I ordered a few of them on Cyber Monday to pair them as stereo pairs in the kitchen and they seem better sounding to me than the original Alexa Echo I had in the kitchen, maybe it's because of the stereo or that one is in one corner of kitchen and the other is in the other side?
Regardless I am really enjoying the purchases and since moved my lower sounding Dot gen 2 to the bathroom where loud music isn't needed.
I highly recommend the Dot Gen 3's for all over the house.
Get them on sale in pairs and you'll find you won't even need to listen to them at half the volume setting.
:)

Kind of cool but also very annoying. Doesn't work right half the time. If you're power goes out randomly at night, Alexa resets and turns all the lights on. For being so smart this device lacks a lot of simple things, like the ability to sense power surges or listen to clearly spoken words. Yell her to turn off my TV and the device is not working properly, check your power supply. Tell her to turn of my WINDOW and she powers down the TV. AMAZON, y'all sold this? Works to tell the weather, play music, and work the lights in the house (sometimes). Wish I would have bought 1 not 4. I thought they would be better than this. A $50 dollar tablet can tell me the weather and play music plus some. Hopefully Alexa will get better. I'm considering taking mine offline and selling them. Time will tell but lately I've been SUPER DISAPPOINTED with my Alexa. Especially with the power outage situation. If I were Amazon I'd work at fixing the current bugs in Alexa more so than focusing on making it talk like Samuel Jackson or other stuff.

reviews.reviewTitle: Side by side I decided to keep the Amazon Echo Plus over the Echo Dot
reviews.reviewText: I liked the Echo Dot, until I received the Echo Plus. The sound from the Plus was just so much better than the Dot. If I hadn't received the Plus as a gift, I would have kept the Dot: It was easy to use, easy to set up and responded as soon as I got it hooked up to my Wi-Fi using the app downloaded from the app store. But...once I got the Echo Plus the difference in sound quality was pretty obvious, and since both do essentially the same functions, decided to keep the Echo Plus due to the better sound quality. All in all it was very easy to set up, pretty much worked straight out of the box. The only thing I wish Amazon would work on is getting rid of the plug which is why I took one star off my rating. Having to use a plug makes these devices so much less portable. I wonder why the Echos are still tethered to a power cord, in this day and age of easy Bluetooth availability. I haven't used the Echo for anything more than asking simple questions and streaming music. As of yet, I haven't purchased anything, made any shopping lists or used the device for any " higher" functions. Maybe in the future I'll be saying "Alexa, order me...". It certainly seems it would be easy enough.

UPDATE: 08-05-2019. I've given up on this model. The sound is smeared or blurry. Maybe younger ears can make out what's being said. My wife's hearing is excellent and she can't understand anything it says. My hearing is fair and I find it difficult to make out the words. It's like the sounds are smeared or blurry. I don't know why this model was released to the public as it clearly isn't ready. And that's the only thing that IS clear about it. My friends have the taller model and it is easy to understand. So now I'm stuck with this DOT thing that I liked because of its size and price. I can't believe that this made it through an Amazon engineering review! Didn't anyone at Amazon try listening to this thing? You need to get a cross-section of the potential market to listen and evaluate its performance. Of course, this should have been done before I bought it. Your service sent out another unit, however, this is an inherent design flaw, not a one-off defect. The replacement was as blurry as the original.

I really like the echo dot 3. You can use it in smaller rooms without a separate speaker or you can add a bluetooth or audio cable directly to a speaker.
The sound quality out of it's own speaker is not jaw dropping. Truthfully, the sound is ok. At low volume or high volumes it gives acceptable audio. When connected to an external speaker then the quality sounds as good as your speaker can sound (or as bad).
The look is much better than the previous echo dot 2 and comes in 3 different colors.
I use money to control several smart devices ( light bulbs, humidifier/aromatherapy, smart plugs, Nest thermostat,etc). All of these work flawlessly with the echo dot 3. Non of my devices require a hub, so for the $49 you get a lot. It can answer many question, although not as many as the google home mini. You can play games on it like Jeopardy. It can tell you jokes, play music of course and much more. All you need do is add the equipment (bulbs, thermostat, etc) and allow the skill in the Amazon Echo App.
I use mine every single day without fail. In fact I now have 1 in nearly every room in my house.
You can also control any of the other echos that you have from any other echo. You can also play the same song on all echoes if you choose. So if you are are walking in and out of other rooms you can continue to hear the same song. The only thing that could make this better is a little bit richer sound from the internal speaker (which, again isn't bad). However, to do that, I am certain that a price increase would be involved. I think $49 is a fantastic price and not to hard to swallow if you want to get multiple units like I have.

I bit the bullet and bought one for s**ts and giggles along with some cheap legelite smart bulbs. The only light source in my bedroom is my ceiling fan lights, and the pull cord broke on it years ago. So I have to unscrew the bulbs by hand to turn off my lights but keep the fan on.

Not anymore. The echo was a quick setup. The bulbs arrived a day later and were setup within minutes. I can use my voice to turn on and off my lights now; I can set brightness per bulb or group name by voice, change color, etc.

I dig the routines so you can customize responses, actions, or sequences of actions. You can even further install skills directly from the amazon website or within the app to further increase the dot's capabilities. Or you can create your own or customize existing simple templates.

I like the alarms best. With two jobs, one with different hours each day I work, I love the ability to add yet another set of alarms to wake me up. My favorite feature of this is the ability to say "set an alarm for one hour" if you wanna just plop down for a nap without having to make or edit an alarm on your phone.

One thing I'd like to see is some more phone app integrations, something standardized and easy for app developers to integrate. One of my favorite android apps to use before bed is Calm. I'd like the ability to integrate a specific guided sleep meditation as part of a sleep routine on the dot.

The sound quality is great for what it is. While not sufficiently bassy, it can rumble and vibrate a whole table at full volume.

It's relatively responsive to my voice. I can say "echo" and wake it even when netflix is playing at talking volume but it won't recognize what I'm saying if netflix has talking while I speak. It will pick up my voice across my bedroom at around 10 feet away.

Overall I'll probably upgrade to the plus model in the future and add in more smarthome things. The whole automation aspect isn't really of use to me but just having the voice control is pretty nifty.

I think other reviews have covered the many pros and cons of this device over others, so I’ll just reiterate how this compares to the two others I own. Compared to Borge the second gen dot and to the Spot, the sound quality of this device is much louder and more dynamic. We have been really impressed by it after. Wing used to listening to music on the other two Alexa devices. We had even purchased a Bluetooth speaker to use with the second generation dot, but it is absolutely unnecessary to use with the third generation. The Spot’s audio is fine, but lacks the depth of the 3rd gen Dot.
This unit is a bit larger than the previous generations, but it’s worth the extra counter space. It otherwise works just like the others, with no other issues in terms of Alexa integration or voice recognition. That technology is continually evolving, so we are consistently seeing advances in how we can interact with and be better understood by Alexa. Great purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: great sound but Very hard to enable all the skills except for the very basics.
reviews.reviewText: It has great sound quality for such a small device. Got it on sale for $29. Would’ve been pissed if I paid 50 for this. It seems like it has a lot of skills. But trying to get them all to work is another story. It is very complicated to set up the skills to get your TV to work with it or your Amazon fire stick to work properly with that. Anything but setting up the very basics is extremely difficult at least for me it is so I would assume for others it is to . Right now the only thing I can do with it is play music call and text my friends ask weather and turn on tv. If I ask to launch Netflix or something like that forget it it always says I don’t know how to do that one time and then the very next time it’ll do it and I had made no changes so what’s going on here. Please simplify your products Amazon. Just like the only music I can play from this device is Amazon music. I really wanted to buy your second generation echo deluxe is with the woofer I believe it was about 350 Dollars but when I discovered all I could do is play music from Amazon forget it why can’t I play music from my sources. I believe for this reason you were losing a great amount of sales.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sounds is louder but muffled, not as clear as Gen 2 Echo Dot's.
reviews.reviewText:
I have 3 (2nd Gen) Echo Dot's and I just purchased this Gen 3 Echo Dot (Amazon stopped selling the Gen 2's), it's not that I'm used to the way the Gen 2 sounds, there's clearly a difference between the Gen 2 and Gen3 in voice sound clarity, to be honest the Gen 2 sounds much better, clearer, in the way Alexa's voice sounds in response to questions, to me the Gen 3 sounds muffled, like talking with your hand over your mouth loudly! I tried adjusting the "Audio Controls", Bass, Midrange and Treble within the Alexa app but it doesn't really help. The Gen 2 just outperforms the Gen 3 in voice clarity, period!
When listening to music however the Gen 3 outperforms the Gen 2 in music/sound quality but how often do you listen to music through the built in speaker? I use an external bluetooth speaker set for that. If your purchasing the Gen 3 to play music then you'll be really happy with it, if not, stick with the Gen 2, if you can still find them...

**Appearance**
The new look of the echo dot 3rd generation looks way better than its previous models. It has a more modern look with a nice material finish on the outside so that it looks less like a hockey pick and more of a well-designed device. I love the customization options for it, the designs look well made and smooth, but I wish they would add more there's only 3 when there are so many colors out there! It doesn't seem like you can take off the outside cover on it; so you'd have to buy it from a third party. It's also slightly bigger than its other models but it's not something noticeable.

**Setup**
It is not powered by a micro USB like the previous model instead it comes with a power adapter that you plug into a wall. This removes a lot of freedom such as plugging it into a computer or using another form of power. Having that accessibility is important because you want to give the customers all the freedom they can. With a micro USB, you don't have to worry about having to plug it away from where exactly you want it. The way it is set up is by the Alexa app. The setup is relatively simple but for me, it took longer than expected as I would be connected to the wifi it was on but it would not give me any further steps. It wasn't a big deal but I thought it was worth mentioning.

**Performance**
It has great functionality it is useful for hooking up to devices such as smart lights, door locks, etc. It can read notifications off your phone with the voice command, control other devices, listen to music, play games, make phone calls, and a plethora of other stuff. It also has an audio jack for you to connect speakers to if you do not like the built-in speaker. You can get traffic updates, weather information, and you can even connect multiple echo devices. It is very useful for example, if mom is in the kitchen and the food is done, she can announce the food is done via her voice and let an announcement out to inform others. This is very useful for when you're far away in the house making it convenient instead of having you walk you the designated person. It has functionality that you can use. The echo dot also has skills. One example of an of a skill is the find my phone skill. Doing this will let Alexa make a phone call to your phone which can be used if you cannot find your phone.

*What I dislike *
One thing I very dislike is the fact it doesn't hear me quite often. I'll be 10 yards away and I have to yell for it to hear me which is very annoying. I have to be very close to it to hear me; this is a very big let down for me. Now the music. You can only play off of a radio station or have a subscription to pay to Amazon. However, on the Google home mini, you can play music off of Google Play Music for free. I do not think it should be so difficult for these smart speakers to force us to buy a subscription for such a single task.

*You should get a Google home mini instead*

The google mini has more customizations, for starters, you can edit the voice from many different choices. You can choose from male and female, and even different accents. On alexa, you cannot change the female voice which limits users by a lot. The Google mini looks better and has mostly the same functionality as the Alexa.

This is a good device and is very useful. If you plan to get it I'm sure you'll love it and it'll be very useful, however, when you look closer into the details, you'll see its competitor can be the better device.

I'm really enjoying my Echo Dot Smart Speaker with Alexa. I am truly amazed at what all you can do with this device. The first night I hooked it up, I was able to get her to recognize my voice out of a group of people. Now I only bought myself one, but if you buy multiples, you are supposed to be able to link them and you can use them sort of like an intercom system to talk to people in another room. You can also do things like have her to make a shopping list, look things up online, play playlists or the thing that really blew my mind....play games!! Yes she will play games with you! You can choose from kids games, adult games, family games, single player, multiplayer, game show games... the list goes on and on! This entertained my older kids for the longest! I even tried it out myself and had a blast. There are still so many things I have yet to try, but I'm already impressed. Now, a few things I wasn't so impressed with is the fact that its not rechargeable. You can unplug it and take to another room with you. Also, there are things you try to ask Alexa to look up, and you have to ask several different ways before she knows how to get an answer for you. Then, there are times you have to get pretty close and loud for her to hear you, but other times, not so much. Those are really the only things I have complaints about. I would still buy this again in a heartbeat. As a matter of fact, I bought two extras to give as gifts.

reviews.reviewTitle: The 3rd Gen a vast improvement over the 2nd Gen!!
reviews.reviewText:
This third Gen is the bomb. I’ve had every generation of the echo dot and the regular Alexa and I have to say that this third generation dodge even almost exceeds the regular Alexa. The sound quality is amazing and it has a very sleek design. I bought three of them and I wish I would’ve bought more. Amazon great job on this design. I can’t wait to see what’s on the hopper.

The voice recognition is spot on. I put it in front of a desk top fan to introduce noise and there is no issue fully understanding the smallest of command detail. The second Gen would sometimes not fully understand my voice commands because of the fan in close proximity. The directional microphone’s must’ve been adjusted to accommodate human voice versus ambient noise conditions.

I almost sound like a fanboy and I am not as I do not own any other Amazon products meaning their Kindles, Smart Products, etc. but these Alexa Dots are amazing.

It's great when it is working. But that is the problem, it doesn't work all of the time. There are some days when the Dot 3 tells me that "it doesn't understand". I unplug it and it may come back "on-line" and then there are days when unplugging it does nothing and it just turns red and "hhhuummmms" at me.
I never have any problems with my Echo Dot 2.

for controlling alexa app lights and sockets. not so good. in fact bad. works for awhile through alexa ten stops. but works thru the app on your phone. this is an update. a few days after writing this review. believe it or not. amazon contacted me and helped me with my issues. which are no more. the support help. talked to me with great concern. about my problem with my alexa's. they took a lot of time to help me get thru this. and more or less is was my fault. for not knowing to update the alexa app. that these programs work in. once I updated the app. everything started to work with alexa. had to reboot my other two alexa's two the new app. even though they said they were their. new app new reboot. every thing ok. I should have called them in the first place. but I jumped the gun. who would have thought that they actually read these review's. so now I upgraded them to five stars. could not ask for better. patient. and understanding service. the girl I had was wonderful. so any problems. give them a call. before you judge here. like I know now.

reviews.reviewTitle: Awesome Sound, Alexa Responsiveness - Not So Much
reviews.reviewText:
I had the earlier generation echo dot, and traded it in for the new generation echo dot - its a completely different experience. So here are some of the pros and cons I noticed as compared to previous generation echo dot:

Pros:

1.Sound quality (alexa sound or music or news) is much, much better and deeper, richer in the new echo dot. The bass is is definitely an upgrade - plus with the larger body, I think it has bigger speakers - so the sound produced is much nicer.

2. Form Factor: The fabric exterior casing is definitely a huge plus, as it is more soothing to the eye than the plastic casing for the previous gen echo dot.

Cons

1. Alexa responsiveness: The new echo dot has 4 ( I think) microphones, as compared to 8 on the previous generation echo dot. I have noticed that Alexa is not as responsive and takes more time to pick up voice commands.

2. The blue ring on the top much more jittery when you say alexa (it moves in an awkward manner when you call alexa and the light blue portion of the blue rings adjusts to where you are speaking from). Definitely a more awkward, less responsive Alexa.

3. Size: Its way bigger than the previous echo dot, while the fabric casing is a plus, the size, in my opinion, the previous gen echo dot was better

Overall: This echo dot is great - the only thing that is lacking is sufficient microphones so that Alexa responsiveness is as good as the previous gen echo dot

reviews.reviewTitle: Seriously you will be addicted just buy 5 and get it over with, yea it's that good!
reviews.reviewText: Wow! Honestly this product is probably the best buy of the year. Alexa can do so much! It is amazing. If you do not have Alexa buy this now. Its affordable and even though I've only had it for a few days I honestly am going to buy like 4 more because it makes everything so easy! Dim the lights, turn the tv down, tell a story before bed, turn on the xbox, launch netflix on the xbox, launch whatever on any platform, tell me how far it is to the moon, and so on so on. My kids are having so much fun getting to see what all they can do with it, and they are advancing themselves by playing trivia with Alexa! Yea outside of school on summer break my kids are playing trivia with Alexa! This is incredible and I am just going to have to buy more. I could not be happier! Not only does it have all of the above features (I didn't even come close to touching all of her features) but the sound quality is perfect for any large room! This is an amazing buy!

reviews.reviewTitle: It’s worth more than every penny you spend on it!
reviews.reviewText: I love my Alexa! I mostly use it to play games with. My favorite games are Escape Room, Escape The Airplane, Dungeon Adventures, Price Tag, Song Quiz, The Magic Door (there’s an overall adventure so you should get online and look it up after you play it the first time), Jack Ryan November Morning, and The Vortex. I also have Apple Music. It’s totally worth buying Apple Music because you can play any song your heart desires. You can create playlists and then ask Alexa to shuffle or play your “Whatever you named your playlist” playlist. I also ask Alexa for the weather report every day. You can also say, “Alexa, what will the temperature be at 10am?” Or “what’s the forecast for Saturday?” I can also have Alexa turn on my Fire TV and tell it to bring up a specific show or genre or have Alexa turn the TV off. You can also buy devices to turn lights on and off. There is so much more you can do and the device is so cheap you can’t get something so cheap that has so much to offer.

I just received the newest Dot (3) device; I am quite interested in many of its features. But I find it hard to believe that Amazon has not made more progress in the kinds of bluetooth devices which Dot can find and connect to. I have a JBL Flip 2 speaker, TaoTronics Wireless 4.1 Magnetic Earbuds, and BÖHM Wireless Bluetooth Headphones with Active Noise Cancelling Headphones Technology. NONE of these apparently will be connected with Dot. The JBL works fine with wired connection, but hardly the point for bluetooth use. You should not advertise the Dot as "able to connect with bluetooth devices" when you are very limited in the kinds of devices able to be connected. Very disappointed given my usual experiences with Amazon products.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great little "machine" to own - useful info provider, in addition to music and book reader
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this 3rd generation Echo because the sound of my previous version echo is sort of low.
This 3rd generation has a much better sound but i often times have to speak in a very loud voice so that the thing will stop what is doing because it does not recognize what i am saying. It is a little "hard of hearing" this unit i have.
However, I love the echo product. I like to use the echo in the setting that speaks back to you because i like to teach the kids that a please and a thank you is appropriate, always .. and it works to add a little politeness to them, which is great.
I use both echo i own for everything - from phone calls to friends, to locate my phone when i misplace it, to recipe and all the other good stuff. I love it --- just wish my newer echo was not so "hard of hearing" when i try to interrupt when she is not responding correctly to my request.

I wrote 3 of the first 1,000 skills for the Amazon Echo when it first came out as part of a developer program. I received a first generation Echo, which has been absolutely fantastic. I wrote a few more skills and got a few more first generation Echo Dots. They were OK for listening to news, etc., but music on them was very tin-sounding.

Fast forward to a couple of weeks ago and my wife saw the third-generation Echo Dot at an Amazon pop-up store at the mall. They had a promotion where if you bought two, you got $20 off, so she texted to ask me what color I wanted. I put it on my desk at home and I'm blown away by its sound quality. I'd say the sound quality of it is close to or at par versus the 1st generation Echo.
